HEADLINE: WORKING;
Someone Has To Be an Adult

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I belong to two work teams that can't seem to get along. I am frequently asked to choose sides in their disagreements. Sometimes, all I have to do to raise the ire of somebody on one team is to mention the name of a member of the other. Any suggestions?
 
A. My condolences. As any parent could tell you, what your co-workers clearly need is a timeout. The boss should put them all into a corner until they learn not to turn their professional differences into a midlife version of playground warfare. 
 Barring such intervention, however, your best bet is to stay neutral, said Andrew J. DuBrin, a professor of management at the Rochester Institute of Technology's business college and the author of "Winning Office Politics" (Prentice Hall Trade, 1990). Trying to appease both factions -- by pretending that you're on the side of whoever happens to be grousing in your office -- only fuels the conflict, and is likely to catch up with you eventually.
Refusing to take sides should not be confused, however, with ignoring the problem. When conflict arises, feel free to voice your opinion of the merits and weaknesses of each side's position, he said, but take pains to remain as detached as possible. In time, people will understand that you are putting the company's interests first -- and they may even come around to your way of thinking.
In other words, by behaving like the one grown-up in this crowd, you may ultimately shame your colleagues into better behavior. At the very least, they'll realize that they can't use you as a sounding board for their whining.
If people continue to push you to take sides, gently push back, Mr. DuBrin advised. Tell them you realize that the two teams don't get along well, and ask them what they want you to do about it. This will challenge them to come up with constructive proposals or, failing that, to get off your case.
Do not feel obliged to assume the role of playground monitor. You shouldn't have to mediate among adults, said Elaine Duffy, a psychologist specializing in organizational effectiveness.
You can talk with team members individually, telling them you've noticed that the conflict is beginning to set them back in achieving their goals, said Ms. Duffy, who is also a consultant with Learning Systems International in Providence, R.I. But don't confront them, because then you will only receive angry responses.
Above all, don't beat yourself up if relations don't improve. You've done your best, and blaming yourself for other people's pettiness can only be self-defeating.
However, if the situation deteriorates to the point where you fear that your own performance is suffering, don't hesitate to take the matter upstairs. There's no reason that you should have to stay after class just because the other boys and girls refuse to play nice.
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
In Long Branch, an Anchor for Redevelopment Area

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
OVER the last decade there have been several proposals to turn a shoreline tract in Long Branch into housing. But none materialized and the site, a small portion of which is used as a parking lot for beachgoers, has remained undeveloped.
Now new owners expect to start work this month on transforming the 9.2-acre tract at the southeast corner of Ocean and Brighton Avenues into a $30-million luxury residential enclave. Called Renaissance on the Ocean, it will have 87 residences, ranging from condominium apartments to town houses and single-family detached homes priced from $375,000 to $1.9 million. 
 Using bank financing and its own equity, Renaissance Construction, of Neptune, will develop the project, which has all its local approvals but is awaiting state approval. It will rise in the West End neighborhood of the Monmouth County seashore city of 29,000 residents, not far from a 150-acre oceanside district targeted by Long Branch for residential and commercial redevelopment.
A group of New Jersey investors -- including the principals of Renaissance Construction, Charles Silberberg and Michael Gohar -- bought the property for $2.3 million last year. The seller, the DeMatteis Organizations of Uniondale, L.I., had proposed several of the earlier unrealized housing projects on the site, including one for three towers with a total of 330 condominium units and another for 125 town houses.
Mr. Silberberg, executive vice president at Renaissance, said that among the reasons for the purchase were the limited supply of oceanfront land and the pent-up demand for "quality upscale housing" at the water's edge. He pointed to the successful sales campaign of the nearby 55-unit Villas at Harbor Island town-house project, where over the last year all but six units have been sold at prices ranging from $250,000 to $500,000.
Location was another reason. The city's West End neighborhood is less than a mile from Deal to the south, where some homes cost in the millions of dollars. And a mile to the north is the 150-acre oceanfront redevelopment district, part of Long Branch's five miles of shoreline, where an effort is being made to inject new economic life into the city.
Long Branch was a grand summer resort until the 50's when residents and businesses started leaving for shore communities farther south. The years that followed brought one revitalization plan after another that ran afoul of local politics, economic pressures or community opposition. While the mid-80's building boom brought a spate of development, including a 250-room hotel and some 500 condominium units, prosperity continued to elude the city.
Determined to turn the situation around, city officials together with residents and business groups, known as Long Branch Tomorrow, approved a redevelopment plan in 1996 for the mostly desolate oceanfront strip. It envisions a new village on the site that would have 1,300 market-rate residences, and 600,000 square feet of commercial space.
The plan also calls for some $20 million in public investment for such improvements as resanding and extending the city's beach, a project that is now nearing completion under an Army Corps of Engineers program.
In addition, Ocean Boulevard will be redesigned to help reunite the oceanfront with the rest of Long Branch. And an old amusement pier, shut down after a fire, has been razed by the city, which is negotiating with private investors to rebuild it into a commercial and entertainment center, said Carl Turner, planning director for Long Branch.
THE difference between the 1996 plan and earlier proposals, Mayor Adam Schneider said, "is that it opened up the planning process to the public, creating a public-private partnership and an environment where economic investment makes sense."
The plan also is consistent with state regulations for developments in the coastal region, extending along shorefront and inlets for 127 miles south of Raritan Bay in Perth Amboy. But the state has made an exception for Long Branch.
The state regulations -- governed under the 1973 Coastal Area Facility Review Act -- require developers to obtain a permit for most projects from the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection in addition to local approvals.
In the case of Long Branch, however, the environmental agency amended its regulations to include what is known as "the Long Branch rule." Under it, the state last summer agreed to allow the city to approve projects within the redevelopment district, though the state retains veto power, said Raymond E. Cantor, assistant commissioner at the department's Office of Land-Use Management and Compliance, which oversees coastal development.
The result is that with city approval alone needed, subject to state veto, the review process is expedited, Mr. Cantor said, adding that the Long Branch rule "is viewed as a model that can be replicated."
Mr. Turner, the Long Branch planning director, said the city would consider tax abatements and other incentives, including helping developers acquire sites, to draw investment to its shoreline.
He also said the city had entered memorandums of understanding with developers for three projects that would produce 80,000 square feet of retail space and about 875 residences and that construction of the commercial project could start by next year. He said the operators of the existing hotel, the Oceanplace Conference and Resort, also hope to undertake an $8 million expansion and renovation project and to build a second building, for which approvals are in place.
"The goal," added Mayor Schnieder, "is not for Long Branch to be just a summer resort, but to become both a destination and a place to live by the ocean that has a year-round economy." He said estimates were that the plan, if realized, would take about 10 years, represent a $150 million investment and generate more than $3 million in new tax revenue a year.
Though not in the redevelopment area, the Renaissance on the Ocean project, along with the nearby 55-unit townhouse development, is considered crucial to the city's revival. "Both are anchors for the southern end of the redevelopment district," Mr. Turner said.
Mr. Silberberg, of Renaissance Construction, said while earlier plans for the site called for a greater number of residences, "we felt a lower-density, upscale project would be more attractive and more successful." What sells is ocean views, he said, noting that all the residences would have balconies and that most would have views of the water.
To meet the state's requirement for public oceanfront-view corridors the developers reconfigured the buildings on the site and scaled back the project from 90 units to its current size. Because part of the site was used for public parking for about 50 cars another concern from the state -- as well as a local surfers' group -- is the loss of those spaces.
So Mr. Silberberg said Renaissance would provide 34 parking spaces along Brighton Avenue for public use and is making a $100,000 contribution to the city to buy land in the neighborhood to create more parking.
Despite the recent gyrations of the stock market he said his company was proceeding with the project because the fundamentals of the housing market remain strong and the still-low mortgage interest rates have helped offset buyer uncertainty. Since sales opened in June, nonbinding reservations of $2,500 have been taken on 50 of the 87 units.
The project, designed by James J. Monteforte of Neptune, will contain two four-story buildings, one with 18 simplex and 20 duplex condominiums, the other with 8 simplexes and 8 duplexes. They will have two to four bedrooms and 1,920 to 2,838 square feet. There is also underground parking. Prices range from $285,000 to $625,000.
There will also be 26 town-house style condominiums, each with three bedrooms and 1,920 to 2,320 square feet of space. Some will have garages, others will have basements and garage parking. Prices range from $375,000 to $795,000. The project will also offer five single-family detached homes with 3,300 to 4,400 square feet priced from $1.5 million to $1.9 million and two attached houses, each with 2,320 square feet and priced at $950,000.
The architecture of the project is classic Southwestern style -- ivory-colored stucco facades with mission tiled roofs. Amenities include a 2,324-square-foot clubhouse, an outdoor swimming pool and a tennis court. Monthly maintenance fees are expected to be $318 to $610.
The project has been attracting empty-nesters, young families, and baby boomers who are "thinking of retiring and of enjoying life," Mr. Silberberg said. He added that the project would be built over the next two years.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Bridgeport Turns to Waterfront to Spur Economy

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
AFTER more than 30 years of grinding depression, failed attempts at urban renewal and dashed hopes for a casino, Bridgeport is now reclaiming its decaying waterfront in an effort to stimulate its economy.
It is replacing deteriorated industrial buildings and substandard housing with Harbour Place, a $1-billion, 3-million-square-foot commercial and retail project designed to attract tourists and generate economic activity in the surrounding area. 
 Capitalizing on the public's affinity for the sea and maritime environments, as demonstrated in the success of waterfront developments in Portland, Me., Portsmouth, N.H., Boston and Baltimore -- as well as Norwalk -- the city began acquiring 38 properties for the first 30-acre phase of the project last June. Demolition of existing buildings and relocation of residential and commercial owners and tenants is expected to be completed in December. Completion of the entire project could take 10 years.
The site is a 52-acre peninsula bounded by Interstate 95, the Pequonnock River, Yellow Mill Pond and Bridgeport Harbor. It is just across the Stratford Avenue bridge from downtown. "This will be a huge boon for the city," said Joseph P. Ganim, Bridgeport's Mayor since 1991.
The first phase of Harbour Place will be a 1.3 million square foot retail mall with restaurants, a 20-screen movie theater and a large-screen IMAX theater. Construction is expected to begin in about 18 months and an opening is planned for the fall of 2002.
The rest of the site would include an Early American "village" with restaurants, shops, a fishing pier, a waterside esplanade, a 400-room hotel and conference center next to a 250- suite hotel, a maritime museum and amphitheater, a fitness and wellness center and a 6,500-space parking garage.
Amenities envisioned at the shoreline or in the water include a marina, a docked ocean liner converted to a hotel, restaurant and nightclub, cruise ships, water taxis, a high-speed passenger ferry service to Manhattan and La Guardia airport and, possibly, two office buildings with parking for an additional 3,000 cars and a helicopter pad.
The plans, submitted by the Conroy Development Company of Greenwich, won the city's approval over two other short-list competitors "because of its scope and magnitude," said Mayor Ganim.
"We brought together a variety of destination uses that would make Bridgeport a point of first interest along the coast from Boston to Washington," said Alexius C. Conroy, founder and president of the 13-year-old company. The rival companies on the short list were Hines Interests Limited Partnership of Stamford and Bridgeport Maritime Partners, a joint venture of Collins Enterprises of Greenwich and Dames, Moore & Brookhill, a Manhattan developer.
Partial financing for Harbour Place will come from a $448 million package approved this year by the state legislature for projects in Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport. Bridgeport will get $130 million of that package, plus a state grant of $20 million. "We wanted to start some entrepreneurship which would uplift depressed areas in cities that are trying to turn themselves around," said State Senator Alvin Penn, a Bridgeport Democrat who is chairman of the bonding committee.
Michael Freimuth, director of Bridgeport's Planning and Economic Development office, said the city would also issue $50 million in general obligation bonds. As the project moves forward property taxes of an estimated $10 million to $15 million a year will be committed to paying off the bonds. Marginal properties on the site now "bring in less than $1 million a year," said Mr. Freimuth.
The remaining $700 million is to be raised privately by the Conroy organization and its partner, Lend Lease of Atlanta, an international real estate and money-managing firm with a regional office in Manhattan. At present, said Mayor Gamin, "the work is moving along at an appropriate pace." And indeed, the few remaining stumbling blocks seem surmountable.
EIGHT appeals from landowners dissatisfied with the city's terms of property acquisition by eminent domain cannot by law halt the taking of property. One lawsuit, filed last July in Superior Court in Bridgeport by the century-old Pequonnock Yacht Club to gain a stay on a city order to move, is "in negotiation on a number of alternate sites," said Russell Liskov, assistant city attorney.
Securing an ocean liner will depend in part on the viability of dredging the harbor to accommodate such a vessel. Still open is the question of how many ferry services the state can support. A new task force on high-speed ferries is studying the matter.
Three ferry services are currently operating, one from Bridgeport to Port Jefferson, L.I., another from New London to Orient Point, L.I., and a summer service from Haddam to Greenport and Sag Harbor, L.I. But interest is high in Stamford, Norwalk and New London in running passenger ferries to Manhattan and the New York airports and to Glen Cove and possibly other points on Long Island. And Captain's Cove, a 19-year-old marina, entertainment and shopping complex west of Harbour Place, has been developing plans for a service with Seaconn, a ferry company in New Haven.
Captain's Cove could lose business to Harbour Place, but Kaye Williams, founder and owner of the popular 15-acre maritime complex, doesn't think so. "We're more of a no-nonsense, boat-building, free-and-easy people place," he said. Two of its main attractions are a reproduction of the 18th century British frigate H.M.S. Rose and the Lightship Nantucket, both open for tours.
On an infinitely grander scale, Harbour Place is also "heavily involved in nautical and historical theming," said J. Thomas Porter, senior principal at the architectural firm of Thompson, Ventulett, Stainback & Associates of Atlanta, designers of the project. "We are planning a large signature lighthouse on the point -- possibly as a restaurant and observation tower."
Along the water, he added, the village of individual shops, restaurants and the fishing pier would be built of wood, recalling the city's early history. The mall will be contemporary but with nautical references in lighting fixtures, decorative accents, directories resembling treasure maps and identification plaques resembling those on ships.
But Mr. Williams, like most people in Bridgeport, feels Harbour Place "will open up the city -- bring more people in," he said. Just as he benefited from the new baseball park at Harbor Yard, he hopes to profit from the Harbour Place overflow. Still, haunted by the city's decades-old identity crisis, he added: "Thank God Bridgeport's smokestacks are gone, but there's still a smokestack mentality out there."
Outsiders driving in on I-95 may admire the People's Bank building, but once past that all they see is power plants, rundown factories, dilapidated housing and mean streets. "The turnpike goes through the worst part of the city, giving people the wrong impression," said Charles Brilvitch, the city historian. "It's a common misconception that Bridgeport is not on its feet."
T HE city's decline from industrial powerhouse to rudderless city brought it close to bankruptcy in 1991. By 1995 it had a $4 million surplus but was still searching for an identity. Its development as a tourist attraction would be a third incarnation since the late 18th century.
"Harbour Place is to be built where a steel mill once stood, giving the peninsula the name of Steel Point," said Mr. Brilvitch. "Before the big industries came this was a major seaport. When the Hudson River froze the goods that came east on the Erie Canal came down through Bridgeport. Farmers brought their cornmeal and cider brandy here, traded it for factory goods and shipped it to New York and the West Indies. There was even a whaling fleet."
Black Rock Harbor on the west side was a shipbuilding port, and Bridgeport Harbor was a prime location for clamming, duck hunting, and oystering. Talmadge Brothers, one of Connecticut's largest oyster companies, is now one of the properties to be moved off the Harbour Place site.
Jose E. Rivera, Jr., his wife, Grace, and young sons, Jose 3d and Hector Luis, must also move. Their house at 23-29 Pierpont Street was condemned by the city. "The closing is on Nov. 22," said Mr. Rivera, "and we have no place to go yet." Surrounding him are other condemned houses and a scrap yard.
People like the Riveras, who are facing displacement, and Mr. Brilvitch who lives elsewhere in Bridgeport, are among the few city residents who are not pleased with what is happening at Steel Point.
"They could have restored the old oyster sheds, wharves, and houses," said Mr. Brilvitch, "but this city has a monumental aversion to historic preservation."
Next year's agenda for Harbour Place lists more land assembly and clearance, relocations, environmental remediation, design and engineering work, dredging, bulkhead construction, and street alignment.
And then, after a few years, Mr. Conroy believes Bridgeport will become a viable new venue for office construction because of "Stamford's constricted labor and real estate market."

HEADLINE: Habitats / Bedford Corners, N.Y.;
Bringing a House Back To the Way It Was

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
MOST people would have just fixed up the big old house and moved into its sun-filled rooms.
But Robert H. Saunders, a partner in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, was looking for a project. Although he had majored in economics at Yale, and now works in international corporate finance, he has always been fascinated by architecture. Maybe that's what a childhood in a ranch house will do. At any rate, he said, "I had been wanting a significant house by a significant architect." 
 So for several years, he and Linda Mahon regularly set out from their New York City apartment and roamed through New Jersey, the north shore of Long Island, and Westchester and Dutchess Counties, looking for a house to buy. They weren't insisting on a particular kind of style.
"They were all different," said Ms. Mahon, who works in mutual funds at Salomon Smith Barney. "We were just looking for something interesting and authentic that had not been ruined."
Finally, they found the house in Bedford Corners, less than an hour north of New York City in Westchester County, where the lawns are large and rolling and the houses have names.
They were not alone in their enthusiasm for the nine-bedroom, three-story house, called Stonecrest, built in 1879, with its charming stone patio in back and huge beech tree in front. In just three days, five people bid on the house on Croton Lake Road, which was on the market for $875,000. Finally, with an offer of $930,000, Mr. Saunders and Ms. Mahon bought it.
Now, a year after the closing, they are about to begin putting in a new kitchen, their first big construction project.
They have been proceeding carefully because they want to return the house to the architect's original vision, and they have spent a great deal of time in the last year searching for documents that would reveal the house's initial configuration and detailing.
ALTHOUGH they knew nothing of the architect when they bought the house, they have since discovered that it was designed by Eugene Clarence Gardner (1836-1915), who was considered a leading architect of the Stick style, distinguished by gabled roofs and elaborate decorative detailing. He was also well known for his so-called pattern books on architecture and design directed at the general public.
The house, which may be Mr. Gardner's only one in New York, was built in 1879 for Mary Wood, the daughter of the family that owned much of the land in the area, and her husband, Francis Underhill.
It was substantially renovated in 1916 to take out the ornate flourishes that were no longer in style, like the second-story balcony, the porch, the roof overhang and the fireplace mantels. "Anything that made the house seem decorative, they took off," said Mr. Saunders.
Places tend to reflect not only their eras but also their owners, and this one is no exception. Only two families have lived in the house, and the second one occupied it without significantly changing anything. They also seemed to have saved everything, and for the purposes of a restoration, a pack rat is a godsend. In piles of paper left in the house, Mr. Saunders found the architect's original description of how the house should be built.
Outside, he found a dump at the edge of the property where pieces of the original house had been tossed and never carted off, providing another source of information. From the pile he has pulled pieces of wood that once adorned porches, as well as a toilet seat he believes was used in the top-floor servants' quarters.
IN a workshop behind the house Mr. Saunders is piecing together his discoveries, using skills he first developed when he clerked for a judge who had a passion for woodworking. Holding a chewed-up piece of wood that was probably part of the front porch, he said, "This isn't in usable shape, but it gives you an idea of what to rebuild."
Another piece of wood "is an interesting detail," he said, but he has not been able to place its origin. Determining the color scheme of the original house has been easier. He hired a laboratory that analyzed the original paint scheme from some chips taken from the walls.
Mr. Saunders ultimately hopes to have the house placed on the National Register of Historic Places. To help in the restoration, he has visited Gardner houses in Massachusetts, where the architect had his firm, and has hired Eloise Marinos, an architect based in North Canton, Conn., who specializes in restoration.
Ms. Marinos said the chances of getting the house on the National Register were good because dozens of Gardner's buildings are already on the register.
In addition, she said, the Bedford Corners house is one of the few relatively intact examples in New York State of the Stick style, which was popular for only two decades and did not always hold up well because its delicate carved woodwork, when used outdoors, tended to deteriorate.
The house is also in an area where other houses built by the Wood family are on the register, as is some Wood family property that was landscaped by Frederick Law Olmsted.
Although Mr. Saunders doesn't know how much the restoration will cost, he estimates it will take five years. Inside, he and Ms. Mahon will recreate the general circulation plan and many of the decorative details that were lost, including the paneling of various woods in each room, and the mantels.
They will reconstruct the original stairwell, removed in 1916, using diagrams they have discovered in books written by Gardner that Mr. Saunders found by tracking down rare-book dealers on the Internet.
They won't be absolutist, however. "We won't restore the baths to the original state," Mr. Saunders said. "You just decide what the compromise is between modern comfort and historical accuracy."
Many details are still intact, like the hardware on the doors into the second-floor bedrooms. And on the third floor, a big old lead tank, once used to collect water from the roof, remains.
Many of Gardner's moldings have been stripped from the first floor, but they remain on the second, with their complex and fanciful designs.
Although Mr. Saunders began the project wanting simply to restore a house, he has become a Gardner fan. "I think he's a very interesting architect," he said. "He had an unusual and unique style. Not too many architects had his ability to develop a personal style."
The couple will restore the exterior as best they can, including returning the driveway to its original location in front of the house. Right now Mr. Saunders is trying to figure out what covered the original roof. He thinks it might have been slate. And of course, they will remove the aluminum gutters that were added. The gutters "are not the most appealing," Mr. Saunders said.
SOME original details do remain outside, including a block of cement outside the back door that was used as a step to make it easier to get up on a horse. They'll keep that, not only because it is historically correct, but also because Ms. Mahon plans someday to keep horses on the property.
And on an outside porch is flooring of painted burlap, something rarely seen because it was only done in the 19th century, and most of it has been lost to decay or modernization.
Because they are living in the house as they work on it, they have painted some rooms and decorated them in colors they find pleasing. When the restoration is finished, Ms. Mahon said, "we'll try to decorate in period."
On a sunny fall day, Mr. Saunders and Ms. Mahon, like any other couple enjoying their weekend in the country, have lunch on the back terrace, with music drifting out from the house.
Ms. Mahon cheerfully offers a snack to some neighborhood dogs while Mr. Saunders, wearing a cap with the name of the house emblazoned on it, carefully catalogues the details of the house he has uncovered during his yearlong study.
Its reconstruction, Ms. Mahon said, is like a big puzzle. "I'm learning," she said. "But he has the passion for it."

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
Quality Rentals for Aging Moderate-Income Tenants

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD

 BODY:
VISITORS at the 156-unit Riverhead Landing under construction here in a pastoral setting on Middle Road often do a double take. Even though the entrance sign clearly states that the 50-acre development is a "senior rental community" many feel there must be some mistake.
With its 4,000-square-foot clubhouse, outdoor pool, tennis court, putting green and two-story buildings with peaked roofs set amid lush landscaping, Riverhead Landing, whose architect is Greenberg Farrow Architects of Atlanta, has all the earmarks of a for-sale development. 
 "We have people driving in thinking this is a luxury condominium," said H. B. Gianos, president of East End Properties, which is building the project in a joint venture with the Whitney Capital Company. Both development groups are based in Manhattan.
Riverhead Landing is being built under the Federal Low-Income Housing Credit program, a linkage that often evokes resistance in local communities.
The housing initiative, which was authorized by the 1986 Tax Reform Act, reduces the cost of developing rental housing. Developers, in turn, must agree to charge their tenants below-market rents. Tenants can make no more than 60 percent of an area's median income, adjusted for family size, and they pay no more than 30 percent of that figure for rent minus a utility allowance.
At Riverhead Landing, where one member of the household must be at least 55,rents are $679 a month for a one-bedroom apartment, and $826 for a two-bedroom. Tenants pay their own heat and utilities. To qualify for an apartment, household income for 1998 cannot exceed $29,460 for one person or $33,720 for a couple.
The project is demonstrating, as are others being built under the Federal program, that subsidized housing can be not only affordable to people with moderate incomes, but also as attractive and as desirable as market-rate projects, said David Osiecki, a Ronkonkoma land broker who has negotiated deals for developers seeking to build this kind of housing.
Developers say that by building high-quality projects they will have low turnovers and will remain competitive over the long term so that they can make profits despite the below-market rents.
"One of our big selling points is that Riverhead Landing is fully amenitized and is similar to upscale projects," said Thomas G. Granville, the managing director of Whitney Capital.
The partnership has pledged to keep rent restrictions for 30 years, "so this doesn't only have to go through the initial lease-up," Mr. Granville added. "The pool, putting green and tennis court add to the quality of life and when people are looking for a place to go, that makes their decision to come here that much easier."
The clubhouse will include a business and conference center with copying and facsimile machines and computers. Apartments, which range in size from 720 to 871 square feet, will all have dining areas and a laundry room for optional washers and dryers as well as central air-conditioning. French doors lead to a private patio or terrace.
The two entrances to the development will have security gates and each of the eight buildings will also have a security system. The construction company is LSM Development Corporation of Riverhead.
Two buildings with a total of 32 apartments will be ready for occupancy in February, with the remainder to be completed over the following six months. Of the 156 apartments in the project, 49 have already found qualified tenants, and the remainder are being rented on a first-come, first-served basis.
Similar to Riverhead Landing is Eagleview, a 150-unit development under construction in Middle Island by a joint-venture partnership of Roizman Development of Norristown, Pa, and the Related Capital Company of Manhattan, an affiliate of Related Properties.
Eagleview, where occupancy began last weekend, has a pool, a clubhouse, a parklike setting on 42 acres and a secured entrance gate. It has the same income and age restrictions as Riverhead Landing.
Providing a good product makes good economic sense "if you want to maintain tenancy and get good tenants," said Alan P. Hirmes, senior managing director of Related Capital.
Rents at Eagleview range from $750 for a 720-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment to $950 for a 1,200-square-foot two-bedroom and den unit. About 100 of the 150 apartments are still available. The architect of the one-story buildings is GGK Architects of Philadelphia,
ANOTHER over-age-55 development being built under the Federal program is the 200-unit John Wesley Village II, which is also in Riverhead. Rents for the one- and two-bedroom units range from $640 to $750. Amenities include a clubhouse and a pool. About half the apartments are rented. The developer is Benjamin Development of Garden City.
Under the Low-Income Housing Credit Program, developers apply to the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for tax credits. Each state receives an annual allowance based on population. New York State's current share is $22.7 million.
Once a developer receives a tax-credit allocation it can sell the credits to an investor or syndicator, which pools them for sale to investors. The proceeds are used by the developer to provide a portion of the cash needed to begin the project. The balance of the development cost is either privately financed by a bank, or through long-term tax-exempt or taxable bonds, which offer below- market interest rates.
Investors become limited partners in the project. Primarily they are large corporations, which purchase tax credits to offset their Federal income tax liability over a 10-year period. Among other inducements is that the dollar-for-dollar credit corporations receive against income taxes is enhanced because credits are purchased at an individually-negotiated discount, The current rate is 65 to 70 cents on the dollar.
In New York State, developers must agree to comply with rent restrictions for at least 15 years, at which point controls are dropped. But many of the projects, Riverhead Landing and Eagleview included, have pledged to comply with rent restrictions for 30 years.
At Riverhead Landing, where development costs will be $16 million, the developers sold $9.5 million worth of tax credits to Related Capital, which is the financial services arm of Related Companies (and also the joint venture partner of the Eagleview development).
Long-term financing is being provided by 30-year taxable bonds insured by the State of New York Mortgage Agency. Key Bank is providing the construction loan.
Eagleview was allocated $11 million in tax credits, which were sold to Related Capital for syndication. The balance of the $18 million project is being financed through a combination of taxable and tax-exempt bonds.
John Wesley Village II, the Benjamin Development project, received a $10 million tax credit allocation and $14 million in financing from an industrial revenue bond purchased by North Fork Bank.
The long, laborious and highly competitive process of winning tax credits and meeting all the requirements of the Federal program is very worthwhile for developers who have attained the expertise and tend to develop many of these projects nationwide, said Mr. Gianos of East End Properties.
"You'll never make the same profit margin as the guy who hits a home run on a condo, but at the same time you'll never go broke if the market turns against you," he noted. "These are more conservative types of developments and much safer bets because there will always be an excess demand for affordable rentals. And at the end of the day, there is a tremendous social upside as well."
Long Island with its high median income (it is currently $70,200 for a family of four) offers great attractions for the tax-credit program, said Mr. Granville of Whitney Capital. Projects for older people are particularly needed because the population is aging, he said. But developers say they are often thwarted because of community resistance against any type of subsidized housing, and especially rental housing.
HOWEVER, would-be residents are often astounded and delighted at the housing they are being offered -- and they are often suspicious that what they are seeing is too good to be true.
At Eagleview, one prospective tenant came in with a lawyer demanding to know what the catch was because "they couldn't believe what they were getting for the price," said Israel Roizman, the president of Roizman development.
"Not everyone is wealthy on Long Island, but you don't treat people as lesser citizens because they don't have a lot of money," Mr. Roizman went on to say. "People applying for our apartments are on fixed incomes, but they don't want to move to Florida away from their families. Why not give them the opportunity to stay here and still have a decent place to live?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Completed rental residence at Riverhead Landing, above. Thomas R. Granville, managing director of Whitney Capital, joint developer, right.
(Photographs by Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: VIEWS;
Now Playing: A Grand Movie House Restored

 BODY:
The marquee of the Loew's Jersey has been beckoning passers-by for 70 years. But the lure is no longer first-run Hollywood films seen in luxury; now it calls out for volunteers to scrape off decades of paint, dirt and petrified chewing gum to restore the movie palace.
The theater has been a dominant presence on Journal Square since it opened in 1929, but television and changing life styles contributed to its decline. After several years partitioned into three theaters, it closed in 1986 and was sold to a developer. 
 Preservationists battled to save the theater from the wrecker's ball and in 1993 the city acquired it. It leased the theater to the Jersey City Economic Development Corporation, and the Friends of Loew's volunteer group set out to do the restoration.
A $2 million grant financed the major renovations, but volunteers do most of the work. Now every Saturday, teams of volunteers come into the dusty halls to work. Some are skilled workers, but the most important commodities are concern and sweat. About 100 people come in at least monthly, helping a core group of about two dozen who work there every weekend. They are helped by volunteers from businesses and community groups and students in the film program at New Jersey City University, like Stefan Pietraszek, above, working on seat standards in the main auditorium. He earns academic credit for the work. Closer to the stage, the wooden armrests, right, were being restained and varnished. This volunteer work saved $150,000 out of a grant of $500,000 for the seat repairs, which will be invested in other areas of the theater.
The projection room has been restored, and the elevators for the orchestra and piano have been repaired. Robert Eberenz, a retired sound engineer from Oradell, is the chief engineer. He was able to restore the original light board, projection room and elevator lifts for the orchestra pit, piano and organ. "We had an estimate of $200,000 to repair the lifts, and he was able to get it working with some WD-40," said Colin Egan, chairman of the Friends of Loew's. On a recent Saturday, Mr. Egan, left, hung from scaffolding as he recaulked the marquee, which dates from 1949.
In the auditorium, which once sat more than 3,000, Peter Collen, above right, cleaned some of the original carpeting, which, beyond reuse, will be cut up into squares and sold as souvenirs to raise money.
The theater is expected to be ready for limited use in the spring. The restoration should be complete, including repairing the clock with its figures of St. George killing the dragon, top right, the next year.

HEADLINE: ELECTION '98;
For the Republicans, Mitch Berkey

 BODY:

6/3/98 -- The day after our primary victory. We receive numerous phone calls from friends, relatives and neighbors offering congratulations, good wishes and help in the campaign. For me and my running mates, Mark Fusari and Armond Forcella, the real work has just begun.
6/5/98 -- Exxon has submitted a revised plan to the Zoning Board in connection with its application for a highway-sized service center near Harrison School. This is a curveball. As chairman of Citizens Organized to Promote Safety (COPS), I am one of the leaders of the residents opposing this proposal. The vote is expected on the 9th, based on the old plan. So many are counting on us. I call our land planner and attorney to strategize for the final meeting. 

6/6/98 -- A welcome break for family fun at the annual Kiwanis Karnival sponsored by the Livingston Kiwanis Club. Although tough to get around on crutches with my broken ankle, Mara, Jessy, Jared and I have a great time.
6/9/98 -- The final Zoning Board hearing on the Exxon application. Town Hall is filled. Months of work on the line. Our land planner testifies and we sum up. Exxon rebuts and it goes to the board. The application is denied by unanimous vote! David beats Goliath. Thank you, Zoning Board!
6/11/98 -- Our informal campaign kickoff at Monmouth Court. Mark, Armond and I slip on our new campaign T-shirts and make our first public remarks as candidates. One supporter suggests a campaign slogan to go with my crutches: I can't walk, but I sure can run!
6/18/98 -- Our gala cocktail fund-raiser at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston. Our committee does a great job as the place is packed. We exceed attendance projections by 50 percent.
6/25/98 -- We receive our shipment of new Livingston Town Council trading cards. A political first in Livingston, there are three individual cards plus a group shot. We plan to distribute the collection throughout the summer to children of all ages.
6/29/98 -- Jessy left for sleep-away camp yesterday. Today, we closed on both the sale of our home of 11 years and the purchase of our new home. We are staying put for six weeks as major renovations are to begin at the new house starting tomorrow. Mara is in charge and has the contractors ready to go.
6/30/98 -- As chairman of COPS, I write to the Town Council demanding that it act to prevent overbuilding similar to the Exxon proposal. I provide an analysis of the zoning law and describe the problem areas that could lead to another battle where residents have to defend the integrity of their neighborhoods. I show which zoning law provisions require modification. It's a real concern, but as a candidate for Town Council, I am curious as to how they will react.
7/5/98 -- I'm finally off crutches. At our town's Fourth of July event, we receive a great response to the introduction of our new trading cards. Kids want them and parents get a huge kick out of them. A fun, low-key way to meet and communicate with our fellow residents.
7/13/98 -- Town Hall is packed with hundreds of owners of commercial vehicles concerned about proposed restrictions regarding trucks in driveways. A very emotional issue. The law passes to mixed reviews.
7/22/98 -- We continue visiting the town pools and handing out our trading cards. They have received no attention in our town newspaper. We decide to pay for ads to promote the cards.
8/2/98 -- Another weekend afternoon outside Shoprite. People are friendly and supportive. Our contractors need at least an extra week at the new house. Camp will be over in three weeks. We're still packing. Our buyers need to know when we are moving. What will happen next?
8/10/98 -- The Town Council reacts to a June 30 letter from COPS by introducing a new law that would prohibit convenience stores at gas stations. They follow our suggestions and modify the exact zoning law provisions pointed out in our letter, but make no mention of COPS or our analysis. Still, the result is gratifying.
8/14/98 -- Moving day, at last. Most of the work on the new house is completed, but there are over 100 boxes to unpack. Camp is over in a week and Mara returns to her classroom in two weeks. The kids are each starting new schools. Things are getting hectic.
8/15/98 -- Our 17th anniversary. Mara and I celebrate by unpacking.
8/22/98 -- Mark, Armond and I conduct a voter registration drive outside of Kings Super Market. Lots of new voters and positive feedback.
8/28/98 -- Our one vacation day! Mara and I take the kids for our annual canoe trip on the Delaware. This year we travel with two other families and it works out great. No campaigning or boxes to unpack on the river.
9/3/98 -- The Town Council announces an "agreement" to negotiate the purchase of a site for a possible senior center, a hot campaign issue. The announcement is a bit confusing and the "agreement" nonbinding. Still, it indicates progress. A sign the election is getting closer.
9/6/98 -- A family day at Memorial Pool. It's been an uphill struggle. Except for one weekly photo and caption in the town paper, we receive no local coverage. Meanwhile, each announcement by our incumbent opponents on the Council is reported in detail. Our views will be reported only when all candidates' positions are printed in October. This is a major disadvantage. But we continue our door-to-door campaigning and reaching out directly to our neighbors. The response, from both Republicans and Democrats, is very encouraging.
9/12/98 --Mark, Armond and I work the crowd over hot dogs and pony rides at the Y.M.C.A. open house.
9/16/98 -- Tony Calcado, our campaign manager, presents our schedule and strategy for our campaign mailing. Less than seven weeks to go.
9/17/98 -- Attend County Executive Jim Treffinger's campaign kickoff in Verona. It is a packed house as we see the difference between the crowd for a county executive race and our municipal election.
9/23/98 -- The Newark Star-Ledger prints a nice article about our series of candidate trading cards, saying they are the first of their kind in the state.
9/27/98 -- After visiting the St. Raphael Church picnic, we have a wonderful backyard gathering at the home of Anne and Tony Crincoli. We are energized by the appearance of Congressman Frelinghuysen and many supporters.
9/30/98 -- Yom Kippur. The Jewish Day of Atonement. All campaigning stops for the High Holy Days. In temple all day, I reflect on family, life and the campaign. A friend needles me by asking whether politicians could use an extra day to atone.
That night I open a letter which claims that one of our campaign signs may have been erected on Rosh ha-Shanah the previous week. In a response, we mention that a non-Jewish contractor erected the sign and ask to convene our local Interfaith Council to discuss what extent the non-Jewish world should limit its business activities during the Jewish High Holy Days. The issue is never raised again.
10/4/98 -- Nine-year-old Howard Tilkin faxes an application to be assistant campaign manager. Perhaps the nicest moment of the campaign so far. I tell him he has the job and that his first assignment is to make a campaign poster with crayons and markers. He is very enthusiastic.
10/8/98 -- At a private gathering, we hear from businesspeople firsthand about the lack of economic development, the sewer moratorium and other issues of concern.
10/14/98 -- We visit Bunnie Ratner's house to attend a meet-the-candidates night for officers and directors of the Livingston Youth and Community Services and the Livingston Municipal Alliance Committee. These wonderful groups are responsible for successful anti-drug and other youth-oriented programs in Livingston.
10/18/98 -- We are told by friendly Democrats that our opponents plan to load the audience with personally embarrassing questions at the televised League of Women Voters Candidate Forum this Wednesday. We decide not to go this route and stick to the issues. We are warned to be ready.
10/21/98 -- A full house at the League of Women Voters Candidate Forum. We do extremely well and force our opponents to defend their record. As warned, bombs were dropped during the question period. Armond, Mark and I weather the storm and finish strong. In my closing I joke that, hearing so much legal talk, maybe Shakespeare was right about killing all the lawyers. One opposing party leader sitting only a few seats from Mara says I should be first. All in all, an exciting evening.
10/25/98 -- The day starts at 7 A.M. at the bagel store. Who wants to see a political candidate on a morning bagel run? I wouldn't. . . . Even so, the feedback is great. It's been like that throughout the campaign. Later it's Shoprite, more doorbells and soccer. With all this going on, I've never missed one of Jessy's or Jared's games all season. Keeping it all in perspective is critical.
10/29/98 -- The local newspaper's pre-election editorial comes out. There is no hiding how the writer feels about us and our campaign. Such is life when you are the outsiders fighting the status quo. We are proud of our effort.
10/31/98 -- With only three days to go, soccer playoffs take precedence over campaigning. Jared gets eliminated, but Jessy plays again tomorrow. My friends joke about my blazer and slacks attire at the soccer field as I jump back and forth from soccer dad to candidate throughout the day. I see Howard Tilkin, who says his campaign poster is ready. I invite him to our election night party where he can display it. He is beaming.
11/1/98 -- Back to the bagel shop at 7 A.M. Our opponents arrive at 8:30 for our first head-to-head campaigning. It's fairly friendly as Bill Williams and I joke about getting our lives back soon. Jared and Bill's daughter were classmates. We both coach Little League. Our wives sat next to each other at the League of Women Voters Forum. Just two regular dads on the opposite sides of an election campaign. I return to the soccer fields by 9 A.M. Jessy's team wins two playoff games by shootout to take the championship. In 48 hours, we'll see if I follow in her footsteps.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
After 120 Years, the Last Apple Falls, and a Family Business With It

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
As always in November, the last of the apples have been picked and crated and the rows of trees visible from Milltown Road in East Brunswick are losing their leaves. But this fall is different from those of the last 120 years, when L. J. Smith Farms sold apples and cider and got ready for another growing season in the spring.
Soon, this land will be spotted with new houses instead of old apple trees The Matzel and Mumford Organization of Hazlet Township is buying the 49 acres of land and will build 83 single-family homes here. 
 Chet and Margaret Tkach are retiring from the apple business started here in 1879 by her grandfather, George Smith, and they will move to a home on the water in Toms River. Mrs. Tkach recently talked about closing the family business and shutting down the cider stand that had become a traditional destination on fall pilgrimages.
Q. How did the family get into apples?
A. The land was purchased by my grandfather, who cleared it and grew fruits and vegetables. He took first prize for strawberries at the Chicago World's Fair.
I remember apples all my life. When my father, Lawrence, took over in the mid-1930's, this area of Middlesex County was really farm country. There were trolleys that ran between New Brunswick and South River. I remember my father shipping apples to the troops in World War II.
Q. Was the business always apples?
A. The family owned 650 acres in South Brunswick where we had corn, potatoes and peaches, and another 100 acres in East Brunswick. Our family paid for paving Harts Lane because we were the only land owners back here then. But the family started with the basics, apples, and now we are back to the basics. My father was the Apple King of New Jersey.
We had our own retail store. We had other jobs for a while. I was a legal secretary and my husband was a computer programmer, but we were always working at the orchard on weekends.
Q. How much business did the store do?
A. We sold the best apples there. The seconds went to manufacturers for applesauce. We sold apple cider for years. We would sell 200 gallons a day. The day before Thanksgiving was always the biggest day when we would sell 800 or 1,000 gallons. We probably sold 12,000 gallons a year.
 Q. What has changed?
A. The new generation does not cook as much. They don't make applesauce and pies. The only farms that can make it now are what I call entertainment farms -- the ones that have hay rides and pony rides and pick-your-own crops.
There are also too many regulations now. It is just too expensive to operate the business. We used to show kids around the orchard but then we were afraid someone would be hurt. Neighbors complained of spraying. People want perfect fruit, and you cannot do that without a good spray program. Roadside stands are not as popular because the supermarket offers everything people want under one roof.
 Q. Why sell for a housing development?
A. The town did not want to use all their open-space money to preserve just one place. In order to sell the development rights and keep it in farming, our daughter would have had to take over the operation. We all felt it just wans't economically feasible. There was a plan to put a warehouse here that would have had buffer zones, so you wouldn't have even seen it, but some of the neighbors objected, so we sold to a housing developer. This is no longer a farm area. It is a commuter area. People just have to realize things change. KAREN DeMASTERS

GRAPHIC: Photo: Margaret and Chet Tkach on their 49-acre apple farm in East Brunswick, soon to be the site of 83 houses. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

INDUSTRY: SIC1522 GENERAL CONTRACTORS - RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS OTHER THAN SINGLE-FAMILY (72%);

HEADLINE: Will Harmony Follow Campaign Discord?

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
WHILE they are not quite ready to stage a love-in, Democrats and Republicans say they are expecting to work for common goals in the next General Assembly session after elections last Tuesday in which candidates in both parties ran on similar issues: tax cuts, improving public education and increased liabiliy for health maintenance organizations.
While admitting disappointment that the Democrats retained their majorities in both houses of the legislature, the Republican State Chairman, Christopher DePino, predicted good working relations. "Democrats and Republicans mostly sang from the same page of the hymnbook in this cycle. It was hard to tell a Democratic handout from a Republican handout," said Mr. DePino, who was re-elected as a State Representative from New Haven. 
 But other lawmakers warned that if the economy takes a downturn, the cooperation between the parties, as well as between legislative Democrats and Gov. John G. Rowland could be endangered.
Howard L. Reiter, a University of Connecticut political science professor, said that with Mr. Rowland's overwhelming re-election victory, "there's no incentive to kick him while he's up. If the economy starts going down, which is a clear possibility, then we'll see a different dynamic."
Mr. Rowland, a Republican, defeated his Democratic challenger, Barbara B. Kennelly, of Hartford, by a wide margin, 63 percent to 35 percent. But his coattails were lacking. With the exception of a tight contest for State Treasurer, all the Democratic candidates for non-gubernatorial statewide offices, called the underticket, easily won election over Republican candidates.
Unofficial returns showed Denise Nappier, the Democratic candidate for Treasurer, almost 2,000 votes ahead of the Republican candidate, Paul J. Sylvester, pending a possible recount. Mr. Sylvester was appointed to the post after the incumbent Republican, Christopher B. Burnham, resigned. In the race for Secretary of the State, an open seat, State Representative Susan Bysiewicz, a Middletown Democrat, defeated Ben Andrews, a Republican and former president of the state N.A.A.C.P. The Democrat ran aggressive television commercials criticizing Mr. Andrews for personal financial problems.
Two Democratic incumbents, Richard Blumenthal, the State Attorney General, and Nancy S. Wyman, the State Comptroller, were re-elected.
In the state's six Congressional races, all five incumbents were returned to Washington. In the open First District seat vacated by Mrs. Kennelly, a Democrat, John B. Larson, defeated a political newcomer, Kevin J. O'Connor, who had received $60,000 from the national Republican party for his effort in the Democratic bastion.
Representative James H. Maloney, Democrat of Danbury, won a narrow victory for a second term over Mark Nielsen, a Republican State Senator, who had aggressively sought to ride Mr. Rowland's coattails.
The other Congressional winners were two Democrats, Sam Gejdenson in the Second and Rosa L. DeLauro in the Third District, and two Republicans, Christopher Shays in the Fourth District and Nancy L. Johnson in the Sixth District.
United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, won a lopsided victory, 65 percent to 32 percent, over his Republican challenger, Gary A. Franks. Mr. DePino expressed belief that because Mr. Franks was "absolutely trounced in the second spot" on the ballot, it contributed to the Republican losses elsewhere.
While Democrats will control both the State Senate and State House when the new General Assembly convenes in January, there will be some changes.
State Representative Moira K. Lyons, a Stamford Democrat, is slated to become the first female Speaker of the House. Ms. Lyons, who has been majority leader for four years, was re-elected to a ninth term, with no Republican opponent. She would succeed Thomas Ritter, a Hartford Democrat, who did not seek re-election.
Ms. Lyons predicted that because she is breaking a barrier, people will watch her more closely, "perhaps expecting a little more." She said one of her major concerns is economic independence for women, which can be attained with government-assisted child care, scholarships and job training.
Republicans had been concentrating their legislative campaign efforts on the State Senate where Democrats held a tight 19-17 majority going into Tuesday's elections. But the G.O.P. did not gain any seats, and may have lost one in the 22d district which includes Trumbull and parts of Bridgeport and Monroe. Pending a recount, William Finch, a Democratic alderman from Bridgeport, had an unofficial 85-vote lead over the incumbent Republican, Angelina Lee Scarpetti.
In the House, Republicans, who admitted they had a slim chance of winning a majority, ended up not gaining any seats. The 96-55 Democratic majority will remain.
The Senate President pro tem, Kevin B. Sullivan, a West Hartford Democrat, said that Democrats would seek property tax relief and health care changes so that patients and doctors have more say over health care, and that health maintenance organizations have liability for malpractice, which means people would be able to sue them.
Like other Democrats, Mr. Sullivan accused Mr. Rowland of adopting Democratic positions for political expediency, including emphasizing education, environment and aid to cities. "We would hope the Governor would continue to embrace our issues as he has in the last year and a half," Mr. Sullivan said.
The Republican leaders of the House, Robert M. Ward of Branford, and of the Senate, M. Adela Eads of Kent, said their party's priorities include tax cuts, rewriting the education funding formula to provide more money for suburbs, continuing to finance a program to acquire more land for open space, and making H.M.O.'s more accountable.
On the economy, Ms. Lyons, the Democratic leader, said that the legislature needs to do more than maintain its current rainy day fund of $500 million. She said that action should be taken to reduce debt "to assure that in an economic downturn, we're in good shape."
The Democratic State Chairman, Edward Marcus, contended that Mr. Rowland was not prepared in case of an economic slide. "I know he hasn't set out any agenda or initiative to improve the economy," Mr. Marcus said.
But, Mr. DePino, the Republican Chairman, predicted that the state would continue to do well economically because there is a greater diversity of businesses than a decade ago. "I think Connecticut is much better prepared right now for an economic downturn than it was 10 years ago," he said.
Republicans, who began the elimination of the party lever from Connecticut voting machines when they were in the legislative majority in 1985, said they believed that the party lever would have helped them this year with Mr. Rowland faring so well. But removal of the lever, they said, is better for the election process, forcing voters to make clear choices.
Mr. Reiter, the politicial scientist, said, "Republicans shot themselves in the foot when in 1985 they eliminated the party lever." He said it came back "to haunt them this year."
Mr. Sullivan, though, contended that the Governor's campaign was strictly about himself. "I don't think John Rowland's message had coattails," he said.
Elsewhere, a much-publicized ballot question in Bridgeport -- to increase the term of the mayor from two to four years -- was approved. It had been defeated in prior elections. This time, supporters took the unusual step of buying television commercials promoting adoption of the question.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Working Out With a One-Armed Bandit

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
AMID the hundreds of exhibits at the recent World Gaming Congress and Exposition, no new products better summed up gambling's place in the American psyche than the "Pedal 'N Play" cycle and the "Money Mill" treadmill.
What better way to get the heart pounding and the palms perspiring than to wager money while exercising? The stationary cycle and the treadmill both have slot machines attached, allowing casino customers to sweat and bet at the same time, or as they say in gambling parlance, to "stay in action," even while they're working out. 
 "People are going crazy about this," said Kathy Harris, president of the Fitness Gaming Corporation of Fairfax, Va., the company that created this latest way of efficiently separating gamblers from their money. Ms. Harris pointed out that the machines were wired so "you can't gamble unless you're peddling and you can't peddle unless you're gambling." The company's motto: "Put your heart into gaming."
To visit the gambling industry's September extravaganza, which drew more than 23,000 casino operators, entrepreneurs and government officials from over 100 countries, is to totally forget that legalized gambling itself is undergoing a re-examination by politicians and law-enforcement officials around the country.
The enthusiasm that caused the industry to mushroom throughout the 1980's and early 1990's is slowly giving way to trepidation, as local governments learn that casinos are no panacea for their economic infirmities.
Meanwhile, a Presidential commission is expected to release a report next year on gambling's impact on the nation. And casino operators themselves have even banded together to finance studies about compulsive gambling. The effort of the casino operators has as much to do with controlling the damage that full awareness of compulsive gambling could have on their industry's reputation as with any desire to expose the problem.
Still, studies continue to show that a majority of people support some form of legal betting. A recent survey by American Viewpoint, an opinion research company, and Gtech, the powerful lottery company, found that 7 out of 10 Americans believe that legalized gambling is an "acceptable form of entertainment."
And with one or more types of betting now legal in nearly every state, it is little wonder that the frontiers of wagering were on full display at the gambling exposition.
The cavernous Las Vegas Convention Center was filled with slot machines and table games, wildly colored casino floor carpeting and furniture, the latest technology in automated teller machines and coin counters and the gigantic fake trees, rocks and animatronics that have transformed the nation's gambling halls into alluring wonderlands.
Plenty of new games were displayed, and their enterprising creators used prize giveaways, free beer and seductive models to corner and cajole wide-eyed casino operators and government regulators into giving these new games a home in a casino. At the Digital 21 exhibit, which featured a new game of virtual Blackjack, a model attracted plenty of interest, although many of the players who crowded around her table were clearly having a difficult time paying attention to the cards.
One casino advertising and marketing company even beckoned delegates by packing its small booth with young women in tight clothing and posting a sign offering a drawing for "a free exotic dancer in the privacy of your room."
Among the celebrities at the convention was the pop star Michael Jackson, who has recently expressed an interest in investing in a Detroit casino. Priscilla Presley, his former mother-in-law, showed up to help promote a new Elvis slot machine, which allows gamblers to wager while they watch a video of The King himself in concert.
Within a few days after the convention ended, the Flamingo Hilton in Kansas City, Mo., became the first customer to order the Pedal N' Play and the Money Mill, according to Ms. Harris. Other potential customers are making plans to include the machines inside their casino hotel spas or create exercise areas on the casino floor itself.
And in Las Vegas, where slot machines can already be found at just about every two-bit bar and convenience store, Ms. Harris hopes to do what any health-conscious American entrepreneur would do: convince local health club owners to get gaming licenses and put her company's machines next to the weights, stair-climbers and aerobic exercise floors.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 872 words

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Bent Out of Shape by Flexibility

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
CONSIDER the option offered to many working parents in the brave new "flexible" workplace: the right to earn a part-time salary for the privilege of leaving promptly at the end of a full day.
If that sounds like a bad bargain, there are deeper compromises to contemplate in today's corporate world of flex time, teams and short-term projects, according to Richard Sennett. 
 Mr. Sennett's provocative, and often persuasive, new book, "The Corrosion of Character: The Personal Consequences of Work in the New Capitalism" (W. W. Norton, $23.95), argues that for employees, the re-engineered, routine-bashing workplace is just as bad as the rigid bureaucracy it is replacing. Maybe worse.
All this flexibility, says the writer, a sociologist at New York University, may help feed the frantic product reinvention and short-term gains that our economy now demands. But it is not about personal power or freedom, as advertised. It's just another form of capitalist control: a confusing regime that erodes employees' sense of work, place and self.
To be nimble enough to succeed, he argues, employees are bending themselves too far. Human character cannot develop in a culture that worships risk, uncertainty and a plug-in work force, he says. Character is formed from long-term mutual commitments -- from sustained work, from a sense of purpose and, yes, even from steady routine.
Mr. Sennett, who with Jonathan Cobb wrote "The Hidden Injuries of Class" in 1972, has been watching workers for a while. And he stresses that he is not calling for a return to the days of Draconian work rules and the endless repetition of the same few, simple tasks.
Instead, he wants Americans to retrieve some of the values that stood alongside (or stood up to) the old, rigid way of management.
THIS, of course, is a tricky business, and "The Corrosion of Character" doesn't always pull it off. There's a whiff of nostalgia here, despite the author's protestations.
But Mr. Sennett's argument, which weaves the work of Denis Diderot, Joseph Schumpeter and Daniel Bell into everyday life, is illuminating.
 The book begins with the author's accidental airport encounter with a man he calls Rico, the son of a janitor he interviewed years ago for "The Hidden Injuries of Class."
Rico is a successful management consultant -- safe, it seems, from the kind of dull job his father held and from a life measured in small home improvements and savings.
But independent consulting is unsatisfying, confesses Rico, who was downsized out of an engineering position. He is tired of drumming up clients whose demands have little to do with his M.B.A. training and is unsettled by his four relocations.
His last move, he says, was for his wife's job, but now she, too, is disappointed. She is a manager, but feels she has little control; some of her staff work at the office, some at home and some a thousand miles away, where they are reachable only by computer. Because of her company's rules on how and when to send E-mail to her staff, her flexible workplace affords no flexibility for her.
Rico also worries that his children have no "ethical discipline." They take his success for granted, he says, and seem to be headed into Mall Rat mode. The couple's career paths are too fragmented, he adds, to provide life lessons about sustained endeavors, patience or loyalty.
"The Corrosion of Character" introduces us to other new-economy workers as well. The author returns to a Boston bakery he visited for his earlier book and finds its current employees -- in sharp contrast to their predecessors -- to be indifferent to their work. Their baking, which is now computer-supervised, is determined by the temporary daily needs of their local market niche: they make mounds of bagels one day, stacks of French bread the next. Mr. Sennett, who seems to be simply cranky about the changes at a once-familiar shop, doesn't make much of a case here.
The story of Rose, a smart manager-bartender at the author's favorite New York watering hole, proves more compelling. She follows the siren song of risk-taking and accepts a job at an ad agency. But she feels invisible working on a team that is always collectively blameless and that values soft communication skills over concrete ideas.
EMPLOYEES in the new economy are being cheated, Mr. Sennett concludes.
They lack a usable work ethic, because there is little long-term planning in a work culture that thrives on uncertainty and denies time's "trajectory" into the future. They lack social bonds based on mutual trust, because they're encouraged to hop from project to project. And they lack a respect for sustained routine.
"Today we stand on a historical divide on the issue of routine," the author says, after a bracing dip into the differing 18th-century views of Diderot (it's dignified and necessary) and Adam Smith (it's numbing). In our own century, the author notes, routine, or rather escape from it, has been an "arena of empowerment" for American labor as it fought for fundamental changes in the way work is done.
Are we sure, Mr. Sennett asks, that routine is inherently demeaning? That long-term commitments are stagnating? That flexibility is the same thing as freedom?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Energy Plan Gets a Lift In California

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
DEREGULATION of the electricity industry dodged a bullet when California voters thumpingly defeated Proposition 9 last Tuesday, 73 percent to 27 percent, to the industry's great relief. The complex model of competition introduced in California last year is now free to proceed there and in other states.
"The concept has been sanctified," said Dan Scotto, an analyst for Carnegie, Childs & Company. "For two years, many states sat on the fence. They are now going to feel a lot more comfortable going ahead." 
 Combined with the defeat of a similar measure in Massachusetts, the vote was a major setback to consumer groups' efforts to secure bigger rate cuts for consumers while forcing utilities and their shareholders to absorb more of the costs of utility plants that are no longer economically viable after deregulation.
Utilities in California will be reimbursed for most of their $28 billion in these costs, known as stranded costs, under a compromise negotiated two years ago. Consumer surcharges for the reimbursement spurred much of the support for Proposition 9.
The battle drew attention to a process that had been dominated by utilities, politicians and regulators. The large industrial power consumers, who have demanded lower rates, have been the main force pushing deregulation. Residential and smaller commercial customers have had little voice in the process, and few have chosen to buy power from the new unregulated suppliers.
Though the utilities won at the polls, some economists are beginning to question whether reimbursing utilities for stranded costs makes sense. Consumer advocates said that they were building support in spite of the measure's defeat and that they would keep pushing for a more favorable deal for small ratepayers.
"We had two million Californians voting for this," said Harry M. Snyder of Consumers Union, a leader in the effort. "We'll just keep coming at them."
