SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2100 words

HEADLINE: Facing Oblivion, Rust-Belt Giants Top Russian List Of Vexing Crises

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MAGNITOGORSK, Russia

 BODY:
Ten years ago, when economic reform began its uneven march through Russia's industrial heartland, the most visible landmark in this steel town was a deadly multicolored plume that hung over the vast Magnitogorsk Metal Works.
Now, on a misty autumn morning, the sky is still, a welcome breath of fresh air for the scarred lungs of the 430,000 people who live here on the banks of the Ural River. 
 One reason is the changes that have swept Russia under the banner of free-market reform. Directors of the mill, now privatized, have done what Moscow's all-powerful central planners refused to let them do: They have spent their own profits to replace 11 of the mill's 35 aged and filthy open-hearth furnaces that heat iron into steel with two cleaner oxygen furnaces.
But there is another reason for the clear skies, one that illustrates why so many Russians have come to associate economic reform with economic collapse.
Today Magnitogorsk -- once the largest mill in the former Soviet Union -- is producing less than half the raw steel it did a decade ago, with about the same work force. It is a story repeated across Russia, whose gross national product has slumped 42.5 percent since 1989, the most abrupt decline in any major industrial country since the Great Depression.
And new clouds loom on the horizon. The Magnitogorsk Metal Works is bracing for a blow that could shut off its sales to the United States, where it now sells 49 percent of its exports.
American steel producers, who say they are being undercut by imports from Russia, Japan and Brazil, have brought a trade case accusing the foreign competitors of "dumping" -- or unfairly selling steel in the United States for less than it costs them to produce it. A preliminary ruling is expected in a few weeks.
As winter approaches, workers here are collecting only half their wages in cash, with the rest provided as credit at stores owned by the mill. And there are fears that this crisis, more than others before it, will hit home -- hard.
"If we lose our exports," said Anatoly Tamchuck, deputy chairman of the local Mining and Metallurgical Union, "the drop in production will be about 50 percent, and layoffs could be about the same. This is the most frightening thing. Since Soviet times, we never have had mass unemployment. This is a new situation. The steel mill is the main enterprise in the city. There is no other work."
Of all Russia's problems, the most vexing lie in its Rust Belt, an interlocking series of industrial giants now living off barter and choking on bloated work forces. Many of the industries are pillars of communities that have no other reason for being.
 
Devalued Cash, Vanishing Assets
Solving these problems without causing social upheaval will be a key test for Russia's new Government, headed by Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and staffed with old-style Soviet ministers who have pointedly set out to rescue Russian industry -- or, as they put it, the "real" economy.
By the end of the Communist era, Russia's heavy industry was already heading for a slump. But many fault President Boris N. Yeltsin's team of free-market reformers for failing to anticipate the economic disarray -- and corruption -- that followed their lifting of state controls.
In the last seven years, the bottom has fallen out of Magnitogorsk's domestic market. Steel consumption in Russia, once one of the highest in the world at 970 pounds per capita, has dropped to under 265. Russian factories that buy steel -- makers of tractors, tanks, railroad ties, ships and industrial machinery -- have verged on bankruptcy, struggling to sell what Russians either do not want or cannot afford.
Many analysts say that the real problems in Russia's once-formidable metals industry run deep in a Soviet-era mentality that continues to regard steel production in terms of targets rather than markets, that views outsiders with suspicion and that shares information reluctantly.
"Russian steel mills on the whole haven't managed to make the final leap," observed James May, the Russia specialist at the London-based Metal Bulletin, a trade newspaper. "They haven't grasped the fact that just producing for the Motherland is not enough. They have to look at their markets, at their costs. Mainly, there is a failure to grasp the bull by the horns, and come to terms with the fact that they are going to have to sack a lot of people."
Just a few months ago, Magnitogorsk was banking on the first hints of an industrial upturn. Then came the devaluation of the ruble in August and a simultaneous freeze on Russia's foreign and domestic borrowing. In one day, Magnitogorsk's bank accounts were blocked, foreign banks refused to finance steel exports and raw materials dwindled to dangerously low levels.
After the August crisis opened a sudden $50 million hole in the factory's cash flow, it took the next obvious step, one used across Russia to forestall layoffs. It delayed paying wages to its 55,000 employees, offering instead plastic cards to buy goods at company-owned stores.
"They are like credit cards, but without any money behind them," said Mikhail Buryakov, head of the mill's finance and economics department. He said the factory -- which depends on barter for 40 percent of its domestic transactions -- had found ways to quadruple its stock of goods, from food to boots, in factory-owned stores. "But that is the state we find ourselves in," he said.
That the steel mill and the city have held together is due to an eerie state of suspended animation, halfway between Communism and capitalism, that has been characteristic of the seven years of Russian reform.
Long after privatization began here in 1992, the mill remains in the hands of directors born and brought up in its shadow and educated mostly at the local mining institute. The Government holds a 23 percent stake in the factory, a testament to Magnitogorsk's special place in Russia's industrial galaxy.
 
Company Town With a 'Steel Heart'
But ownership is still a novel notion and, as elsewhere in Russia, has come with a fair share of scandal. Last year 30 percent of Magnitogorsk's shares disappeared when the director of a local holding company secretly tried to unload them in sales that have since been declared illegal. Those shares have been recovered and are soon to be pledged as collateral against a $95 million credit from the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development.
A Western steel trader tells of a visit to Magnitogorsk a few years ago when he asked a midlevel manager who now owned the metalworks. After a long conversation with a colleague, the manager came back with the memorable reply: "First, we think that is a strange question. And to answer it, we don't know and we don't care."
By various accounts, not all of Magnitogorsk's profits, earned in the export boom of the early 1990's, were plowed back into the steel mill. An untold share was siphoned into offshore trading companies, split between unscrupulous managers and their shady Western trading partners.
"The factory was set free to export," said a former deputy director who left in 1993, "and everyone in management understood that in their own way." The official spoke on condition of anonymity.
But changes have taken place. During the export boom, when Russian steel was selling at world prices and costs were artificially low, Magnitogorsk sank almost $1 billion into new equipment, including a hot-rolling mill. Even now, Magnitogorsk is seeking Government-backed credits for another $1 billion investment, this time in a cold-rolling mill for another stage in the finishing process.
Magnitka -- the nickname for both the town and the factory, intertwined since their birth in 1929 -- is a company town. The factory employs almost half of the work force and pays 40 percent of the city's taxes -- if delivery of raw steel, in lieu of cash, can be called revenues.
Very little happens here that is not connected with the "kombinat," as the mill is called. Besides steel, it produces furniture, cement, bread, meat and other unrelated products. Its electric generators -- including one still operating with boilers from the 1930's -- provide the city with light.
All this has lent a certain feudal stability to life here, with the mill's general director playing the role of baron. Workers, lining up outside the factory gates to pick up their delayed July paychecks on a gray October day, were both bitter and grateful. "At least work here is guaranteed," said Tatyana Konopolova, a clerk. "I see no danger of losing my job."
In 1987 the mill employed 65,000 people, which even then was considered far too many by industry experts. Today, thanks to retirements and other attrition, the number is about 55,000, of whom half make steel.
Such a work force, even sprinkled through the metalworks' array of daughter companies, flies in the face of economic common sense. But to the directors there is simply no other choice.
"Where would people go?" said Sergei Nosov, grandson of the factory's famous World War II director, and now director of its capital construction department. "There would be a huge social explosion, and that is something everyone is afraid of."
The seven years since the collapse of Communism have not been easy, but most people will acknowledge that life has improved. They still remember meat and butter rationing a decade ago, and the hours spent standing in line on cold winter mornings, waiting to buy milk.
Now the stores are full of goods, even if the prices are high -- particularly after the ruble's collapse on Aug. 17. Private restaurants and cafes, even a Baskin-Robbins ice cream store, have opened. People travel abroad, and the town is relatively well kept.
Monthly salaries at the mill average 2,000 rubles, worth about $300 last summer and about $120 today. By Russian standards, that is good pay, certainly better than the 800-ruble average salary of doctors at the city's hospitals, which struggle to afford imported medicines.
 
An Isolation Not So Splendid
But Magnitogorsk -- for decades virtually closed to foreign travelers -- is paying the price for its links to the global economy. First Europe stemmed the flow by imposing quotas. Next came the economic crisis in Asia, where until last year Magnitogorsk sold 43 percent of its exports.
Then Russian producers turned to the United States. If it, too, closes its doors, Magnitogorsk will have to cut production -- again.
This cuts deep into the legend of Magnitogorsk, which has been glorified in Soviet art as Russia's "steel heart."
In the beginning there was logic to Stalin's decision to raise a steel mill on the eastern slopes of the Ural Mountains, 800 miles from Moscow and 1,200 miles from the nearest port, but next to an outcrop of iron ore that continued to supply the plant until the 1970's. In World War II the factory, safely situated hundreds of miles from advancing German troops, cranked up production to provide steel for half of the Red Army's tanks.
But today isolation is a handicap. The mill's two main domestic competitors are in western Russia, closer to export markets and raw materials. In these hard times, transportation has become one of Magnitogorsk's many nightmares.
Another problem is product quality. Throughout the Communist period, Magnitogorsk fulfilled orders from Gosplan, the state planning agency, which emphasized quantity. Magnitogorsk's cold-rolled steel, even now, is not good enough for the Russian automobile industry, because its surfaces cannot hold paint.
The Soviet command economy also left Magnitogorsk at the mercy of monopolist suppliers. Seventy percent of the iron ore pellets it uses still come from a plant 200 miles over the border, in Kazakhstan, now an independent country that accepts payment in dollars, not rubles. It is unclear whether the Primakov Government will grant Magnitogorsk a new flow of money, or forgive its old debts. "Credits would be good for the factory, and the city," said Georgi M. Tikhonov, editor of Magnitogorsk Worker. "Whether it is good for the national economy is another matter."
As far as Mr. Buryakov, the financial director, is concerned, the Government owes the Magnitogorsk mill for the damage it caused on Aug. 17. "It is our Government that created a situation in which we have to live on credit from each other," he said. "They should be the ones giving us credits. I don't know what they will do, but my impression is that this Government will take any steps to avoid any sudden unrest."

HEADLINE: November 1-7;
Russia in Deep Debt

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

 BODY:
After months of hedging, Russia acknowledged that it will default on its foreign debt next year and seek to renegotiate the loans. Its coalition Government put the blame on a collapsing currency. But the looming default also reflects Prime Minister Yevgeni Primakov's failure to put together an economic plan that would advance market reforms -- and win funds from the International Monetary Fund. Russia will also get 1.5 million tons of wheat and $600 million from the United States to buy more American-grown food next month, the United States Agriculture Department said. Russia's food stocks, its Government says, have fallen sixfold, to two or three weeks' reserve. MICHAEL R. GORDON

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
Official Seeks Expansion Of School Choice Policy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Any city school student wanting to attend school in the suburbs could do so under an expansion of school choice policy being considered by the State Board of Education.
The idea would speed up a school choice initiative that is part of a state law intended to reduce racial, ethnic and economic isolation, said Education Commissioner Theodore Sergi, who is proposing the plan. 
 In 1997, Gov. John G. Rowland signed into law a bill requiring the state to reduce racial isolation in public schools. A limited school choice plan began this fall, with more than 900 students being bused from schools in Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven. Mr. Sergi's latest idea would broadly expand the program so it would eventually include students in the entire state.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Gambling: Married to the Action, for Better or Worse

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN; Timothy L. O'Brien, a reporter for The New York Times, is the author of "Bad Bet" (Times Books, 1998), a look at gambling in America.

 BODY:
WHEN California voters approved a measure last week giving Indian tribes broad permission to run casinos unhampered by state control, it was a big loss for the Coalition for Unregulated Gambling, one of the measure's fiercest opponents.
It's not that the coalition disapproves of gambling; in fact, it was financed largely by gambling companies based in that granddaddy of gambling states, Nevada. Why did Nevada's gambling bigwigs, many of whom have pushed aggressively for the acceptance of gambling in other parts of the country, work so hard to keep California from joining the club? Raw fear. 
 More than a third of Nevada's casino patrons come from California, and many of them will stay closer to home if Native Americans offer a more enticing menu of table games and slot machines, which the ballot measure permits. You don't need to be a bookie to know how bad that would be for business in Las Vegas.
California's tribes could end up with legal casinos with about 20,000 gaming devices, about 5 times the number at Foxwoods, the Indian casino in Connecticut, according to William Eadington, an economist at the University of Nevada at Reno. Foxwoods is the biggest gambling joint in the Western Hemisphere. Legislators in California may now feel compelled to legalize or expand gambling at card clubs, race tracks, bars and taverns, and other recreation centers. "All of this would indeed be bad news for Las Vegas," he said.
Nevadans also know that wagering is now a national industry and that the explosive growth of the business has made it available everywhere -- on street corners, on the Internet, and all along the Mississippi River. By the year 2000, 90 percent of Americans will live within 200 miles of a legal casino, the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority noted in a recent report that pointed out challenges facing a town that is still regarded as the mecca of American gambling. Only a generation ago gamblers had few choices but Las Vegas.
But all gambling moguls, not just those based in Las Vegas, are looking over their shoulders. Gambling's ubiquity is forcing the industry's impresarios to fret about the best ways to drum up new business.
"Americans have all the gambling they want," said Eugene Christiansen, a gambling analyst with Christiansen/Cummings Associates in New York. "The driver of growth over the past three decades -- the satiation of unsatiated demand -- is no longer there."
While Steve Wynn's new $1.9 billion Las Vegas casino, the Bellagio, aims to attract new gamblers with luxurious rooms, posh shops and a collection of Picassos and Matisses, analysts expect most gambling concerns to focus on something more basic to stir up new business: gamblers' thirst for action and the fast-paced, mindless devices like slot machines and video lottery games that quench that thirst most effectively.
Even if its growth slows, gambling is still a colossal business. Americans bet $638.6 billion legally in 1997 and lost about $51 billion of that amount -- more than the loot pulled in by the recording, movie and theme park businesses combined. Those losing bets were also up 70 percent from the $30 billion gamblers forked over in 1992, according to International Gaming & Wagering Business, a trade publication.
But that money is being lost in a lot more places now. In 1989, nearly all casino gambling took place in Atlantic City and Las Vegas; now it's just over half. Riverboat gambling is now far bigger than the action in Atlantic City. And the boats are no longer confined to rivers. Last week, voters in Missouri approved a measure legalizing slot machines in casinos floating in artificial basins.
So most gambling concerns are now focused on a core mission: pushing games that appeal to gamblers' need for speed. Speed sells. Speed hooks gamblers. Slot machines have long since replaced the plodding table games of craps and roulette as the mainstays of the casino business. Anyone walking into a casino a few decades ago, when the Rat Pack was in full swing in Las Vegas, would have encountered a room full of table games like blackjack and craps with slot machines relegated to the periphery where the little old ladies played. Today, slot machines dominate the floors of every casino and the allegiance of most gamblers -- especially retirees parked in front of the slots at their local gambling den. Slot machines are fast and simple; crap games are not. So slots and other electronic gambling devices accounted for about 70 percent of the money that gamblers lost in casinos last year.
 
'Video Crack'
Many state lotteries, the recent Powerball mania notwithstanding, are encountering gamblers who are increasingly blase about huge jackpots. The lottery industry calls it "jackpot fatigue," and many lotteries are relying on the speed of instant-ticket games to snag more gamblers. If piles of money aren't enough to get gamblers' attention, the adrenaline blast from a quick gambling hit usually will do the trick. The New York lottery, the largest state lottery in the nation, now gets more money from instant games than it does from its better known Lotto games that offer big jackpots and snare the lion's share of media coverage.
And on-line lottery games like New York's Quick Draw game -- labeled "video crack" by its critics -- let gamblers play a new game every few minutes. Video lottery terminals, though legal in only five states, generated a quarter of all lottery sales nationwide last year.
"There is no question that when you make these machines available, people use them," said Mr. Christiansen, the gambling analyst. "The other side of this is that with increased gambling you create social friction like compulsive gambling. It's a legitimate policy concern." The stakes in all of this are high, because compulsive gambling is still a fuzzy issue and is one of the key concerns of the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, which is currently examining the industry. It is expected to report its findings next year.
When criticized, the gambling industry rightly points out that most gamblers wager within their budgets and just do it for fun. Still, a significant number of gamblers -- about 20 percent in most markets -- lose the lion's share of the money, about 80 percent, according to casino executives. And within this core group, a sizeable though unquantifiable chunk are compulsive or problem gamblers.
Conventional wisdom has it that about 5 percent of the adult population, or some 10 million people, are compulsive gamblers. That is, they are hooked on gambling like others are hooked on nicotine, heroin or alcohol. But terms like compulsive and problem gambling are notoriously fuzzy, given that they are used to describe a wide variety of behaviors that do not fit easy definitions.
Last year, the Harvard Medical School published a study indicating that about 1 percent of the adult population and 6 percent of youths are what could be described as active compulsive gamblers. The same study found that about 3 percent of adults and 15 percent of youths are what could be described as problem gamblers, those who regularly wage beyond their means but are not addicted.
The same study also found that gambling disorders in the United States have been increasing over the last two decades. Needless to say, the growth in gambling problems coincides with the expansion of the gambling industry, and with faster games. It is the faster, repetitive games that tend to be the most addictive.
Still, attempts to put the brakes on gambling have little success. Frank Padavan, a Republican State Senator from Queens, sponsored legislation earlier this year to limit gambling, but it failed. "Compulsive gambling disorders," he said, "may be for Generation X what cocaine and crack were for their parents' generation."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2583 words

HEADLINE: Newark's Toxic Tomb;
Six Acres Fouled by Dioxin, Agent Orange's Deadly Byproduct, Reside in the Shadow of an Awakening Downtown

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
THE crook in the Passaic River affords a view of downtown Newark to the left and lower Manhattan to the right. All around, the life of the city's Ironbound section proceeds for the 40,000 or so residents and thousands more workers on its industrial rim. Everyone agrees that this makes an especially poor site for storing hazardous waste.
Yet a riverfront lot on Lister Avenue, where the Diamond Alkali Company turned out nearly 1 million gallons of Agent Orange for the Vietnam war, is itself about to become a sprawling tomb for the herbicide's toxic byproduct, dioxin. And city officials, who are trying to shake Newark from its decay and neglect and partake of the Wall Street prosperity that neighboring cities have grasped at, have had little to say about the environmental embarrassment not far from the city's center. 
 Fifteen years after the discovery of contamination on the factory site, which sent men in moon suits across the neighborhood with sampling devices, the Environmental Protection Agency has decided on a remedy: rather than excavate or incinerate the soil and debris, Diamond's corporate successor, the Occidental Chemical Corporation, will wall it off and cap it, leaving a sealed six-acre mound amid the riverfront factories.
"They should put a monument to man's stupidity there," said Arnold Cohen, who heads the Ironbound Committee Against Toxic Waste and has spent 15 years in the messy negotiations between community, government and corporate owner of the property. "This could be with us forever."
A permanent installation is not the Federal environmental agency's intention; in fact, it has taken the unusual step of designating the burial plan an "interim remedy," to be re-examined every two years in the hope that eventually technology will yield an economically practical method of removing and decontaminating the soil.
Still, the poisoned parcel on Lister Avenue provides an illustration of how hard it is to make one of New Jersey's best-known products, toxic industrial waste, go away. A decade has passed since the agency and Occidental entered a consent decree setting out the containment plan that the E.P.A. approved only in August. Construction is to begin next year.
Moreover, the factory site is just one section of what is known as the Diamond Alkali Superfund site. The rest consists of a six-mile stretch of riverbed beginning in Clifton and wending through Newark, past the Performing Arts Center and Pennsylvania Station, on its way to Newark Bay. Studies of the dioxin-contaminated river sediments are expected to continue for several years.
Among the corps of activists who fought to have the factory waste removed -- a few suggested Texas, home of Occidental -- some say their elected officials, far from rushing to clean up one of the nation's most densely populated square miles, turned away from a poor community in a poor city.
 
Newark Officials Seem Unfazed
"The politicos have shown no interest whatsoever," Stephen Powell, a neighborhood resident, said after a recent community meeting.
Tirza Wahrman, a lawyer who as an adjunct professor at the Seton Hall law school, organized a symposium last spring on environmental issues in Newark, said: "Another thing going on here is New Jerseyans don't feel a sense of ownership about Newark. It gets lost between New York and Philadelphia, and city government can be hard to get through to."
In expressing frustration with local officials, the residents make an exception for Augusto Amador, their City Councilman, who took office five months ago and almost immediately helped organize a meeting at a housing project near the site.
Mr. Amador, while saying in an interview that the administration would "do the best it could for residents," added that the city had "relieved itself of responsibility with regard to what to do with the stuff."
"The Ironbound is a hotbed for toxic waste," he said. "It's too common for these things to happen in a community that up until recently has lost its political nerve."
Marc Poirier, a Seton Hall professor who organized the symposium with Ms. Wahrman, said the Ironbound was short on advocates and organization. In Newark, Mr. Poirier said, "once you got past the 60's, there's nobody with any political clout. And I don't see any source of political will here. E.P.A. announces they're going to build this giant mound, and in some parts of the world people would be out demonstrating."
Mr. Cohen said the neighborhood's indignation had been spread thin over the years. He can reel off a list of environmental assaults that the Ironbound has tried to repel, including the state's largest garbage incinerator, which opened in 1991, and proposals for a tire incinerator and a medical waste plant, among other things. "The community has been well organized and responsive," Mr. Cohen said. "It's just that they've had to respond to a lot."
For the neighborhood, the encapsulation project is not entirely a defeat. Rather, it is a compromise in what might be called the war of the remedies. The struggle had three sides with three solutions: the community activists, as represented by a citizens advisory board convened by the E.P.A., which wanted the waste dug up and taken away; the site's owners -- compelled by the Superfund law to conduct and pay for the cleanup -- who favored containment, and the agency itself, which initially supported containment but made an 11th-hour pitch for incinerating the contaminated material on site.
The site contains 66,000 cubic yards of dioxin-contaminated soil, the remains of factory buildings and equipment, and debris collected from nearby areas in the initial cleanup effort 15 years ago. Much of the debris is stored in 932 cargo containers stacked six high on one edge of the property; the most heavily concentrated contamination is in the soil, now covered by an impermeable tarpaulin to keep rainwater out and dust in.
The containment plan was devised by a group representing Occidental and other former site operators and their contractors. They maintain that the plan, which has cost $46 million and is expected to require another $20 million, is the safest alternative as long as there is any risk in incineration.
The citizens advisory group and local environmental advocates favored incineration -- as long as it would take place far from the site. "It's either got to be trucked to a hazardous waste landfill or burned at a licensed incinerator," said Michael Gordon, a lawyer who represented former Diamond workers and neighborhood residents in a negligence suit and has continued to advise community groups. "The E.P.A. said there's no place that can handle this material because it's too toxic, no place in the world. And we said, 'You're going to leave it surrounded by people, and the river?' That logic never made any sense."
The agency maintains that the only plant in the nation licensed to destroy dioxin by burning, which is in Coffeyville, Kan., could not handle the construction materials from the Diamond Alkali site and would take 7 to 10 years to process the contaminated soil. The agency also ventured a cost estimate -- $241 million plus transportation costs -- that it said would scotch the idea.
Moreover, said Sharon Jaffess, the E.P.A.'s project manager for the site, the agency does not have the authority to dump the contaminants elsewhere, or to compel Occidental to undertake a totally new plan. As recently as a year ago, the agency, while tentatively endorsing the containment plan, was still investigating the possibility of excavating the site in the hope that such a "walk-away" remedy would allow complete cleanup and reuse of the property. Then it turned to a new idea: on-site incineration, which had been successful in removing dioxin, albeit in lower concentrations, in Times Beach, Mo. Agency scientists estimated that the Diamond Alkali waste could be decontaminated by burning within two years, at a cost of about $40 million.
 
Containment Favored Over Incineration
The advisory group was unmoved. "We're very adamant," Mr. Cohen said. "We don't consider that a solution. We consider it a victory that E.P.A. listened to us. I prefer to deal with the reality of what we're doing now.
"We'd rather have things contained where they can be monitored," he went on. "Mistakes are made. They put rockets into space, and nobody expects to see an explosion. But then there's an explosion. Let's minimize the risks."
The Diamond Alkali team concurred. On-site incineration would be "a disaster," Mr. Jones said. "Dioxins at these levels have never been successfully incinerated anywhere. You've got to have a track record before you start experimenting, especially in a heavily populated area like this."
For the administrators of the Superfund law, that is a common story in New Jersey. The agency estimates that 14,250 people live within a mile of the Chemical Control hazardous waste plant in Elizabeth, for example, site of an explosion and fire in 1980. About 40,000 people live within a mile of the Diamond Alkali site, and 357,000 within three miles.
The Ironbound presented special public relations problems, which the agency said it has tried to address by meeting regularly with the citizens group. "These people have been through hell -- toxic waste, solid waste, all kinds of waste," said Rich Cahill, a spokesman in the agency's regional headquarters in New York. "They felt the shock of being a Superfund site. Guys in moon suits were going into their houses to collect their vacuum cleaner bags."
Given a choice between a dioxin burial ground and another incinerator in the Ironbound, in Mr. Cohen's words, "we chose bad over worse."
The containment project is well under way. L. Anthony Wolfskill, an engineering consultant and former M.I.T. faculty member who is overseeing the design, said two-thirds of the work was done: old tanks and buildings taken down, 500,000 pounds of steel shipped away for recycling, the construction plan all but final.
The mountain of cargo containers will be dismantled. Walls around the site's perimeter will rise. It will be capped, in a mound 15 feet high, with sand, gravel, plastic membranes and geofabrics to seal it from rainwater. Finally, wells will pump groundwater to filter contaminants; a water treatment plant is to be the only building on the property. Construction is expected to take two years.
In the meantime, a coalition of community and environmental groups is applying for a $50,000 grant from the environmental agency to hire its own experts to study the river contamination and to review the containment plan before construction starts.
The escape clause in the pact between the Government and Occidental is the requirement that the company re-investigate other alternatives every two years. Agency officials note that methods of destroying dioxin -- so far, by burning it -- have improved greatly in the last decade and might eventually promise a true cleanup.
But neighbors and environmental groups doubt that the tomb, once built, will ever be dismantled. "I consider ourselves fortunate because this is a court-ordered agreement," Mr. Powell said. "Nobody can back out. But another part of me says they're going to put a cap on it and say, sayonara."
At Superfund sites, putting a cap on the problem is not unusual. The majority are former dumps and landfills that have dribbled toxic substances into the groundwater. The waste usually cannot be treated, and removing it would only create a toxic dump elsewhere. The groundwater must be pumped and monitored for years.
There are now 1,192 sites on the Superfund list, including 107 in New Jersey. Since the first listing in 1983, 178 sites (14 of them in New Jersey) have been removed from the list, the cleanups deemed complete.
Only a few among them have involved dioxin, in its most common form a byproduct in the manufacturing of pesticides. In addition to Times Beach, contaminated by dioxin in oil sprayed on the town's dirt roads, one other dioxin-contaminated site in Arkansas, which also produced Agent Orange, has been put on the Superfund list. At that site, owned by the Vertac Chemical Corporation, the most heavily contaminated waste was shipped to the Coffeyville incinerator and some was buried and capped.
Whatever the exact level of danger it poses -- and there is scientific debate over its toxicity -- dioxin is different. Very few disposal plants can accept it.
Benjamin Longstreth, toxics coordinator for the Baykeeper environmental group, said that among sources of pollution in the waterways around New York, "this is the worst by far."
"You have to go up to the Hudson River Superfund site, the PCB's, to get something comparable," Mr. Longstreth said.
He said the Upper Hudson site, a 40-mile stretch of riverbed from Hudson Falls to Troy, had a much greater volume of contaminated material than the Passaic River or the Diamond Alkali plant. "But dioxin is so much more toxic, perhaps 100 times more toxic than PCB's," he said. "There's nothing like it."
The dangers were unknown for years, though Diamond Alkali was apparently informed in the 1950's that the byproducts from its processes posed health hazards to workers and that using higher temperatures could destroy the toxins.
The Lister Avenue plant had started producing DDT and other herbicides that were precursors of Agent Orange in the 1940's. Diamond, which acquired the plant in 1951, dumped DDT waste products in the river. In their lawsuit against the company, former workers testified that employees were directed to wade out surreptitiously at low tide to chop up mounds of DDT so they would not be detected.
Agent Orange production continued until 1969, and the plant operated off and on until 1983, when the state documented the contamination, believed to be the largest concentration of dioxin in the world. Months later the E.P.A. issued its first listing of sites to be cleaned up under the Superfund law.
A year later, after residents watched workers scrape and sweep the yards and streets around them, the Lister Avenue property was designated a Superfund site.
 
Attention Is Shifting To the Passaic River
The next 15 years brought the halting negotiations and technical studies that the law required. It was a pace fairly typical of problematic Superfund sites -- and a pace that community activists say made residents forget the problem in their midst.
"To E.P.A.'s credit, they've fulfilled a mandate by holding meetings and keeping people abreast of what's happening," Mr. Cohen said. "Have they been aggressive enough in moving this forward?" he asked, repeating the question slowly. "It's been 15 years."
Now, the agency will turn its focus to the river. Already the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has spent millions on dredging dioxin-contaminated material from Port Newark, and long and expensive studies of the six-mile Passaic River portion of the Superfund site are in store. Dioxin binds to soils, and it is unlikely to leach into the river after the flood wall and slurry walls are constructed around the old factory.
Still, the property is a flood zone, and the presence of toxic waste there unsettles everyone. "What scares me is that it's close to the river," Councilman Amador said. "The river should be treated as the heart of the community. Until we decide to change the quality of life in the river, I think we have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
At Play With Space and Its Ideal Proportions

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
ELIZABETH DILLER and Ricardo Scofidio, the New York architects, once took issue with the conventional wisdom that mass tourism, with its comfort, ease and homogenization, has replaced the hardy travel of yore. Actually, they suggested, tourism inflicts an enormous amount of stress, risk, and discomfort. Delayed flights, mixed connections, metal detectors, lost luggage, toddler-size airplane seats, crying infants, pestilentially recycled air and inquisitorial customs officials: this is a new kind of travel, but not a less taxing one.
I was reminded of this recently when I went to Finland to see Kiasma, Helsinki's new museum of contemporary art. The building, which opened in May, was designed by Steven Holl, one of New York's most gifted architects. It shouldn't be necessary for a New Yorker to endure jet lag to check out one of his buildings. And what if the thing turns out to be a turkey? 
 Fortunately, Helsinki's new museum is worth the trip, in part because it is informed by an awareness of the twists and surprises of contemporary life, the unexpected departures from plans, the vast tracts of unknown experience that reside even in a built-up, shrinking world. Artists can explore that experience, and Steven Holl is one of them who does. Hooray for John Glenn's second voyage into outer space; three cheers for Steven Holl for creating a new space on Earth.
Kiasma stands in the center of modern Helsinki. Compared with Senate Square, the city's 19th-century neoclassical core, this nameless zone lacks cohesion and grace. A case study in modern disjunction, it is a mixture of the civic, the commercial and the industrial. Monumental buildings, like the Finnish Parliament and the city's main train station, swim around in the same tepid urban soup with a 50's hotel and shopping complex and a movie theater from the 1930's. All are basically background buildings trying to be foreground buildings.
Holl's design reverses the equation. Firmly planted at the center of this disarray, it is a foreground building that behaves as if it were a background building. Its formal variety, its collagelike use of materials, its reflective surfaces of glass and water, pick up fragments from the city around it and mold them into an astonishing sculptural presence. The views from within -- carefully framed and scaled vistas of the city -- also knit Kiasma into the urban fabric, and transform the way you see it.
The architect got to name his own building. There's not a donor's plaque in sight. Kiasma, a neurological term, refers to a crossing of optical nerves at the base of the brain. Though I doubt that Holl intended a literal depiction, the building's ground floor plan does suggest a cross-over structure: two reflecting pools are joined by a water cascade that runs beneath the museum at the point where it flares out into the horn-shape that terminates the building's northern end. (Holl envisions a water park that will eventually connect the pools to the broad expanse of Helsinki's Toolo Bay.)
But I assume that the optical twists Holl is aiming for are those between art and the city: between the contemplative and the bustling, the metaphoric and the urban domain of material reality; between retinal experience and what the mind's eye makes of it. This he accomplishes with a strikingly assured interplay between windows (including skylights -- the path of the sun was a major force shaping the design) and walls, curves and grids, voids and planes. The result emerges as a symphonic variation on the city itself.
Helsinki never had a museum of modern art. The Finns were probably too busy creating great design. Crowds have flocked to Kiasma since the day it opened. They animate the square as well as the building. A bookstore and cafe are on the ground floor, both open to the public without charge; in one corner of the cafe there are some stools and a shelf with laptops that can also be used free of charge. They are being heavily surfed.
In plan, the museum looks something like a boxcar colliding with a comet. It has two wings, joined by a skylit circulation spine. The roof and inner wall of the largest wing, five stories at its highest point, are both dramatically curved, with the roof curling down to form part of the outer wall. The flat-roofed "boxcar" slams it at an oblique angle. The exterior is clad in polished industrial materials: zinc, aluminum, brass and glass.
Holl's method of design makes it nearly impossible to read his work from plans spatially scenographic. He begins with perspective renderings and then works on constructing the spaces he has envisioned. The building does not express its structure. But the result differs from the scenographic architecture of, say, Charles Moore or Michael Graves. Holl's drawings, while two-dimensional, represent deep and highly plastic space.
On entering, the long ramp of the circulation spine pulls the eye upward and forward; the body follows. As Vesa Honkonen, Holl's associate architect, writes in a book about the museum, this is about movement in space, and the entrance establishes that. No works of art are presented on the the ramp because it is one.
The wings partly overlap and are fused with a seamlessness that makes the building's organization difficult to hold in mind but pleasant to explore. There are four floors of galleries, two of them devoted to the museum's permanent collection, the others to changing exhibitions, special projects and a 230-seat cinema.
None of the galleries resemble the perfect white cube envisioned by modern architects. Entrances to the galleries are not aligned on axis. The walls dividing some of them are not parallel but radiate outward from the shallow curve of the central circulation spine. Side walls echo the curve of the spine or the buildings exterior skin. The galleries are art-friendly. In each, three walls are properly perpendicular and square. But Kiasma is not an egg crate. Its interiors are continually and subtly varied.
Complaint Department:
1. Too much detail. These are mostly finely worked, but not entirely. The small, metal-lined cascade running beneath the building fills up unattractively with grit and now looks like a gutter. But Holl is still relatively young for an architect, and I would much rather see him design with a young man's excessive exuberance than affect an old man's simplicity. And many of the details are wonderful. At night, a small triangular skylight in one of the galleries perfectly frames a blue neon advertising sign floating high up on the skyline in the dark sky. It was delightful to see this in a museum featuring a Bruce Nauman retrospective.
2. Holl's esthetic fundamentalism. Holl is much attached to the Golden Section, not only as a system for determining proportions but also as a means of establishing his lineage from Le Corbusier, whose Modulor system was also based on the Greek ideal. This may be a problem for a contemporary art museum built at a time when many artists are questioning the enduring validity of classical ideals. I myself like a nice, classically ordered space. But when the Section motif turns up repeatedly and emphatically in, say, the design of window mullions, it begins to seem like a crutch.
In 1947, John Summerson gave a lecture at the Architectural Association attacking the orthodoxies of the Modern movement. He believed it would take 10 more years for architects to rebel against them. His hope was that by then architects would "learn to study not merely minimum requirements, but maximum possibilities; to learn not only how to economize space but how to be extravagant with it; to study the overtones of architecture and the geometrical discipline of space as space: to learn not only to use space but to play with space."
Well, a rebellion did occur, but it did not proceed in the direction Summerson had hoped. In America, at least, architects did begin to play, but not with space. They were playing with images, with decorative motifs, visual quotations drawn from pop culture or the historical styles. But by the late 1980's, the post-Modernism dispensation, too, had reached a state of crisis. Today, many architects are beginning to realize something much closer to Summerson's vision. Zaha Hadid, Rem Koolhaas, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, Henry Smith Miller and Laurie Hawkinson, among others, are producing work that aims toward realizing the maximum possibilities of space.
Holl's building is a first-rate example of this development. Too bad it takes practically a space mission to get there.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 4; Column 4; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO;
Models Without Runways

BYLINE: By SARAH SCHMIDT 

 BODY:
A JET plane roars across the screen. The camera cuts to a speeding Gillette razor, which flies into the outstretched hand of a handsome, towel-clad actor. After shots of the shaving actor and a close-up of the razor's triple-blade system, the razor zooms through the air again and lands in its package.
Gillette manufactures its razors in South Boston, but the three-foot-long Mach 3 razors in this 30-second television commercial were made by John Kuntzsch and his crew at Brooklyn Model Works, one of the handful of advertising model makers in New York. 
 Product models have been used in television commercials since Lucky Strike cigarette packages came dancing onto American screens in the 1940's. But the industry's roots, in the print field, are much deeper.
"It goes back to the advertising early in this century," said Mr. Kuntzsch from his Red Hook studio, where plastic bars of Caress soap share workbench space with 10-inch-by-15-inch credit cards and a Maalox tablet 3 inches in diameter. "A photographer must have looked at the real thing with all the lights on it through the lens and said: 'This doesn't look so great. Let's build a better one.' "
Real food melts, real pills are too small, and shooting exotic spots on location is costly and time-consuming. And even the most beautiful actors can't make a gooey bar of soap look good on camera. But cover a sculptured bar of plastic soap in lather, do a close-up, and the viewer sees a fresh bar of soap with sharp lines and a readable logo.
"We make things look hyper-real," Mr. Kuntzsch said.
While most of the visual effects for movies and television shows are done in Los Angeles, most advertising models are built in New York, where most agencies are based. (Agencies frequently check up on the models as they are being built.)
About a dozen model-making businesses, usually with a couple of full-time employees and a group of freelancers, handle most of the advertising work in the city. Generally, a model maker is hired by the director or the photographer of the advertisement, although agencies and clients may have a preference. Individual models can cost from $500 for a simple item (an oversized pill) to $100,000 for an extremely detailed model (a small-scale city, say, with buildings, landscaping and moving parts). Materials are inexpensive, so the price depends mainly on the labor involved.
It was in the 1980's that New York's model-making business came into its own, with the booming economy and an advertising trend away from the goofy character costumes of the 1970's, like the Kool-Aid Man and the Fruit of the Loom gang.
In the 80's, "There was this glut of very similar products, and every manufacturer was trying to persuade you that theirs was the best," Mr. Kuntzsch said. "The differences in reality would be very small, so you'd have to get in really close to exploit those differences."
Today, typical requests include large-scale models of small products (cereal flakes), small-scale models of large things (monuments) and long-lasting models of the ephemeral (ice). Then come items that just don't exist, like dancing gas pumps.
But though advertising models are still in demand, improvements in computer graphics "have put a huge dent" in the business, said Arthur Portnoy, who represents advertising visual-effects companies.
Smaller model-making companies are starting to worry. "It used to be that they'd spend literally $20,000 on one small model of something like a fancy icicle," said Dan Castelli, whose shop in the Garment Center, Castelli Models and Effects, is cluttered with items like a 2-foot-long Dr. Scholl's foot cushion and a 13-inch Prozac capsule. "There was no other way to get a really nice picture of it. Then about four years ago, computer graphics programs started getting really good."
Computer-generated imagery, known as C.G.I., is most often used to replace models for precise or glossy items: logos, credit cards, gears, computer circuits. "If you want to go inside of a razor and look around, that's something that should be done with C.G.I.," Mr. Portnoy said.
But the more irregular something is, the less well C.G.I. works, at least at the moment. Anything organic -- skin, wood, plants, food -- is still nearly impossible to do with C.G.I, nor can it duplicate the movement of water convincingly.
"You could have done these letters C.G.I.," said Christo Holloway of Clockwork Apple, a shop in the meatpacking district, as he showed how his movable "Plaque" letters are rigged to break apart and dissolve when hit with a splash of Plax mouthwash. "But you never could have gotten a good enough splash."
Moreover, at least for now, actual models are cheaper than virtual ones. Thirty seconds of computer animation can cost up to $650,000, Mr. Portnoy said.
More advertisements are combining C.G.I. with models. For Gillette Mach 3, three large-scale razors were used for the close-ups, while Digital Domain, which did special effects for "Titanic," used computer animation to create the airplane.
Model makers are even employing computer graphics themselves. In a Sprint advertisement, Mr. Holloway used a computer drafting program to design a miniature city connected by phone circuits. He sent the designs to an etching company, which transferred them to metal panels, which he bent into three-dimensional buildings.
"Twenty years ago, I did a miniature New York skyline for a liquor ad and I had to cut out each window by hand," Mr. Holloway said.
Although model makers admit that their field is becoming more specialized, Mr. Kuntzsch predicts there will always be room for their art.
"There's only so much you can do with a bunch of pixels," he said.

Some terms used in the product-model business:
 
KNURDLE (NER-del) -- A solid model of an application of toothpaste which is curled at both ends; seen in Aqua Fresh ads.
 
WORM -- A solid model of an application of toothpaste which is not curled at the ends.
 
POUR -- A solid model of a liquid that appears as if it is being poured; used in Mountain Dew ads.
 
HERO -- A specially built model of a product that will star in the final take for an ad.
 
PRACTICAL -- A stand-in for the hero; used in rehearsal so the hero does not get scuffed.

PUB-DATE: November 9, 1998

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1877 words

HEADLINE: A Busy Man of Opera Gets Even Busier;
Domingo, Artistic Director in Washington, Is 'Upgrading' His Job in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Even by his own standards, Placido Domingo has accomplished an extraordinary hat trick in recent weeks. At the same time he was discussing extending his contract at the Washington Opera, where he has been artistic director since 1996, he was also meeting individually with members of the board, and with the entire executive committee, to explain why they should not be alarmed at his decision to become the artistic director of the Los Angeles Opera while continuing to hold the reins in Washington.
Mr. Domingo's contract in Washington ends in 2002, and the extension under discussion would take it to 2004. The Los Angeles post, which was announced last week, begins in July 2000. The announcement comes at a time when the Los Angeles company is hoping to increase its number of productions and performances, and Mr. Domingo says he is willing to curtail his own performing schedule in order to keep up with his new responsibilities. 
 Still, Mr. Domingo says he regards his Los Angeles position as more of an upgrade than an entirely new job. His connection with the company goes back to its founding in 1984. At first, he signed on as a member of its board, and when Peter Hemmings became its first general director, Mr. Domingo took the title of artistic consultant. He sang the title role in the company's first production, "Otello," in 1986 and became artistic adviser in 1995.
At 57, he now succeeds Mr. Hemmings, who is retiring at 64. Mr. Hemmings has already planned the 2000-01 season, so Mr. Domingo's own programming will not be seen until 2001-02.
"I think of my new position as an upgrading," Mr. Domingo said in a telephone interview between rehearsals in Washington, "because as artistic adviser I was involved in discussions with Peter Hemmings about the productions, the casting. It was a collaboration, although it was minor compared with what I will have to do now."
Still, Mr. Domingo's dual directorship raises questions. The most immediate is: Where in his schedule is the room to pencil in further commitments? He continues to give more than 60 performances a year in international opera houses, and in recent years he has been conducting as well, both in the opera pit and on the symphonic podium. Every four years, when the World Cup games are played, he joins Luciano Pavarotti and Jose Carreras to trawl for megabucks as the Three Tenors. He sponsors Operalia, which is billed as the world's largest opera competition, held annually. And to keep things exciting, he owns a restaurant, called Domingo, on East 49th Street in Manhattan.
If the Washington Opera board members have doubts about Mr. Domingo's ability to run two companies effectively, they have not expressed them publicly. Robert Craft, the president of the company, said that after he faxed board members to warn them, on Oct. 30, that the Los Angeles appointment would be announced the following Monday, he received no protests, comments or questions.
Mr. Domingo and spokesmen for both companies have advanced a variety of reasons why the dual directorship poses no problems for either side. But weighing heavily in the equation is something the companies do not go out of their way to point out: Mr. Domingo's value as a fund-raising asset more than offsets any problems that might be caused by potential scheduling conflicts.
Opera companies, and arts organizations in general, learned long ago that if they are associated with an artist who is a household name, corporate and private donations flow more freely. Beverly Sills discovered this when she was director of the New York City Opera, and she has continued to put her celebrity to use in raising money as chairwoman of Lincoln Center. Mr. Domingo, as one of the best-known opera singers of his generation, has proved to be a similar lure.
 
No Mere Figurehead
But those in the opera world who expected Mr. Domingo to be little more than a money magnet have been surprised at his hands-on approach to the Washington job. No mere figurehead, he taken charge of the company's programming, offering both standard repertory and unusual works. His success has been mixed: rarities like "Il Guarany," by the 19th-century Brazilian composer Antonio Carlos Gomes, and the company's current production of Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" have been skewered by critics; others, including a revival of an American classic, Douglas Moore's "Ballad of Baby Doe," have fared better.
Mr. Craft, noting that Mr. Domingo has also been involved in administrative aspects of the Washington company, said the level of energy he had brought to his work helped persuade the board that his taking on another directorship would not be a problem.
"I really don't think there were doubts expressed in the executive committee after hearing him explain how he could do both these jobs," Mr. Craft said.
Part of Mr. Domingo's presentation, both Mr. Craft and Mr. Domingo said, was a demonstration that the production schedules of the two companies did not overlap, allowing Mr. Domingo to focus on each during crucial times.
"We can organize the dates so that if something is happening on one company, it is not also happening in the other," Mr. Domingo said. "In other words, as an artistic director, I begin to think three years ahead about a production: about casting, conductors, designers, directors.
"And then, if you have the right people with you, they can start to get in touch. That's not work I have to do. I have the ideas. Then, when the production begins, I am involved in the beginning moments, I attend the first rehearsals; I look in as the rehearsals develop and I attend the final rehearsals and the opening. I don't have to be in the city the whole time."
Mr. Hemmings, the outgoing general director of the Los Angeles Opera, noted that Mr. Domingo was succeeding him only partly, coming in as artistic director, not general director. "So there will be someone else to take on that part of the job," he said. "And the search for that person has not yet begun."
 
How Much Work Can Be Delegated?
But that raises further questions. Can a directorship be maintained if so much is delegated? And what will happen if crises occur when Mr. Domingo is on the other side of the country? A division of responsibilities of this sort, however, is hardly without precedent. Artistic and administrative duties are handled by separate staffs, under separate directors, at both the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera; and James Levine, the artistic director of the Met, spends time away from his company.
The model that Mr. Domingo presented to his board in Washington, moreover, included some tempting blandishments, including the possibility of sharing productions, and therefore costs, with the Los Angeles Opera. The two companies have borrowed each other's productions on occasion; now that arrangement would be formalized.
"There could be some synergies and economic possibilities," said Christine Hunter, the chairwoman of the Washington Opera's executive committee. "It would be an ace in hand to assemble a wonderful cast for a production and have it performed both places. Even if the production begins in Los Angeles and comes to Washington, we have a true ensemble when it arrives."
Mr. Domingo did not think that was quite what he had proposed.
"It's a nice dream," he said, "but I don't see it working exactly that way. It's difficult to get singers to commit that much time, for rehearsals and a production in one city, and then moving to another city.
"I was thinking that our shared productions would not coincide in the same season. But there are exceptions. In 2003, for example, I hope to celebrate the anniversary of Berlioz with a big production of 'Benvenuto Cellini.' That could be in both theaters. But it would be an exception."
 
Energy Inspires Confidence
Mr. Craft expressed complete confidence in Mr. Domingo's energy, noting that one week recently, he sang at the Met on a Saturday night, stayed up until 5 A.M. studying the score of Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila," which he was about to conduct, then attended a Sunday noon brunch in Maryland on his way to "Simon Boccanegra" rehearsals in Washington.
That night, he flew to the West Coast, and was back to conduct "Aida" at the Met on Tuesday.
Mr. Domingo, however, has started to rethink his ability to take on an imprudent number of commitments, and he said that when he began in Los Angeles, the shape of his performing schedule would change.
"I will cut my touring," he said, "so I can spend more time around Washington and Los Angeles. When I am working at the Washington Opera and singing at the Met, I can commute. When I am in Los Angeles, that will give me a chance to perform more with the San Francisco Opera, which is a company I love very much. But to do this, I will have to give up some of my European engagements."
At the moment, the Washington and Los Angeles companies are of comparable size: Washington, with a budget of $25 million, presents 70 performances of 8 productions a year; Los Angeles has a $19 million budget and presents 54 performances of 8 productions.
Both, however, have cautious expansion plans. After the renovation of the Kennedy Center Opera House, the company may add slowly to its production schedule, assuming it can raise the money to do so. The Los Angeles Opera, which shares the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, will be in a position to expand when the Philharmonic moves to Walt Disney Hall, possibly in 2002.
Within the next two years, Mr. Hemmings said, the company expects to add another production, and by the 2003-04 season, it envisions giving 80 to 90 performances of 9 or 10 productions. This expansion is tied to the ability to raise money and expand the audience. Besides his skill at attracting donations, Mr. Domingo has another edge in Los Angeles: The company hopes that having a Spanish-speaking director -- and one with a passion for zarzuela, a form of popular Spanish opera -- will help it reach into the growing Hispanic community.
 
The Structure Is In Place
There is a sense, too, that time is on Mr. Domingo's side. Neither company is likely to expand much before 2000, and his responsibilities in Los Angeles do not begin in full until 2001. By the time that growth at either company begins to exert any real pressure on him, Mr. Domingo will be in his early 60's, and may be reconsidering his singing schedule yet again. If worse came to worst, he could decide between companies.
Mr. Hemmings, who is returning to his native England, where he will consult and oversee the construction of an opera house, discounts assertions that holding two positions will be unduly taxing for Mr. Domingo, and in any case, he has no fears for the company he built in Los Angeles over the last dozen years.
"He is an incredibly busy and active man," Mr. Hemmings said. "He has considerable roots here. Because I'm not a performer, I've always been resident in the place I'm working, and have therefore had time for a lot of the administrative details. But those will now devolve upon an executive director. So a lot of the structure is in place, and I think he'll succeed."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Out of work for a year, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco's cartoon endorser now faces Government charges.

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JOE CAMEL, the advertising icon that became a powerful symbol to critics of the tobacco industry's efforts to get minors to smoke, will go on trial today, more than a year after he was retired by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
The Federal Trade Commission brought the case contending that Reynolds, a unit of RJR Nabisco, committed an unfair trade practice by using the Joe Camel character to attract children and adolescents to cigarettes. Government lawyers assert that once Reynolds introduced the campaign, Joe Camel became as recognizable to children as Mickey Mouse, promoting a lethally addictive product for a segment of the cigarette market that was central to the company's future. 
 The case is the culmination of an eight-year struggle between the F.T.C. and Reynolds over the Joe Camel campaign. It is also the first time that the commission has characterized a tobacco advertising program as unfair because of its effect on young consumers.
Since the company voluntarily decided to pull the campaign last year just weeks after the commission filed its complaint, the case has turned into the regulatory equivalent of a probate contest, with the two sides fighting over Joe Camel's corpus.
The Government seeks a permanent ban blocking Reynolds from ever using Joe or his brethren characters, which include Buster, Max and Floyd, in cigarette ads. Government lawyers have also asked the administrative law judge hearing the case to order Reynolds to pay for a consumer education program intended to discourage adolescents and teen-agers from buying cigarettes.

 Reynolds has tried to transform Joe Camel from a cool and goofy promotional character to a protector of the First Amendment. The company says that Joe Camel has had no significant impact on smoking by people younger than 18 and contends that the commission's complaint poses fundamental constitutional issues that are certain to affect how other industries can go about marketing their products.
"The witnesses and other evidence the F.T.C. will put on will not show that Joe Camel caused anyone -- let alone underage persons -- to start smoking, smoke more or not quit when they otherwise would have," said Guy M. Blynn, vice president and deputy general counsel of Reynolds. "This attack on cigarette advertising will fail both because it does not meet the Federal Trade Commission's own standard for establishing unfairness, and because it tramples on the constitutionally protected right of a lawful industry to advertise a lawful product."
Lawyers at the commission respond that the First Amendment does not protect unfair trade practices, particularly in a case like this in which the product at issue causes deaths and illnesses. In a trial brief filed two weeks ago, the F.T.C. said that the Camel campaign "had immediate and dramatic effects on youth smoking behavior."
"Within one year, Camel's brand share of smokers below the legal smoking age almost tripled and within five years quadrupled," the brief said. "More disturbing, the incidence of youngsters age 12-17 smoking their first cigarette began to increase, as did the incidence of daily smoking by this age group."
According to a Federal survey, the brief concluded, the incidence of new smoking increased by nearly a third, and the incidence of daily smoking rose by 50 percent, during the years of the Joe Camel campaign.
But the company contends that the Joe Camel campaign was aimed primarily at the 18-to-24 age group. The case will feature a stream of testimony and company documents about its advertising campaign, disclosing the marketing strategy of Reynolds at a time when it was beginning to see a serious erosion in sales.
In addition to company executives who worked on the campaign, the two sides are expected to call experts in health, marketing and economics.
The Joe Camel character was created in 1974 by a British artist, Nicholas Price, for a Camel advertising campaign in France that subsequently appeared in other countries throughout the 1970's. The character arrived in the United States in 1988 in materials created by Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C., for the 75th anniversary of the Camel brand.
The figure almost immediately attracted the attention of officials studying the problem of smoking among the young.
After studies found that Camels were 10 times as popular among teen-agers as adults and that illegal sales of cigarettes to minors had reached $500 million, the Surgeon General, Antonia Novello, called on Reynolds to withdraw the Joe Camel campaign.
Five years ago, the F.T.C. staff recommended banning Joe Camel ads because of their appeal to children. But in 1994 the commission rejected the recommendation by a vote of 3 to 2. President Clinton then attacked Joe Camel, saying the campaign told minors that "smoking is cool."
In March 1997, the staff of the F.T.C. again recommended taking action against the campaign, and two months later, the commission approved the complaint that is to be heard today.
The case is expected to be completed next month.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A New Drama on Broadway And a New Son in Turmoil

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
Talk about a play with legs: "Side Man" has been using them on a veritable walking tour of Manhattan. The production's unusual journey began last spring with a brief, acclaimed run in a little Off Broadway theater and continued with a successful move for the summer to the main stage of the normally revival-driven Roundabout Theater Company.
Now "Side Man" has entered an even unlikelier phase of its nomadic life, leaving the relative security of nonprofit theater for a commercial Broadway run at the 800-seat John Golden Theater. The significance of the drama's rise, and the bravery of its producers, should not be understated. Although in recent years new musicals like "Rent" and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk" have moved popularly and profitably from Off Broadway, uprooting a new straight play to Broadway is an altogether iffier proposition because the production can't count on the musical-devouring tourist trade or on the kind of built-in hype that often attends a glittery London transfer. Its survival depends on a smaller, specialized audience of serious playgoers, many of whom may already have discovered it. 
 The odds, therefore, may be especially long on Warren Leight's lovely "Side Man," which reopened last night. The show is such an anomaly on Broadway, a tender, deeply personal memory play about the turmoil in the family of a jazz musician as his career crumbles at the dawn of the age of rock-and-roll, that seeing it on a big stage is like peering at Broadway through the giant stereopticons of "Ragtime." It's a gentle reminder of bygone days, when a new play by Tennessee Williams or William Inge would stir up the public and fill seats for months.
In its depiction of a young man struggling to remain the glue in the troubled marriage of his vacant, trumpet-playing father and unbalanced, alcoholic mother, the play has an abiding power, although of a muted variety. (Men, I think, whose fathers were emotionally unavailable will respond especially strongly to the hero's predicament.) But if you go to "Side Man" expecting tour de force portrayals or actorly pyrotechnics, you're liable to feel as if you've walked into the wrong neighborhood. Go instead for the more refined pleasures of Mr. Leight's offbeat story and his true-to-life, as opposed to larger-than-life, characters.
The production, directed by Michael Mayer, is practically a mirror of its Roundabout incarnation, with one important exception: the addition to the cast of the movie actor Christian Slater in the central role of Clifford, the play's put-upon son and narrator. (Robert Sella, the role's originator, left to fill in for Alan Cumming as the M.C. in "Cabaret.")
Mr. Slater's performance is courageously economical and without showiness; it retains the actor's cinematic sense of containment in close-up. This works extremely well in a role that is all about the witnessing, absorbing and denying of pain. His composure pays off remarkably at the play's subtle climax, when Clifford must thoroughly assume the role of parent to his parents and cast his ineffectual father, Gene (played by Frank Wood), out of the family's apartment.
The actor never overplays Clifford's festering anger. It's expressed, in fact, only once, when Gene suggests that he has no responsibility for the pathetic condition of his wife, Terry (Wendy Makkena), now confined to a psychiatric hospital. Disgusted, Mr. Slater sends Mr. Wood flying helplessly into a chair. Suddenly aware of his power, and inclined to use it, the son has taken control. Mr. Slater pulls this off so unself-consciously that you believe in it as an act of frustrated love rather than rage.
Alternating between the family's apartment and Gene's world of versatile, freelance jazz musicians -- the side men of the title -- the play conjures an extremely specific slice of New York City between 1953 and 1985. It pairs the story of the decline of jazz with the disintegration of Clifford's family, and yet some of the moodier interludes erupt with astonishing joy, as when, in flashback, Gene woos Terry with a bluesy trumpet version of Debussy.
No moment is better than the one in which Gene, sitting with two of his cronies, played delightfully by Michael Mastro and Joseph Lyle Taylor, is swept away listening to a cassette of an heartache-filled trumpet solo. Mr. Wood's rapture is even more wrenching than the music.
Mr. Mayer holds onto much of what made "Side Man" so touching, but a few things have also slipped in the move around the corner to West 45th Street. It may be that the actors are too conscious of the higher stakes on Broadway because they are now misguidedly pushing things, trying to convince us that this is a punchier, more monumental play than written.
Ms. Makkena, saddled with the difficult job of ending Act I with the declaration of a not-very-potent threat, has become intolerably broad and cartoonish. This is only partly her fault. Terry is the play's toughest role, consisting largely of volume-raising rants and pitiful tears. How many ways can an actor do meltdown? And the gang of jazz men suddenly seems to be actively courting audiences (and Tony voters) by telegraphing the laugh lines, which, of course, only makes the laughs harder to come by.
The strength of "Side Man" is that it holds its characters accountable and, with affection and efficiency, tells us things about people in a quirky little cul-de-sac that reminds us of people in our own imperfect worlds. This honesty and directness is what makes it a vital and refreshing experience, and what, if anything in the unpredictable whirlpool of Broadway, will sustain it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christian Slater has taken over the central role of the beleaguered son in "Side Man" at the John Golden. (Carol Rosegg/"Side Man")(pg. E4)

Netscape Co-Founder Plans To Invest in VCR Alternative
A co-founder of Netscape Communications is expected to announce today that he has invested in one of two companies developing digital television recording systems, a technology intended to replace the traditional home VCR.
The investment by Marc Andreessen in Replay Networks Inc., a small Silicon Valley start-up, would be an important vote of confidence for the systems, which enable viewers to watch, store and retrieve programs in novel ways, including recording a complete program that is already in progress, automatically recording programs that meet certain criteria -- for example, movies with a particular actor -- and skipping commercials. Joe Camel, the advertising icon that became a powerful symbol to critics of the tobacco industry, will go on trial today, more than a year after he was retired by R. J. Reynolds Tobacco. The case is the culmination of an eight-year struggle between the Federal Trade Commission and Reynolds over the campaign, which the commission contended was an unfair trade practice because it used Joe Camel to attract children and adolescents to cigarettes. Despite promises earlier this year by the owner of "The Jerry Springer Show" to tone down the program's violence, the brawling or attempted brawling have resumed, along with so many bleeps that it is often impossible to follow the dialogue, and the show's ratings have risen in tandem with its ribaldry. Magaziner to Leave Government
Ira C. Magaziner, who has led Government efforts to foster the growth of the Internet and electronic commerce, said he would leave the White House before the end of the year. The announcement comes as the Government prepares to turn over governance of the Internet to a private multinational organization and as it heads into a period of what are expected to be tough negotiations with the European Union over data privacy issues. Thrust and Parry at Microsoft Trial
As its antitrust trial moves into the fourth week, Microsoft finds itself trying to deflect a flood of allegations of threats and bribes. The Justice Department contends that the digital-age monopolist showed up in the doorway, brandishing a club in one hand while offering price discounts and marketing support with the other. Microsoft insists that its tactics are not hurting consumers. News Analysis. C6.
 
Coastal Differences in Capital
Different attitudes toward venture financing at established technology companies on the East and West Coasts have resulted in very different environments for the incubation of high-technology start-ups in Silicon Alley and Silicon Valley. On the West Coast, entrepreneurs routinely seek out larger, established technology companies as part of the start-up process. On the East Coast, the corporate-to-entrepreneur network is not as evolved. Prospectus. C4.
 
Separate Home for Public Relations
In a sharp departure from other journalism schools, which have incorporated advertising and public relations under the rubric of mass communications, the University of Maryland's College of Journalism has dropped public relations, which will be part of a communications program in another department.
