HEADLINE: All That Glitters Isn't Gold;
Charlotte Area Feels Ill Effects From the Asian Crisis

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

 BODY:
The downtown skyline comes suddenly into view just over a rise on Interstate 85. In the distance, the morning sun sparkles on the glass and polished-stone office towers, which seem to rise straight up from the green countryside. More than one visitor, catching sight of the skyline for the first time, has compared the experience to Dorothy's wide-eyed first glimpse of the Emerald City.
The comparison is apt, if exaggerated. Greater Charlotte, a star performer in the economic expansion of the 1990's, does have an aura of having sprung from the soil overnight. The towering skyline did not exist a decade ago. Nor did most of the industrial parks, luxury homes, hotels, office buildings and shopping centers that now spread for miles, adding thousands of jobs. 
 But the global financial crisis is beginning to erode this achievement. Manufacturing is particularly vulnerable. Many companies here make products that are also made, less expensively, in Asia. Currency devaluations have increased this cost advantage. And with recessions shrinking demand at home, the Asians are shipping more merchandise to America, cutting into Charlotte's markets.
What is happening in the Charlotte area -- a seven-county region with 1.4 million people -- appears to be happening in other Southeastern metropolises that have enjoyed similar booms. A shining example of the South's rising prosperity in the 1990's, Charlotte now illustrates how the Asian financial squeeze is starting to undercut that growth.
"The South has gone from being a high-flying economy to a more moderately expanding one, with signs of more slowing down the road," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates. "But unlike the weakening that has occurred in the West or the Farm Belt, the weakening here is related more to competition from imports than to difficulty exporting."
The Charlotte metropolitan area has flourished because of its prosperous banks, because of its advantages as a distribution center and because of the constant influx of new companies, drawn here in part by a relatively low-wage work force and by state laws that restrict labor unions. Dozens of telephone marketing and customer service operations have located here. So have several corporate headquarters and all sorts of service companies.
But the largest contingent is low-cost manufacturers. No industry employs more people in the area than manufacturing: 141,000 in a work force of 764,000. Historically a center for textile and apparel companies, the Charlotte area, like elsewhere in the South, is host today to a variety of manufacturers that have migrated here from higher-wage states or from abroad. They make, among other things, machine tools, fiber optic cable, chemicals, paper, electronic switches, auto parts, tires, yarn -- all items Asian companies are selling in the United States in growing quantities.
Consider Carolina Pad, one of the many manufacturers whose single-story plants have devoured the farmland along I-85 and I-77, which intersect here. The company makes all sorts of pads and notebooks, using paper increasingly imported from Indonesia. Given the shrinking demand for paper in Asia, the Indonesians are converting their paper to pads and offering them for sale in the United States. Yellow legal pads -- one of Carolina Pad's products -- are a big Indonesian item.
The Indonesians "took Staples' business, not from us, but from a competitor, at 24 1/2 cents a pad when the going rate was 29 cents," said Joseph K. Hall 3d, chairman and owner of Carolina Pad, which employs 130 people at $7 to $10 an hour. "I'll know by mid-December how we stand against them in the back-to-school market for next fall, and if they get in enough I may have to cut out our second shift."
Construction activity in the Charlotte area offers a more visible signal of the erosion taking place. Buildings are going up everywhere. But it is construction that began months ago; ground is being broken for very few new offices, factories and warehouses. Less visibly, job creation, strong last winter, has slowed now, mainly because of a decline in manufacturing jobs, a problem everywhere in America. Banks are lending more cautiously, encouraging developers, for example, to sign up more tenants in advance before actually borrowing money to put up an office or apartment building. Corporate relocations, once such a huge source of growth, have declined. And so has human migration. Fewer people from elsewhere in the nation are asking the Chamber of Commerce about opportunities in Charlotte.
"The home-building numbers I have seen have started to tail off; you don't have the same influx of people," said William A. Hodges, managing director for real estate at Bank of America, which moved its headquarters here after merging this summer with Nationsbank, a Charlotte institution that has expanded exponentially in recent years.
Bank of America, a unit of the BankAmerica Corporation, and First Union, another banking giant based here, have generated much of the downtown office tower construction to accommodate their expanding national operations. Each occupies a skyscraper and each is planning to construct another office tower.
"We have a built-in demand in this community that will drive commercial construction growth for some time," said Malcolm E. Everett 3d, president of First Union's North Carolina operation -- referring mainly to the demand created by the banks themselves.
Overcapacity is inhibiting other construction. That is the problem for warehouses in Charlotte, which is second only to Atlanta as a distribution center for the Southeast. The warehouse vacancy rate has risen gradually, to a discouraging 15 percent from 10 percent in 1994. Nor does the banking industry's building boom hold for hotels. Two big hotel projects have either been canceled or delayed, including a 1,000-room structure that was to have gone up on Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker's old revival grounds in nearby Rock Hill, S.C.
"A lot of new industrial capacity has been brought on line, and people are going to wait until they fill up some of that capacity before they go out and do it again," said James K. Buchanan, First Union's chief of commercial lending in the Carolinas. "That would have been the case even without Asia."
Even Bank of America and First Union are pulling back on one front. With the global financial disarray curtailing bond market activity, they are no longer importing high-wage investment bankers to beef up their capital markets operations, which are based not on Wall Street but here. The hiring freeze, in turn, has curtailed the bidding for $1 million homes in the swankier suburbs.
But manufacturers are hurt the most. Drive south on I-77 from downtown Charlotte and stop at the Okuma America Corporation, which manufactures machine tools in one of the sprawling industrial neighborhoods. Meet John D. Hendrick, 60, the president and chief operating officer, and listen to him bracing for the months ahead.
"If I were talking to you a year ago, I would have been very upbeat," he said in an interview. "We have had a very strong 1998, but there are too many soft spots developing. Orders are already down and that means the first six months of 1999 are going to be down for us."
Okuma is a Japanese-owned manufacturer of computer-controlled lathes and machining centers, which cut metal into precisely measured rectangles and cubes. The largest, most expensive, most technologically sophisticated are made in Japan and exported for $1 million apiece.
Several are installed at the Okuma plant here. Okuma had a distribution operation on Long Island before locating its factory in lower-cost Charlotte in 1987. The big Japanese machines cut the intricate metal parts that go into the smaller, blue-and-beige lathes and machining centers made here and sold by the dozens in the United States for between $100,000 and $150,000 as standard equipment in factories and machine shops. "Commodity machinery," Mr. Hendrick calls it. Companies in South Korea and Taiwan make similar commodity machinery, and that is Mr. Hendrick's growing headache.
"They have always been in the United States to some degree," he said, "but now with their home markets hurt, their presence is much greater. We sell through dealers and they tell us that the Koreans and Taiwanese are calling them, offering prices 10 to 15 percent below ours."
Okuma's goal, Mr. Hendrick said, is to hold onto market share, which means cutting prices and reducing profits, and this at a moment when Okuma America generates half of the parent company's annual revenue of nearly $900 million. It also means a cap on hiring in Charlotte, after two years in which the work force grew to 485 from 402.
Some Charlotte-area companies cut labor costs through layoffs. Okuma is taking a different tack. Its 300 assembly line workers, earning up to $15 an hour, have been collecting 25 percent of their annual income through overtime. That built-in overtime is being cut back to 10 percent. "We are slowing the assembly line," Mr. Hendrick said.
Drive west, to Gastonia, on the Catawba River, an old center of the textile industry, still a big employer in the Charlotte area. Through relentless spending on new technology and machinery, yarn manufacturers have survived against foreign competitors and Gastonia is now a yarn-making center.
Some companies have thrived, among them Parkdale Mills, the nation's largest cotton yarn manufacturer, operating 31 plants, most of them in North Carolina, including three in Gastonia, the company's headquarters. The work force of 3,500 is only 300 people higher than in 1988. But Parkdale's yarn production has doubled.
Lands' End sells shirts made from fabric woven in the United States with Parkdale's yarn. This is higher-quality yarn that the Asians do not make, says Duke Kimbrell, Parkdale's chief executive. The problem is at the low end.
First, Asian yarn is going into inexpensive T-shirts and golf shirts made in Asia and entering the United States in growing quantities. They are displacing similar shirts sewn in Mexico using fabric woven in the United States with American yarn.
Second, there is Pakistan, which has a huge yarn industry. With their sales in Asia shrinking, Pakistani companies are selling more lower-quality yarn to American fabric makers. "A basic Pakistani T-shirt yarn sells in the United States for under $1 a pound while American yarn makers charge just over $1," said Jim H. Conner, executive vice president of the American Yarn Spinners Association.
The upshot in Gastonia has been plant closings and production cutbacks, although the town's growing role as a prosperous bedroom community for Charlotte masks the impact on its textile workers, who earn $8 to $11 an hour. Parkdale's mills now operate 120 hours a week, down from 168 hours earlier this year. And the entire yarn industry is planning a four-day shutdown at Thanksgiving and 10 days at Christmas.
Still, many companies in Charlotte continue to prosper. BellSouth is one. It employs 3,000 people in the southern third of the state and operates out of a modern office building in a crowded Charlotte industrial park that did not exist 12 years ago.
"We are working more overtime than ever," said Robert Freedman, BellSouth's regional director, and he ticks off the growth of telephone access lines in his region: 435,000 in 1996, 467,000 in 1997, 493,000 in 1998.
"I hate to sound like a Chamber booster," Mr. Freedman said, "but the future is so bright that you have to wear shades."
The Chamber is not quite so enthusiastic. Tony Crumbley, its vice president of research, insists that recent job growth is not as weak as the Labor Department now shows it to be. But ask him about Charlotte's economy and he puts out his hand, holds it flat, then slowly tilts it slightly downward.
"I am a firm believer that nothing goes up forever," Mr. Crumbley said. "And I guess we are at a moment when we are catching our breath."

HEADLINE: Deal Is Reached For Lippo Bank

BYLINE: ByThe New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Indonesian businessman at the center of the controversy over campaign donations to the Democratic Party is selling the California bank that is his main business in the United States.
James T. Riady is selling the Lippo Bank California to Commercial Bank of San Francisco for $15.9 million in cash, the banks said today. 
 Mr. Riady and his family control Lippo Group, an Indonesian conglomerate that like other companies in that country has been hurt by the Asian financial crisis. Many Asian banks are selling, closing or scaling back their operations in the United States.
In a statement issued last month, when his intention to sell the California bank was first announced, Mr. Riady said the Asian crisis meant he could not devote enough attention to the bank in California.
Mr. Riady and his business associates have been major donors to the Democratic Party, and he had ready access to President Clinton, whom he knew from the days when he was a banker in Arkansas and Mr. Clinton was Governor.

HEADLINE: G.M. Signs 10-Year Pact to Buy Aluminum From Alcan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had signed a 10-year agreement to buy aluminum from Alcan Aluminium Ltd., using a complex financial arrangement to shield the giant auto maker from the highly volatile price of aluminum in commodity markets.
The purpose of the arrangement is to keep G.M.'s long-term costs for aluminum close to its production costs. G.M. will pay Alcan roughly the market price for aluminum but is entering into contracts with a group of financial institutions to limit its exposure to price fluctuations, said Alan G. Brown, an Alcan spokesman. 
 G.M. did not disclose the details of its plans other than to say in a statement that it would "stabilize the price of aluminum using third-party financing to manage the pricing risk." Such financial contracts, which are increasingly common in the commodities business, would typically require the financial institutions to pay G.M. when the price of aluminum climbs. But G.M. would be required to pay the financial institutions if the price of aluminum fell unexpectedly.
The agreement was intended to even out G.M.'s aluminum costs over time.
Julie A. Rochman, a spokeswoman for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, a trade group that seeks to reduce insurers' accident claims, said that cars could be built safely with more aluminum parts. "If they are designed properly, there should be no detriment in terms of safety," she said.
For a few raw materials with high and volatile prices, like palladium for catalytic converters, auto makers have traditionally used long-term contracts with mines at prices that stay fairly constant. But the auto industry's biggest suppliers have resisted the risk associated with setting prices far into the future and have limited the duration of their contracts.
The auto makers now buy steel, for example, under contracts that also insulate them from fluctuations in global steel prices. But these contracts never last more than three years, said Nicholas Tolerico, the executive vice president of Thyssen Inc. North America, the American subsidiary of the big German steel and auto parts company.
Aluminum industry contracts had typically been for up to three years until now, too, Mr. Brown said. Because the new contract with G.M. called for payments at close to the market price, "we're satisfied we will make a decent return," he said.
G.M. now buys 1.7 billion pounds of aluminum a year, an average of 210 pounds for every car or truck it produces around the world, and forecast today that it would increase that use by 7 percent or more a year. The price of aluminum typically ranges from 60 to 80 cents a pound but sometimes jumps as high as $1.50 a pound during shortages.
An old rule of thumb in the auto industry, which has held true for a remarkably long time, is that aluminum offers half the weight of steel for twice the cost. Reducing weight is important because lighter vehicles have better fuel economy.
The Big Three are having great difficulty meeting Federal fuel-economy standards for light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks. The domestic auto makers are being forced this year to offer deep discounts on their less heavy models, so that the average fuel economy of their light trucks will meet Federal minimums.
G.M. has had the greatest difficulty this year, with repeated revisions in its production schedules to avoid building too many of the heavier but more profitable models, like the Chevrolet Tahoe and Suburban. The Ford Motor Company has also had trouble, and industry trade journals have recently reported that it plans to start building a mostly aluminum sport utility vehicle in 2002.
There has been no clear consensus among researchers on whether the substitution of aluminum for steel helps or hurts safety. Compared with steel parts, aluminum auto parts can be designed to be stiffer, stronger and have more capacity to absorb energy in a crash, said Jon F. Harmon, a Ford spokesman.

HEADLINE: Kosovo Crisis Strains Relations Between the U.S. and Europe

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 9

 BODY:
When Richard C. Holbrooke reached an agreement last month with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to avert NATO air strikes in Kosovo, the German Government waited two days for a copy of the accord before finally squeezing one out of the Yugoslav Embassy in Bonn.
"It was almost funny, if it was not so worrying," a senior German official said. "There seems to be very little willingness to treat the Europeans on an equal footing. Our impression is sometimes that the Americans prefer to cut us out and that they are no longer capable, intellectually speaking, of being part of a team." 
 As with Bosnia, Kosovo has once again sharpened tensions between the United States and the European Union over security issues, revealing a European incapacity to mount a concerted response to a crisis in Europe without American leadership.
When the Balkan wars began in 1991, the Europeans at least had pretensions to resolving the crisis themselves. The Luxembourg Foreign Minister, Jacques Poos, representing the European Union, uttered the famous phrase, "The hour of Europe has dawned."
But as fighting raged in Kosovo this summer, senior European officials conceded, there was not the first inkling of a coherent European response, even as the continent prepared to take a decisive step toward greater economic union. The vacuum opened the way for Mr. Holbrooke's whirlwind negotiations -- and then deep European misgivings about continuing American domination of security issues in Europe almost a decade after the end of the cold war.
"We get criticized for too little leadership in Europe and then for too much," Mr. Holbrooke said. "The fact is the Europeans are not going to have a common security policy for the foreseeable future. We have done our best to keep them involved. But you can imagine how far I would have got with Mr. Milosevic if I'd said, 'Excuse me, Mr. President, I'll be back in 24 hours after I've talked to the Europeans.' "
Western officials said the Europeans were particularly incensed by Mr. Holbrooke's failure to attend a meeting of the so-called contact group on Oct. 15, two days after the agreement had been reached in Belgrade. It was that group -- made up of Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Russia and the United States -- that formally gave Mr. Holbrooke his mandate to negotiate with the Yugoslav President.
Although Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott attended the meeting, Europeans felt that they had been slighted. Almost a week later Mr. Holbrooke made a special trip to Paris to have dinner with the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, in an effort to make amends.
Europeans were also angry at how the appointment of an American, William Walker, to head the mission to Kosovo of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe had been decided. "We provide two-thirds of the expense and the personnel, and then the appointment is made with almost no consultation," said an official.
At one point, angered by what was seen as a lack of consultation, the top British official in the Foreign Office formally protested to the National Security Council, officials said.
Mr. Holbrooke said the European protests were generally overblown or insignificant expressions of frustration and masked a reality of fruitful cooperation. "It took us four years to put together anything effective in Bosnia and four months in Kosovo," he said. "That is progress."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Christopher S. Wren

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
BELGIUM: FOOD AID FOR RUSSIA -- The European Commission proposed a $480 million package of food aid for Russia to offset shortages that are feared this winter because of the financial crisis and the worst harvest in four decades. The European initiative followed the conclusion of an agreement between the United States and Russia on Friday. (Agence France-Presse) 

RUSSIA: YELTSIN RESTING -- President Boris N. Yeltsin is resting at a country home outside Moscow after returning from vacation on the Black Sea coast. Mr. Yeltsin was recovering from fatigue and high blood pressure, his office said, but still plans to be host to a succession of foreign leaders this month, beginning with the Japanese Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi. (AP)
 
FRANCE: SEEKING DEBT SUSPENSION AS FLOOD AID -- Paris called for a moratorium on international debt owed by Central American countries that were devastated by Hurricane Mitch. President Jacques Chirac plans to meet leaders of Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador in their capitals next week to discuss emergency needs of the countries hit hardest by the disaster, French officials said. Craig R. Whitney (NYT)
 
FRANCE: JOSPIN DEFENDS WORDS ON MUTINY -- Prime Minister Lionel Jospin responded to President Chirac's criticism of his call last week for rehabilitation of the reputations of French soldiers who mutinied in a failed offensive in World War I. "All I did was say some humane, just and necessary things," Mr. Jospin said. He had made his appeal on Thursday at a memorial to 180,000 soldiers killed in an futile attempt in 1917 to break through German lines. Craig R. Whitney (NYT)
 
GERMANY: DEMAND FOR POLICE DOCUMENTS -- Former East German dissidents called on President Clinton to return the archives of the former Stasi secret police, which the United States seized after the fall of Communism. They said the files would help throw light on the huge network of agents. (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
INDIA: BORDER DISPUTE DISCUSSED -- Indian and Pakistani officials met in New Delhi to discuss a settlement of their longstanding boundary dispute over a potentially oil-rich tidal channel, Sir Creek, on their western coasts, but made no progress in reaching a resolution in the fourth day of talks, officials said. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 CHINA: PUSH FOR OPPOSITION PARTY -- Chinese dissidents are planning another attempt to register the nation's first opposition party since Communist rule began in 1949, a Hong Kong-based human rights group said. The dissidents, from 23 provinces, decided at a meeting in Hangzhou to try to proceed with their Chinese Democratic Party, the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said. (Reuters)
 
INDONESIA: MILITARY REORGANIZATION ANNOUNCED -- Gen. Wiranto, the armed forces chief of staff, announced a structural reorganization that would diminish the military's political influence by abolishing the post of Chief of Socio-political Affairs. But the general said the reorganization did not mean that the military was prepared to withdraw from Parliament, where it holds 75 appointed seats. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
AFGHANISTAN: TALIBAN REJECTS U.N. COMPLAINTS -- The Taliban movement dismissed complaints by the United Nations' World Food Program that it had stolen 1,500 tons of food and said the missing grain had been distributed to the needy when it captured the area where the grain was stored. (Reuters)
 
TAJIKISTAN: REBELS WITHDRAW TO MOUNTAINS -- Government troops, left, chased the last large group of rebel fighters into the mountains after five days of fighting in the Central Asian nation. Forty rebels were killed and 10 government soldiers were wounded, a presidential spokesman said. Whereabouts of the rebels leader, Makhmud Khudoberdyev, were unknown, Itar-Tass said. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: TURKISH ATTACK IS DENOUNCED -- Baghdad condemned Turkey for launching a fresh military operation into northern Iraq against Kurdish separatist guerrillas. Turkish officials said troops backed by armor were pursuing guerrillas of the Kurdistan Workers Party deep inside northern Iraq. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA -- ETHIOPIA: BORDER DISPUTE UNSETTLED -- Ethiopia has accepted a peace plan drawn up by the Organization of African Unity to resolve its border conflict with Eritrea, Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin said. But Eritrea has not yet accepted the plan, which includes the deployment of international peacekeepers. (NYT)
 
NAMIBIA: PLANS FOR ANTI-GAY LEGISLATION -- Namibia's Home Affairs Minister Jerry Ekandjo has announced plans to introduce legislation to "curb the spread of homosexuality in society" by imposing heavy penalties, the Mail and Guardian newspaper in Johannesburg reported. While Namibia's Constitution bars discrimination, President Sam Nujoma and others say homosexuality is inimical to African culture. (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: IMMIGRATION CONTROLS TIGHTENED -- Mexico and China signed agreements to tighten control over undocumented Chinese immigrants who pass through Mexican territory into the United States, the Foreign Ministry said. In recent years, smuggling groups have used Mexican territory, especially Baja California, to infiltrate undocumented Chinese into California. (NYT)
 
VENEZUELA: LEFTIST COALITION PREVAILS -- The left-wing coalition of a former coup leader is the strongest force in the new Congress. With 67 percent of the vote on Sunday counted, the Patriotic Pole coalition of Hugo Chavez won 34 percent of the seats. Mr. Chavez, an independent supported by millions of peasants, is favored to win the presidential election on Dec. 6. (AP)

HEADLINE: White House Is Said to Favor a Swift Move Against Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Senior Clinton Administration officials said today that they were leaning toward using force against Iraq sooner rather than later and were making contingency plans about how President Clinton's trip to Asia might be curtailed, or even canceled.
The Pentagon also took the first step to bolster its forces in the region, dispatching another guided-missile cruiser, the Anzio, toward the Persian Gulf, Defense officials said today. Its arrival later this week will increase the number of warships in the region to 14, led by the aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower. More significantly, it will increase to eight the number of vessels -- two cruisers, five destroyers and one submarine -- that can fire Tomahawk cruise missiles. 
 But officials emphasized that Mr. Clinton has not made a decision about using force or when to use it.
As his top national security officials met again today at the White House, the officials quietly debated the virtues of striking Iraq now, while there appears to be international disgust with Saddam Hussein and he maintains a defiant position toward the United Nations.
Mr. Clinton has already delayed his departure for Asia by one day, the White House announced today. Rather than leaving on Friday for a scheduled 10-day trip to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea, Mr. Clinton will leave on Saturday.
His spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said the delay was simply because Mr. Clinton did not want to be in Guam before a Monday runoff in an election there for governor. But other officials were skeptical of Mr. Clinton's sudden reluctance to intervene in party politics, suggesting that the delay is meant to leave more options open for ordering force.
It is important for Mr. Clinton to be in Washington to monitor any use of force and deal with the diplomatic and public fallout, the officials said. Vice President Gore could travel in his place. But the President is eager to go to Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Malaysia and grapple with the issues of Asia's economic troubles. He skipped an APEC meeting once before in 1995, at the time of the Government shutdown, and Asians were hurt and angry.
Mr. Lockhart said it could take a couple of days for Mr. Clinton's national security team to refine the options for the timing of any attack. After some departures over the weekend, some 100 United Nations weapons inspectors remain in Iraq, and they would presumably be withdrawn before force is used.
But no ultimatums will be issued before force is used, and no new negotiating missions to Baghdad are planned by any country, officials said.
Mr. Clinton is described by some officials as reluctant to appear bloodthirsty. "He's not gung-ho; he'd rather not resort to this," one official said. "But there's a feeling that it's the best of bad alternatives."
The options for the use of force revolve around timing -- strike now, while Mr. Hussein continues his defiance, or wait until more American and allies forces can be moved to the gulf to make a strike more forceful.
"If there's going to be one morning-after reaction," one official said, "it's likely to be, 'Gee, we didn't know it would be that big.' "
He and other officials said they were tired of Mr. Hussein's constant challenging of the United Nations and the United States, and his continued defiance, after repeatedly breaking vows to comply with the United Nations and allow arms inspectors unfettered access to sites in Iraq.
Now Mr. Hussein's refusal to cooperate with the inspectors of Unscom is complete, officials said. "This is a first, for Saddam to stiff the U.N. to such an extent," an official said. "We've been through this so many times. Saddam bought himself eight or nine months, but it's time to pay the piper."
Mr. Clinton is also asking what the use of force would accomplish, as precisely as possible, and what will follow any use of force. "The day-after scenario gets dicey, and we may not be coming up with the right answers," another official said.
Any use of force would likely mean the end of the Unscom inspection regime, which Mr. Hussein has not allowed to work for 8 of the last 12 months in any event, officials say. If Mr. Hussein were to attempt to reconstitute nuclear, biological or chemical weapons afterward, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today, "we will act."
But Mr. Rubin and other officials noted that even Mr. Hussein's normal advocates have been silent this time. "What we're hearing around the world is a clear and ringing call on Saddam Hussein to reverse course, from every quarter, from every country," Mr. Rubin said.
The Anzio, which had been stationed in the Adriatic Sea, is expected in the Persian Gulf by the end of the week, but it could be in a position to strike Iraq sooner if Saudi Arabia were to allow the missiles to pass through its airspace.
If the Administration opts for a quick strike, Tomahawk cruise missiles would play a dominant role. Although the Administration significantly reduced its air and naval forces from a peak in February of more than 400 warplanes, it has doubled the number of Tomahawks, to somewhere between 250 and 350.

HEADLINE: Expectation Aside, Water Use in U.S. Is Showing Decline

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
In a little-noticed environmental turnabout, Federal analysts report that Americans' use of water declined by about 9 percent from 1980 to 1995 -- even as the United States' population grew by 16 percent over the same period.
The drop in water use, which came after decades of steady increase, is attributed by experts largely to a gradual shift in focus away from finding ways to capture more water -- building dams, for instance -- and toward devising ways of using it more efficiently once obtained. 
The recent disclosure of the decline, by the United States Geological Survey, runs contrary to a deeply seated conventional belief, namely that water use inevitably rises along with economic and population growth and that priority must therefore be given to opening up new sources.
But now, agriculture and industry, especially, have become more frugal in using water. As a result, some experts say, the once-solid linkage between water and growth may have been broken.
"The data are showing a fundamental change in the way we're using and thinking about water," said Dr. Peter H. Gleick, director of the Pacific Institute for Studies in Development, an environmental research organization in Oakland, Calif. Dr. Gleick is also the author of a new study, "The World's Water" (Island Press).
Whether the decline in water use will continue is unclear. Most of the drop occurred in the 1980's, with a decline of only 2 percent reported from 1990 to 1995, the latest year for which numbers are available. Moreover, the numbers are estimates and therefore subject to some error. Nevertheless, the experts say, it seems clear that a steady, century-long upward trend in the use of water has at least been halted.
"We feel pretty confident in saying that things have stabilized over the last 15 to 20 years," said Wayne B. Solley, a hydrologist at the geological survey's main office in Reston, Va. He is the lead author of the agency's report, released last month.
The decline in water use is especially striking when measured against population growth. The use of water per person declined, on average, by about 20 percent from 1980, the all-time peak year, to 1995, Dr. Gleick said. The demand for water is shrinking in Europe as well, he said.
Sandra Postel, director of the Global Water Policy Project, a research group in Amherst, Mass., said, "Globally, we're seeing a big slowdown in the expansion of irrigation."
But population pressures and rapid industrialization are expected to put increasing pressure on the water supply in some developing countries, and Ms. Postel said its inefficient use might eventually cause these countries to "bump up against limits" of the supply.
On the other hand, Dr. Gleick said, developing countries might be able to exploit the gains the United States has made in water efficiency and skip the United States' early stage of water profligacy.
"Their steel industry will never use as much water as our old steel industries used," he said.
In the first eight decades of this century, as the American economy went through its biggest burst of industrial development, the growth in the use of water was continuous, outstripping population growth by about 5 to 2. Expansion of irrigation, industry and electrical power generation accounted for most of the increase. Then, the experts say, a number of factors combined to reverse the trend. The best sites for dams (the main means of gathering water for use) had been taken, and building new ones became ever more expensive. Widespread concern about the negative environmental effects of dams added to the pressure against building new ones. In the case of industry, it became less expensive to recycle water than to remove pollutants from it and return it to the stream, as required by Federal law. And industrial expansion itself slowed down.
In the West, where most of the United States' irrigated land lies and water is scarce relative to the rest of the country, the prospect of shortages, the steady depletion of water under the ground and rising pumping costs prompted users to seek better efficiency in using water.
Western farmers, for example, have increasingly abandoned irrigation systems consisting of long, rotating sprayer arms that waste water by projecting it high into the air, where much is lost to wind and evaporation. In their place are systems that use less water by applying it directly to the root systems of plants. As a result of this and other efficiency gains, the average amount of water used per acre of irrigated land fell by 16 percent from 1980 to 1995. The amount of land under irrigation has remained about constant.
Likewise, the recycling of water and conservation measures, along with new technologies, reduced the industrial use of water by 35 percent, to the lowest level -- 29 billion gallons a day -- since record keeping began in 1950. This amount does not include water used for cooling power plants, both nuclear and those powered by fossil fuels like coal. Water used for that purpose -- the biggest single category of use, at 190 billion gallons a day in 1995 -- fell by nearly 5 percent in the 1980's and has remained about stable for several years.
The amount of water used for domestic purposes, both inside and outside the home, increased sharply in the 1960's and 1970's as the size of houses grew, along with the number of bathrooms, and homes were stocked with more water-using appliances. Since then, Mr. Solley said, the domestic use of water has stabilized at about 100 gallons per person per day as more water-efficient dishwashers, clothes washers and toilets have been installed. Even so, domestic use increased as a share of the total, rising to 12 percent in 1995 from 10 percent in 1985.
The use of the public water -- water withdrawn from natural sources by suppliers and conveyed to users rather than withdrawn directly by users like farmers and factories -- is one of two categories in which the use has continued to increase. It grew by 18 percent from 1980 to 1995. But because of greater efficiencies, the per-person use in this category has stabilized at about 180 gallons a day.
The amount of water used by livestock and rural households has risen 58 percent since 1980. Much of the jump is attributed to growth in the raising of fish, fur-bearing animals, horses and pets.
Most water is returned to rivers and streams after being used. Consumption of the rest by people, animals and crops dropped by almost 8 percent from 1980 to 1985 but has since rebounded to its 1980 level.
All of these categories apply to water withdrawn from its natural location, or off-stream use. It is this overall category that declined by about 9 percent, to 402 billion gallons in 1995, from 440 billion gallons a day in 1980. Far more water is used without being removed from the source, by hydroelectric power generators. This type of use declined by about 4 percent from 1980 to 1995.
Among regions of the country, the area designated by the geological agency as the Northeastern quadrant (basically, the Midwest, Northeast and Middle Atlantic region) led in the overall drop in off-stream use with a decline of about 17 percent from 1980 and 1995. The decline was nearly 5 percent in 17 states in the Great Plains and West, and nearly 3 percent in the Southeast.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Pataki's Luck On the Road To Triumph

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Successful politicians make their own luck, and on that score, give Gov. George E. Pataki his due. He did what he promised -- cut taxes and reinstated the death penalty -- and he has shown a knack for taking advantage of what fate and Wall Street have handed him.
Some are luckier than others, though, and this Governor must rank near the top. Any incumbent politician is blessed to run for re-election in such affluent and placid times, but even measured against such company, Mr. Pataki has been particularly lucky. 
 Factors beyond his control have contributed to the broad popularity that carried him to a second term in last Tuesday's election, in a year that proved unkind to so many other Republicans. The economic boom has been louder, the drop in crime more dramatic, the decline in welfare rolls more astonishing in New York than in other parts of the country.
"He's adapted well to his circumstances," said Gerald Benjamin, dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the State University at New Paltz, who closely watches state government. "But there's no question he's been very fortunate."
Since 1994, the year Mr. Pataki was first elected Governor, the national economic expansion has been accompanied by an impressive rise in the financial markets that has not only made many New Yorkers wealthier but has also transformed state government.
How? New York traditionally relies heavily on its personal income tax. Mr. Pataki kept his promise and cut income tax rates 25 percent, yet thanks to the Wall Street run-up, the tax generates more money for the state than when he was elected.
What that means in Albany is that the budget cuts Mr. Pataki imposed to pay for his tax cuts have been reversed, and then some. He piled new tax cuts on the old ones, while raising spending on popular causes like education and the environment. Not a bad platform for re-election.
Though it would surely gall him to hear it, it has also been Mr. Pataki's good fortune to govern while his sometime ally, Rudolph W. Giuliani has been New York City's Mayor. Mr. Pataki crisscrossed the state this year boasting of falling crime, but experts contend that he was taking credit for changes due more to City Hall's actions than to Albany's.
Serious crime has been in decline in New York since the early 1990's, before either man took office, part of a national trend that criminologists attribute to several factors, ranging from demographic changes to an improving economy.
But since 1994, the drop in New York City has been much steeper than in most other cities. That was the year that Mr. Giuliani took office and that he and his first Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton, transformed police tactics -- another factor the experts cite. That was a year before Mr. Pataki became Governor. Since the decline began, about 85 percent of the drop in serious crime statewide has been in the city; in many upstate counties, it has actually risen in the last few years.
"The state has done a good job, built the prisons, toughened parole, set the right tone," said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private organization. But, he added, "the connection between what a state does and crime on the streets, over the short run, is pretty weak."
Mr. Pataki also takes credit, with reason, for the state's shrinking welfare rolls. He increased enforcement of child-support orders, moving thousands of families off welfare. He also made it easier for local governments to insist on workfare and screen out applicants, though such moves were overtaken by the 1996 Federal welfare law.
But the number of people on welfare in New York began to fall just as Mr. Pataki took office in 1995, before he had a chance to influence it, a coincidence due most likely to the growing economy.
Again, Mr. Giuliani's role cannot be underestimated. Most of New York's welfare recipients live in the city, and the Mayor, more than his counterparts around the state, has taken advantage of new rules on work and eligibility to reduce the rolls, so the statewide decline in the number of welfare recipients mostly reflects changes in the city.
All of which gives one pause to wonder what happens when the economy fizzles. Do the tax cut bills come due, without enough revenue pouring in to pay for them? Do the welfare rolls grow again? What happens when crime begins to rise again? Does Mr. Pataki's luck run out? And what if it does as he pursues national office?
"Presuming there will be another economic downturn someday, there is a real political risk to him," Mr. Benjamin, the university dean, said. "But he's surprised me before. I wouldn't sell him short."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Federal Express Pilots Move Closer to a Strike
Pilots at Federal Express began refusing to fly overtime and their union mailed strike authorization ballots, increasing the odds that the world's largest air freight service could be crippled during the peak season between Thanksgiving and Christmas. 
 The 3,200 members of the Federal Express Pilots Association will cast ballots over the next three weeks. If more than two-thirds vote in favor of granting the union's leadership permission to call a walkout, the strike could begin after Dec. 3. Page C4.
 
Dow Corning's Bankruptcy Plan
Dow Corning filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan that included $3.2 billion to settle claims from women over its silicone breast implants and $1.3 billion in payments to commercial creditors. C8.
 
Slower Economy Seen in Argentina
In the first concrete sign that recession in Brazil may be slowing Argentina's economy, leading auto makers have temporarily idled plants and are reporting a drop in car sales. Argentina has been one of the strongest economic performers in Latin America this year, but Roque Fernandez, the Economy Minister, said recently that economic growth would be virtually flat in the second half of this year. C7.
 
Intel Says Microsoft Made Threats
Microsoft repeatedly threatened Intel, its key ally in the computer industry, as part of the software giant's campaign to stifle the challenge to its business posed by the rise of the Internet, an Intel executive testified. C2.
 
GPU to Sell 23 Power Plants
GPU, which owns utilities serving large parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey, announced the sale of 23 power plants to Sithe Energies, a major independent power producer and affiliate of Vivendi of France, for $1.68 billion. C6.
 
G.M. Reaches Deal for Aluminum
General Motors announced that it had signed a 10-year agreement to buy aluminum from Alcan Aluminium, using a complex financial arrangement to shield the giant auto maker from the volatile price of aluminum. C14.
 
Another Citigroup Departure
Steven D. Black has resigned his position as a vice chairman of the Salomon Smith Barney, a departure that points to continued disarray in the executive suite at the Citigroup unit. C15.
 
J. P. Morgan to Cut 740 Jobs
J. P. Morgan, squeezed by global financial turmoil, will cut its work force by 740 people by the end of the year. C8.
 
Clinical Trials Bolster Centocor
Shares of Centocor rose more than 9 percent after researchers at separate medical conferences reported positive outcomes from clinical trials of the company's two major drugs: Remicade, which Centocor hopes to sell to treat rheumatoid arthritis, and Reopro, which researchers said could reduce the risk of death in patients whose coronary arteries have been surgically opened. C14.
 
Two Are Accused of Stock Fraud
Two people affiliated with Sterling Foster & Company, a defunct brokerage firm, were indicted on charges of cheating investors out of $100 million by manipulating the prices of stocks the firm underwrote and sold. Three others have pleaded guilty in the case. C15.
 
Hershey Seeks Buyer for Pasta Unit
Saying it wants to stick to making candy, Hershey Foods is shopping for a buyer for its pasta business, which includes the Ronzoni, San Giorgio and Mrs. Weiss brands. C10.
 
Lippo Bank California to Be Sold
James T. Riady, the Indonesian businessman at the center of the controversy over campaign donations to the Democratic Party, is selling Lippo Bank California to Commercial Bank of San Francisco for $15.9 million. C7.

HEADLINE: East 40, West 40, All Around the Farm;
High School Agriculture Program Thrives in the Heart of Queens

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
Walk up the steps of John Bowne High School one chilly fall morning and you'll find a familiar tableau: school safety officers roving the grounds, portable classrooms parked out back, teen-age boys and girls with their bulky parkas and fuzzy dreams about the future.
But walk on ahead, past the narrow path lined with purple ageratum, and the picture changes: a crimson barn with 150 squawking, egg-laying hens; a girl with a safety pin pierced through her ear learning to groom a calf; a four-acre farm brimming with collard greens and green beans and sunflowers with their mammoth faces turned to the ground. 
 Here on Main Street in Flushing, Queens, next to the Long Island Expressway and down the road from a bustling corridor of halal butcher shops and Taiwanese bakeries, lies the largest agricultural science program of any high school in the state. Here, nearly 600 students learn to tend an orchard of peaches and apples. They look after a roomful of snakes and birds native to the jungles of India and Brazil. And they dig into the ground with their spading forks every summer so that tiny green seedlings can grow into beefy tomatoes and sweet red peppers by fall.
For many of the students, who come from throughout the city, it is their first time growing anything. And in the spring, when weeds had to be yanked and the soil prepared for planting, there was considerable skepticism in the air.
"At first, I thought it wasn't going to go anywhere," confessed Laura Fragoso, a John Bowne sophomore who grew up in an apartment house in Flushing. "I didn't think it was possible until it started growing."
On July 20 -- she remembers it clearly -- the first tiny green tomatoes appeared. Soon, the vines began to spill over, and she had to hold them in with thin wire cages. By summer's end, her doubts had been washed over by a bountiful harvest, the last of which she washed and set aside the other day: cherry tomatoes, shiny round eggplant, fat stalks of broccoli.
Established in 1917, when there were family farms on much of Queens and Long Island, John Bowne's agriculture program once trained young people mostly for on-the-farm jobs. But these days, farming isn't exactly a booming niche in the metropolitan region's economy, or beyond, for that matter: over the last several decades, family farms have closed nationwide and the number of jobs has declined. Moreover, new citywide high school graduation requirements have compelled vocational programs like this one to prepare their students to pass a battery of college-prep Regents examinations.
So, John Bowne has had to reinvent itself in recent years to adapt to the changed industry, offering courses in landscaping and creating animal labs to teach students how to care for exotic snakes and iguanas.
"Our kids are not really thinking farming," said Steven Perry, the assistant principal in charge of the program. "They're looking to enter plant and animal careers that aren't rural-based."
Approximately three-fourths of the graduates go on to college, with some continuing their studies in agricultural fields, Mr. Perry said. A perennial favorite of the graduates continues to be veterinary school, while others major in marine biology and plant science. Other graduates go on to work in nurseries, fish farms and landscape design businesses in and around the city, Mr. Perry said.
"Are 100 percent of these kids die-hard aggies?" he offered. "No. I'd be lying to you."
Yet there still are a handful of graduates who want to leave the bustle of the city to live and work on a farm upstate. And for students like Ana Huerta, 14, the school has also provided a family tie. The small, quick-talking girl from Corona, Queens, had only seen pictures of her grandfather's big, beautiful garden in Mexico. But over the summer, Ana got her own taste of growing a real garden -- eggplant and basil and green beans, bordered by a bed of daisies and sunflowers.
"My parents were really surprised that I grew stuff," said Ana, who is now considering a career in horticulture or, maybe, going to veterinary school -- though her father wants her to eventually take over the family flower shop in Corona. "Most of the stuff I took home from here -- they looked better than what they buy at the store. They tasted better too."
Although less than 2 percent of American workers are employed directly on farms, Federal economists say that agriculture continues to be an important source of employment. Today, compared with 25 years ago, agricultural workers include more gardeners, both commercial and residential, and animal caretakers -- those working in horse riding stables, for instance.
Wages for the most abundant agricultural jobs remain paltry. Farmworkers -- who have recently been in such high demand that Federal lawmakers proposed a bill to import guest workers from outside the country -- earn on average $273 a week, while gardeners bring in $298, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics; a bartender, by comparison, earns $312 weekly.
The decline in on-the-farm jobs has led John Bowne to expand its course offerings to include landscaping and design, where students learn how to fashion and maintain a garden, as well as to build trendy accouterments like gazebos.
"This is the flavor of the week," Mr. Perry said, pointing to one that this year's class recently constructed. "Gazebos are big time now."
Mr. Perry says he is also trying to look ahead. In the spring, for the first time, his students will raise fish in a 400-gallon tank and grow hydroponic lettuce in nutrient-filled cups of water instead of in soil. Fish hatcheries, Mr. Perry said, are booming in the nearby suburbs, and the hydroponic crops are already the rage at fancy Manhattan health food stores. There are plans to build an aviary in the near future.
At the same time, the makeup of the school's student body has changed.
Its more than 3,600 students comprise a mix of youngsters from the world over -- a fact that became apparent when a small white bean from Latin America showed up on the school farm. Teachers had never seen such a bean before. Most likely, said Mr. Perry, it came from a student's pantry at home.
Today, nearly half of John Bowne's students are Hispanic; about 25 percent are Asian, 20 percent are black, and less than 10 percent are white. Nearly a third have limited English skills. The demographics of the students in the agriculture program, Mr. Perry said, roughly mirror those of the overall student body.
To accommodate the diverse student body, the school offers, among other things, a plant science class for students whose English is limited. One classroom is also stuffed with the so-called "exotic" animals that are all the rage among the teen-agers -- among them, a tortoise with amber-colored spots on its back, a Goffins cockatoo that performs stunts in its cage, and an iguana named Lucifer that demands to be fed by hand every day.
Like all high school students citywide, students here must take the standard math, English and social science courses. Students in this program are also required to choose to major in either animal or plant science. They must work on the school farm the summer before their sophomore year. What they grow on their own small plots they take home; the rest, including the eggs laid in the barn, is sold at a farmstand on Main Street in the summertime and at school in the fall.
But if many of John Bowne's students have never before gotten their hands dirty tilling the earth or sweeping a barn, some are only a couple of generations removed from the country life.
There is the soft-spoken young man from Jamaica, Queens, who remembers riding horses on his grandfather's farm in Mississippi, and another, from Kew Gardens, whose grandfather lived on a farm in Ecuador.
Another classmate, Shaheim Kallum, 15, of Bushwick, recalled his mother's amazement at the stories he tells of his days at school, about cleaning the chicken coops and weeding.
Shaheim, also a sophomore, said he now was thinking of becoming a veterinarian. The idea came from his uncle, who is alsoone. But the program at John Bowne exposed him to the flesh and blood of the trade. "It puts you on the field of life," he said.

HEADLINE: THE SPEAKER STEPS DOWN: MAN IN THE NEWS;
A Classic Republican: Robert Linlithgow Livingston

BYLINE: BY KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The man who would be Speaker is in many ways a classic Republican. He is a hawk on defense. He is an advocate for business, especially the oil and gas industries in his home district in Louisiana. He opposes abortion. His formative political years were spent reading Ayn Rand and George Orwell.
And he is no softie. He has a black belt in karate. His temper has flared openly on the House floor and in private behind closed doors -- anywhere he decides to dig in his heels, Bob Livingston can suddenly shout, turn red and flail his arms as if trying to take flight. 
 But friends and adversaries alike say these outbursts are usually done for effect, and when they are over he will catch someone's eye and laugh. In any case, he now promises to keep his cool.
Representative Robert Linlithgow Livingston, 55, a lanky Louisianan with an aristocratic New York pedigree, is the presumptive Speaker of the House, second in line to the Presidency after the Vice President. He secured the position unofficially today after a monthslong campaign in which he doled out thousands of dollars to fellow House Republicans and, over the last week, commanded a five-day panzerlike roll across his potential rivals, including the current Speaker and his longtime friend, Newt Gingrich.
Mr. Livingston is expected to be picked by his fellow Republicans in a secret ballot on Nov. 18. Then the entire House is to vote for Speaker in January, a vote that normally runs along party lines and will almost certainly propel Mr. Livingston into the top spot. He is presenting himself as a calming influence in the House, a day-to-day manager and a reassuring figure of stability after a wild ride under Mr. Gingrich and two elections in which Republicans have lost seats.
Members of both parties said today that Mr. Livingston's taking over the helm would probably have little effect on the Republican policies that have emerged over the last four years but that he would put less emphasis on the social issues pushed by the hard-core right. They said the biggest change, at least initially, would be to take the sting out of the fierce partisanship that developed under Mr. Gingrich.
"He will have pretty much the same agenda that Newt had," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, which Mr. Livingston heads. "You will still have a pro-big business, very much pro-oil industry party, and it is still very much a Southern-led party."
But, Mr. Obey added, "the main difference is that Livingston is an institutional man and Gingrich was an anti-institutional man. Gingrich was willing to turn the institution into a snake pit in order to take power and hold power. This place will become much less cannibalistic and much less of a snake pit."
Some conservatives worry that Mr. Livingston will prove too conciliatory to Democrats. Some worry that, as a manager, he will be too narrowly focused on the details of the budget and forgo the role of inspirational leader.
To Mr. Livingston, this is a virtue.
"The big picture is easy," he once said. "Anybody could sit around and direct the big picture. But where the second-guessing occurs and you get your problems are on the hundreds and perhaps thousands of little issues that can develop all of a sudden into a big issue and hang up your bill."
When he announced his candidacy for Speaker on Friday, he promised a devotion to day-to-day governing. With a mere six-vote majority, he has played down expectations about what he can accomplish.
"If we aren't realistic about those goals," he said on Friday, "we will not achieve them."
Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican and one of Mr. Livingston's top lieutenants, said: "He will insist on getting the budget out. There is more of an understanding among Republicans now that four years of pushing a social agenda has not succeeded in expanding our majority."
With Mr. Livingston's respect for the institution of the House, his supporters say he plans few internal changes, except for making members work longer weeks.
Mr. Livingston also likes to convey a sense of being in control, occasionally resorting to theatrics like wielding a machete to show he is a budget cutter. As Appropriations chairman, he had a habit of standing up throughout his committee meetings.
"When he's running the committee," said a Republican, "he likes to see the whole terrain."
At 6 feet 4 1/2 inches, Mr. Livingston has an imposing bearing. He is descended from New York's Livingstons, who once owned a million acres in the Hudson Valley. The family patriarch, Robert R. Livingston, swore in George Washington as President and helped negotiate the Louisiana Purchase; Philip Livingston signed the Declaration of Independence.
The family fortune was wiped out in the Depression. His father was an alcoholic, who divorced his mother when Bob was 7. His mother supported Bob and his sister working at the Avondale Shipyards. In an interview earlier this year, Mr. Livingston said that the lesson he took from his father was this: "I wanted to do better than he did."
The question facing Mr. Livingston is whether he can keep control of the House. John Maginnis, a longtime Livingston watcher and editor of The Louisiana Political Fax Weekly, said Mr. Livingston sometimes faltered at crucial times.
"When it comes down to being able to rise to the moment, he sometimes hasn't been very good," Mr. Maginnis said, recalling Mr. Livingston's failed bid for governor a decade ago in which his verbal stumbling in a debate doomed his candidacy. "He's shown now that he can handle pressure, but the question is whether he can handle the pressure and the national spotlight."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Mets Leave Options Open on General Manager

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla., Nov. 9

 BODY:
Saying that extramarital affairs are not necessarily a reason to fire a general manager, the Mets' admittedly disheartened owners nevertheless left open the possibility that Steve Phillips would not return from his leave of absence to resume his role as the team's No. 1 baseball executive.
The Mets announced on Sunday night that Phillips was taking temporary leave to deal with an allegation of sexual harassment by a former employee, and to attend to family matters following a series of other consensual sexual relationships that Phillips acknowledged having. 
 In a conference call with reporters today, neither of the co-owners, Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday, spoke of when Phillips would return, but rather if he would. And they acknowledged that they held executives to a higher standard than players. At one point, Wilpon talked about "when Steve gets back, or some other action is taken if Steve can't come back."
Doubleday said, "The sooner this problem is resolved one way or another, the better off the whole organization is."
Nevertheless, Wilpon said, the organization had not concluded that infidelity warrants a termination. "We do not believe that his admission of a consensual relationship of short-lived duration with a woman is reason to say that he cannot carry out his responsibilities with the Mets," he said.
An official in the Mets' organization and a high-ranking executive of another team said they did not believe Phillips would be taken back. Speaking on the condition of anonymity, both people said they based their views on what they knew of the situation.
Wilpon and Doubleday discussed the development in a wide-ranging question-and-answer session with reporters as Frank Cashen, the reluctant interim general manager, began leading Phillips's staff in business-as-usual talks with other clubs at the general managers' meetings here and with representatives of free agents by telephone. The owners, who on Sunday issued only a brief statement on Phillips's situation, confronted the matter directly and expansively today.
The allegation of sexual harassment against Phillips and the general manager's marital infidelity were particularly difficult for them, they said, because they thought they had succeeded in eradicating an image created by a series of player incidents in the last decade.
"Both Nelson and I said that we don't condone this kind of infidelity; we think it's wrong," Wilpon said.
Speaking of Cashen's willingness to serve on an interim basis, Wilpon said: "He said he'll do it, but he said, 'I want to get back as soon as I can.' We see this as a short duration. Either Steve is going to be able to pull this together, or if he can't, Nelson and I and the board will have to make another decision."
Wilpon said he could not put a time on Cashen's interim term, "but I don't believe it's months. I don't think we'll be going into spring training without this being resolved."
If the Mets decide to seek a new general manager, two veteran executives are unemployed. Fred Claire was dismissed as the Dodgers' general manager last season, and Pat Gillick left the Orioles at the end of the season.
The organization has suffered from a wide variety of embarrassing incidents. In spring training in 1992, Dwight Gooden, Vince Coleman and Daryl Boston were named in a rape complaint filed by a woman from New York City, but they were never charged. In spring training this year, four minor leaguers were arrested on sexual battery charges involving a gang-rape of a 17-year-old woman. Three were recently convicted, and their lawyers have filed motions for the verdict to be overturned. In 1993, Coleman threw a large firecracker in the parking lot at Dodgers Stadium, injuring bystanders. The same year, Bret Saberhagen was involved in an incident in which he sprayed bleach on reporters.
"It hurts; it's not what we like," Doubleday said about the new problem. "But Steve's a good guy and we're going try to work our way through it."
Asked why Omar Minaya, the assistant general manager, was not elevated to the interim job, Wilpon said: "It would have been awkward for him to take over. I think it would have given the message of a fait accompli. Nelson and I did not want to do that. We wanted to give every chance for Steve to come back."
Phillips and the Mets decided he should take a leave of absence while he gets counseling and tries to work out his problems with his wife, Marni. The Mets became aware of Phillips's situation when a lawyer for a former Mets employee at their complex in Port St. Lucie, Fla., advised Phillips in a letter that the woman was considering suing him and the club for sexual harassment.
The letter was shared with David Howard, the Mets' vice president for legal affairs, and one other in-house lawyer. Howard then talked with Phillips and called Wilpon on the night of Oct. 28.
The owners met with Phillips the next morning at Wilpon's home. Phillips told them about what he said was a consensual sexual relationship with the former employee, as well as other affairs he said he had had.
The Mets concluded after an investigation that there had been no sexual harassment. A Mets official said tonight that the investigation was conducted by a group of lawyers inside and outside the organization. The official would not say whether private investigators were used or whether the woman was questioned.
During the conference call, Wilpon was asked why Phillips had included his admission of other affairs in the statement he issued on Sunday.
"Just to be forthcoming and honest as he has been with Nelson and me," Wilpon said. "He didn't want to leave that out and then have a call like this and have someone ask the question. He and Marni, his wife, felt it was necessary."

HEADLINE: PLUS: PRO BASKETBALL;
Quick Settlement To Dispute Unlikely

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
With no negotiations scheduled and neither the National Basketball Association nor the players union budging, the chance of ending the stalemate and putting a starting date on the season this week seem extremely remote.
 More about the N.B.A.'s labor dispute will be known when 20 to 30 players convene in Manhattan tomorrow. The players, who compose the union's negotiating committee, and several team player representatives will decide whether to submit a new proposal to the owners and whether to have a full bargaining session later in the week. 
 Since halting talks indefinitely last Friday, the two sides have been politicking on behalf of their proposals.
 Billy Hunter, the union's executive director, was angered last week by the owners' move to tell players directly about the league's latest plan. Hunter said efforts were under way in Boston, Cleveland, Miami and Milwaukee to get players to support the N.B.A.'s plan. The union added Charlotte, Detroit, Orlando and the Nets to the list yesterday.
 The union will spend the next few days talking to players to keep them abreast of developments.
 The two sides are far apart on several key economic issues, including an escrow plan and total revenue distribution. The players have proposed a 60-40 division of basketball-related income; the owners have countered with a 50-50 share. More than 57 percent of revenue last season went to player salaries, a figure that prompted the reopening of the old labor agreement. MIKE WISE
