HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
From Senatorial Politics, a Passage to India

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
IF her husband had not decided to announce his retirement from the United States Senate last Friday, Elizabeth B. Moynihan would have been in the Bronx that very day, indulging one of her greatest passions. She has been overseeing a major archeological project near the Taj Mahal in India, and one of her colleagues, a paleobotanist at the New York Botanical Garden, had just returned from there with some new slides of the project site.
But as she has so many times over the decades, she deferred her own plans for just a bit, making room for the inevitable intrusion of politics. 
 "It's the story of my life," she said.
Of course, this was a rather special announcement, one that guaranteed that future intrusions would be minimal. Beginning in 2001, her husband, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, would no longer reign as the leading intellectual of the Senate, a guiding light on any discussion of welfare reform, tax policy or immigration. And she would no longer have to serve as his campaign manager, setting aside her monographs on architectural history to preside over some of the most Spartan and wily campaigns for a Senate seat in modern history.
But the time had come, she said on Tuesday, sitting in the couple's grand apartment in Washington, halfway between the Capitol and the White House. Shaking her head of luminous white hair in disgust at the malevolence and expense that now define Senate campaigns, she said she told her husband four years ago that she was leaving politics, and his decision to do the same followed inexorably.
"I was not going to run another campaign," she said. "I'm running out of time. I'm 69, and there's a limited amount of time I can go turning over rocks in the desert, you know, especially with arthritis. And there are things I have to write, and I'm crazy about my grandchildren. As it is, we're lucky to have survived this long with our style of politics."
That style, utterly anachronistic in its straightforward, high-minded, nonviolent way, is as much a reflection of Liz Moynihan's personality as of her husband's. The idea of broadcasting an attack ad against an opponent, or hiring a focus group to guide the Senator's policy positions, was simply unthinkable to her. The campaigns never raised much money, and her ads simply talked about what Mr. Moynihan had done.
Of course, it helped that he almost never had a serious opponent, Democrat or Republican. But that was part of her strategy, too -- psyching out potential opponents with early television ads that convinced them Mr. Moynihan was unbeatable. That left more time for architecture.
"The plan to every campaign was always the same: how not to have a campaign," said Mandy Grunwald, the political consultant who advised the Moynihans during three campaigns and is an old friend of the family. "In 1988, she told me they couldn't have a campaign because Pat needed to work on welfare reform. And after Rudy Giuliani backed out, we didn't have one."
THESE minimalist, martial-arts campaigns didn't mean she disliked politics; quite the opposite, in fact. "Every six years, she would drop what she was doing, get through this little business, and do it quite happily and quite well," Mr. Moynihan said. "And then she would get back to India."
In her range of interests, in the steel of her intellect, Elizabeth Moynihan is just as remarkable and singular a character as her husband. It's rare enough for a spouse to run four successful campaigns in a state the size of New York while disdaining the cocktail parties and superficiality of the Washington social scene. It is rarer still for that spouse's abiding interest to be half a world away, in the Mogul gardens of India, the graceful, ruined landscapes of the 16th-century Muslim conquerors on which she has become an acknowledged, self-trained expert. In 1978, following her husband's three-year posting as Ambassador to India, she deduced the location of one of the most elaborate gardens by studying the memoirs of the Emperor Babur, and proceeded to dig it up, to the astonishment of Indian archeologists. She has since written extensively on the subject, and is now overseeing another major project.
Her interest began in 1966 after she heard an architectural historian lecture at Harvard, where her husband was teaching. She herself had dropped out of Boston University years before after running out of money, having been raised by her divorced mother in Cohasset, Mass. Her earlier interest had been in politics, particularly in the work of Adlai E. Stevenson, and after meeting a not-dissimilar political intellectual during W. Averell Harriman's 1954 campaign for governor of New York, she married Pat Moynihan a year later.
The couple, who have three grown children, are deeply entwined but hardly inseparable. She stays away from most legislative issues, often flying off to India on her own or with colleagues. (She did, however, play a crucial role in helping to pass President Clinton's economic plan in 1993, urging the wavering Senator Bob Kerrey to support the plan in a 50-50 vote.) But they revel in each other's successes.
"I think I've helped him, and that makes me feel great," she said. "But we are not a twofer. The people of New York never elected the two of us. After an election, I disappear, and spend a lot of time with Babur." Soon, she says, the two men in her life will each get a great deal more attention.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elizabeth Moynihan will be freer when her husband leaves the Senate. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Medical Concern Job Cuts

BYLINE: Dow Jones

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Molecular Biosystems Inc., a developer of ultrasound contrast agents for diagnostic imaging, will cut 40 jobs, or more than 28 percent of its work force, in an effort to save $5 million a year. Molecular Biosystems, based in San Diego, said it expected to make further cuts as it hires outside companies for various manufacturing operations. The company said it did not plan to eliminate positions critical to the introduction of its flagship cardiac ultrasound imaging agent, Optison.

HEADLINE: Germany and U.S. Nurture Bond At a Mansion With a Few Ghosts

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Private pain and public hopes came together in a Berlin mansion last week when the new American Academy was opened on a site marked by Nazi terror and now dedicated to the trans-Atlantic partnership that raised Germany from the ruins of war.
Speaking at what was once the lakeside house of a prominent Jewish banking family, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger described Hitler's rule as "an aberration, but not an organic aspect of German society" and said the academy's existence showed how the wounds of "the 12-year interregnum" could be overcome. 
Much of the founding grant for the academy was provided by the descendants of Hans Arnhold, a Jewish banker who fled the mansion before it became the wartime home of Hitler's chief economic adviser, Walther Funk, and later a recreation center for Americans stationed on the cold war's eastern frontier.
Richard von Weizsacker, the former German President, called the Arnhold family's endowment of the academy an act of "unbelievable magnanimity," dedicated to overcoming "the evil of the past" through "a generous gift for the future."
Behind Mr. von Weizsacker, sailboats passed on the waters of the Wannsee lake, on whose banks stands another villa where the destruction of European Jewry was decided by Nazi bureaucrats on Jan. 20, 1942, a decision later described by Adolph Eichmann as "the final solution of the Jewish question."
The Arnhold family escaped, but as she recalled the lost places of her childhood, Anna-Maria Kellen, Mr. Arnhold's daughter and now a New York philanthropist, battled her emotions. The staircase where she once played was gone, she said, but not her hope that the mansion would now be a "staircase leading to higher levels of understanding and closer degree of cooperation."
The academy was conceived four years ago as a symbol of enduring American commitment to Germany after the end of the cold war, a demonstration that even in the absence of a common enemy a relationship at the heart of the NATO alliance would not be allowed to erode.
But Mr. Kissinger, an honorary chairman of the academy, and Michael Naumann, the chief cultural official in Germany's new Social Democratic Government, both expressed concerns about the state of German-American relations.
"A new generation of German and American leaders must redefine the creative purpose of this period," Mr. Kissinger said. "America and Europe no longer have clearly defined common paths."
Mr. Naumann, a former chief executive of the publisher Henry Holt in New York, lamented a loss of "Germany's political importance in the United States" and said he detected the "quiet emergence of a cultural anti-Americanism" in Europe driven by negative reaction to ubiquitous American television and the effects on incredulous Europeans of the Clinton sex scandal.
By holding seminars and by awarding fellowships to American, German and central European scholars in the fields of the arts and humanities, the academy aims to promote understanding between Germany and the United States.
While Richard C. Holbrooke, chairman of the academy, talked of Mr. Funk and the Nazis, who built a bunker in the basement of the house, a sudden gust blew in from the Wannsee. It forced open the glass door behind Mr. Holbrooke and sent a sudden rush of cold air through the house. "The ghost of our former occupants," Mr. Holbrooke said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Orders Inspectors and Relief Staff Out of Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
After a warning from the United States that a military strike on Baghdad may be imminent, the United Nations abruptly evacuated more than 230 foreign staff members from Iraq today, including all weapons inspectors. Another 41 people from various agencies will depart on Thursday, leaving only essential staff members behind.
Russia, angry that there had been no consultation with all Security Council members before a decision was made to withdraw the arms inspectors, called a meeting of the Council today to demand an explanation from the chief inspector, Richard Butler. 
 But Mr. Butler was not questioned as expected, diplomats said after the closed meeting, which instead focussed on more general concerns about safety of United Nations workers. The Council also discussed how it might persuade Iraq to rescind its ban on inspections.
Secretary General Kofi Annan -- who went to Baghdad in February and persuaded Iraq to back down in the face of an American threat -- said in Morocco today that he was cutting short a North African trip to return to New York on Thursday.
But Mr. Annan has no plans to go to Baghdad or meet Iraqi officials here, his spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said. In Marrakesh, the Secretary General said that he was "saddened and burdened by Iraq's decisions not to cooperate with U.N. weapons inspectors."
Mr. Eckhard said that for now Mr. Annan's role would be "to monitor the Security Council's deliberations, to confer with members of the Council and basically to stay on top of what is developing as a crisis situation."
Mr. Annan discussed the Iraqi crisis with a high-level Clinton Administration official within the last 24 hours, his spokesman said. But the Secretary General has not been in direct contact with President Hussein, who agreed after meeting with Mr. Annan in February to give full access to inspectors, an agreement that he has since broken.
Mr. Annan's special envoy to Iraq, Prakash Shah, is staying in Baghdad. He was told again today by Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz that the Iraqis would cooperate only when the Security Council acts to lift sanctions. The Council is now unified in responding that this cannot happen until unfettered inspections resume.
Mr. Butler, who leaves behind a skeletal Iraqi staff, said he was confident that the equipment and documents the inspectors left behind were safe. The monitoring center, on the edge of Baghdad, is lightly guarded.
Inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency were also withdrawn, leaving the Baghdad monitoring center "dead," an official said here today. The inspectors -- 92 from Unscom and 11 from the I.A.E.A. -- flew to Bahrain today.
The United Nations withdrew 130 staff members from agencies like Unicef, the World Health Organization, the United Nations Development Program and the World Food Program, as well as the staff of the "oil for food" office.
Benon V. Sevan, the New York-based director of the Iraq oil for food program, said that in the Kurdish areas of northern Iraq, the 231 foreign staff, who actually distribute goods, would remain in place.

HEADLINE: A Dogged Mexican Agent Gets His Man, a Fugitive Banker, and Credits the U.S. for Its Help

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 11

 BODY:
It began as one Mexican detective's dogged but lonely search for an elusive banker who was wanted on 21 charges of financial fraud amounting to at least $170 million.
But the four-year international manhunt for the banker, Carlos Cabal Peniche, finally succeeded, Mexican officials said, after top American authorities recently decided to pitch in. 
 Mr. Cabal, who was on the short list of men most wanted by Mexican justice, was arrested on Tuesday afternoon at his tree-shaded beach-front mansion in Melbourne, Australia, where he had been living with his family for about a year posing as a merchant from the Dominican Republic.
Mexican officials moved today to seek his extradition.
Mr. Cabal's capture gives a boost to cross-border cooperation against crime, which faltered earlier this year after the United States Customs disclosed that it had conducted an undercover money-laundering investigation of Mexican banks without informing Mexico.
Mexican officials said that Attorney General Janet Reno gave new support to the pursuit of Mr. Cabal after Mexican investigations turned up signs that he was running a secret financial empire that reached to the Caribbean, South America and Asia with a major base of operations in southern Florida.
The arrest of Mr. Cabal, 41, was a political success in the short term for the Mexican Government's financial officials, who have been accused by the opposition of protecting corrupt bankers. But if he is brought back to Mexico for trial, Mr. Cabal could add explosive new fuel to several scandals.
Bank documents recently unearthed by opposition leaders in Congress show that he contributed at least $14 million during the 1994 election campaign to the political party that brought President Ernesto Zedillo to power. And Raul Salinas de Gortari, who is a brother of the former President and is under investigation on suspicion of narcotics money-laundering, used accounts in Mr. Cabal's banks to make secret transfers of at least $67 million, according to an investigation by the police in Switzerland.
Mr. Cabal had a meteoric rise from a small-time shrimp exporter to one of Mexico's wealthiest and most prominent financiers during the presidency of Carlos Salinas de Gortari. The Salinas Government sold him two banks, Banca Cremi and Banca Union, and Mr. Salinas once singled him out as a model Mexican business executive.
Through his banks Mr. Cabal started agricultural businesses across the Yucatan peninsula. In 1992 he organized a group of Mexican agribusiness families to help him buy the Florida-based Fresh Del Monte Produce Company, one of the world's largest fresh food companies, for $535 million. Mr. Cabal also tried to close a $1 billion deal to buy another branch of Del Monte in 1994, but it fell through when he was indicted for fraud in Mexico and fled.
In his heyday, Mr. Cabal moved to the center of power in Mexico, hobnobbing with President Salinas and top leaders of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, whose dominion over Mexico was then unchallenged.
A federal investigation revealed that Mr. Cabal had set up a fund in 1994 to channel $4.5 million in illegal funds to the gubernatorial campaign of a PRI candidate, Roberto Madrazo, a friend of his.
The federal inquiry showed that Mr. Madrazo had spent more than 30 times the legal limit to win that race, although the case was dismissed two years later on a technicality.
Mexican regulators charged in 1994 that Mr. Cabal lent hundreds of millions to himself from his banks through a network of phantom companies he set up.
Standing eye-to-eye with Mr. Cabal as Australian police officers took him prisoner was Juan Miguel Ponce Edmonson, head of the Mexican branch of Interpol, the agency that links federal police forces around the world. Mr. Ponce had made it a personal mission to track down Mr. Cabal, but for years he felt he was getting a cold shoulder from the American authorities.
In a telephone interview from Melbourne today, Mr. Ponce said he could not help but smile when Mr. Cabal, his hair now gray and his face slightly disguised with a close-trimmed goatee, opened his door to the police.
"It was joyful, joyful," Mr. Ponce said.
Mr. Ponce was able to crack the case after the American authorities started to help monitor Mr. Cabal's movements in earnest about four months ago. That produced a pattern of information that always seemed to lead back to Australia, he said.
Soon after Mr. Ponce contacted the Australian police three weeks ago, they turned up the immigration documents of a Dominican man who nominally ran a business importing Italian wines but seemed to be an intermediary for Mr. Cabal. Mr. Ponce noticed that the Dominican had given the same birth date as the fugitive financier.
"That's when I said, I have to see this guy's face," Mr. Ponce said.
Mr. Ponce said he had noted "a radical change of attitude in the American bureaucracy" after the Mexican Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo, provided his American counterpart with details of "the enormous network Cabal had in the United States."
Mr. Cabal was able to elude capture for so long because he had enough cash to buy false documents for himself, his wife and four children from several countries, and to set himself up in regal style wherever he settled. In 1995 Mr. Ponce just missed nabbing Mr. Cabal at a 12-bedroom mansion in a Madrid suburb.
Mr. Cabal continued to travel regularly to the United States throughout his years as a fugitive, Mexican officials said. His most recent trip ended when he left Los Angeles on Aug. 24.
Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation discovered that Mr. Cabal owns a mansion in the ski resort of Aspen, Colo., which he put up for sale for $12 million. Mexican officials said they were working with the F.B.I. to obtain a search and seizure warrant for the home.
In his absence from Mexico, Mr. Cabal became a central figure in the scandal surrounding the privatization of the Mexican banks in the early 1990's and their $65 billion bail-out by the Government in 1995.
His downfall and flight caused many Mexicans to wonder why the Government sold him two banks in the first place. The sales were handled by a committee headed by Guillermo Ortiz, a widely respected economist who was President Zedillo's first Finance Minister and is now head of Banco de Mexico, the central bank. In recent weeks opposition lawmakers have mounted a campaign to force Mr. Ortiz to resign.
Mr. Ortiz has said that his committee was forced to make decisions about the sales of state-owned banks based on limited information that was available at the time under Mexican law about potential investors.
Opposition lawmakers in the Mexican Congress have also charged that the Government spent vast sums of taxpayer money to pay for the corrupt loans in Mr. Cabal's banks. Government regulators seized Mr. Cabal's banks in 1994. They sold the healthy part of Banca Cremi in 1996 to Banco Bilbao-Vizcaya, a Spanish bank.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Intel Outlook Bodes Well For the Sector

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation's announcement that its fourth-quarter results would exceed Wall Street estimates not only bolstered its stock to a new high yesterday, but analysts said it boded well for a broad range of technology stocks, particularly those whose fortunes are tied to the personal computer.
Intel said on Tuesday that stronger-than-expected demand for personal computer products across all market segments and geographical regions would raise fourth-quarter revenue by 8 percent to 10 percent, compared with third-quarter revenue of $6.7 billion. The company also said that profit margins would be up a couple of points from 53 percent in the third quarter. 
 Shares of Intel shot up yesterday on the report, gaining $6.125 each, to $103.6875.
And Intel's news was buttressed yesterday by a bullish forecast from the Semiconductor Industry Association, which predicted that the global chip market would rebound next year. The association said strong demand for microprocessors, memory and digital signal processors would increase sales by 9.1 percent, to $133.4 billion, and that sales would rise an additional 15.2 percent in 2000 and 18.2 percent in 2001.
Analysts scrambled to raise estimates yesterday, taking the consensus to $1.05 a share for the fourth quarter from 95 cents a share, and to $3.41 a share for the full year from $3.31 a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Analysts raised their estimate for Intel's 1999 earnings to $4.16 a share from $3.92 a share.
But Intel predicted strong earnings in the third quarter only to exceed even the revised estimates, and many analysts expect the company to do the same this time.
"Intel historically has not preannounced very often, and when they do they are very careful," said Mark Edelstone, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The company had a break-out quarter in Q3, and and I expect more of the same in Q4." Mr. Edelstone continues to rate Intel a strong buy.
Intel has long been a leadership company: It invented the microprocessor and the dynamic random access memory chip, or D-RAM, without either of which the personal computer would not exist. Analysts say it is now also a leadership stock, one whose performance serves as a bellwether for the whole technology group, much the way I.B.M. once did. If demand for Intel microprocessors is growing, so too should demand for memory, disk drives and other personal computer components.
Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, has been predicting for some time that Intel's stock price could reach $120 by the end of the year. He said stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings for Intel pointed to a broad-based technology rally. "It's the right sign for the technology sector because what it's saying is there is still genuine double-digit growth in PC's," he said. That growth was hidden by the inventory glut that hung over the sector for the first two quarters, he said.
Despite Intel's good news, Tom Kurlak of Merrill Lynch retained his neutral rating on the stock, as did eight of the 32 analysts polled by First Call. One raised a neutral to a strong buy, one a neutral to a buy. That left the stock rated a buy by 9 analysts and a strong buy by 14.
Those not recommending Intel point to concerns about increased competition at the low end of the market, where Advanced Micro Devices Inc. has been coming on strong, and less need for ever-greater processing power at the high end, which in the age of the Internet is more driven by band width than by microprocessor power. Some analysts say the surge in demand now is mostly inventory replenishing, a temporary phenomenon created by efforts to clear the previous glut.
"It's something that was almost set up to happen and now it is occurring," said John T. Rossi, an analyst with BancBoston Robertson Stephens. "We should enjoy things as they are now, but realize it will also go through the usual seasonal cooling off in mid- to late winter.
Longer term, however, Mr. Rossi said he expected traditional blue-chip companies to suffer more from the Asian economic crisis and to spend more on technology to improve productivity and cope with the Year 2000 problem.
"I look at it as a great place to put money for 1999," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
The N.B.A.'s Senior Owner Speaks Out, and Bluntly

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Abe Pollin bought the Washington Wizards 34 years ago, when they were called the Baltimore Bullets, the National Basketball Association consisted of nine teams and the league was more than a decade from becoming a global marketing phenomenon.
Now, it is a 29-team league and Pollin not only owns the Wizards and the Washington Capitals hockey team, but also the $200 million MCI Center in downtown Washington. 
 At 74, he is the senior owner in the N.B.A., one of three left who have worked with Walter Kennedy and Lawrence O'Brien, David Stern's predecessors as commissioner.
"Larry and I hired David Stern," he said in a telephone interview Tuesday.
Now, Stern's leadership in the lockout, which has prevented the start of the season, has kept Pollin's Wizards idle, while Pollin's Capitals continue playing on his MCI Center ice.
During the lockout, now more than four months old, owners have hardly been heard from as Stern has forged a management unit by cautioning them not to talk about the negotiations.
In discussing the lockout, Pollin did not provide sensitive details and did not break with Stern. But he provided an unusually candid view of the lockout.
Although he is generally optimistic about a deal being reached, Pollin said the owners must get a fair deal. Or, he said: "We're prepared to gut the season. We went into this knowing that if we can't make a fair deal, the season would be gone."
Surprisingly, Pollin doubted that the N.B.A. would require a long period of recovery if it shutters the entire season. Major League Baseball needed until this past season to heal the wounds from the 1994-95 players strike that scotched a World Series.
"I think the N.B.A. will recover quicker," he said. "There's no question the league will survive. It's not something you look forward to, but I'm sure we have some good ideas."
Pollin praised Stern's leadership, but said he is not an omnipotent commissioner towing the owners behind him. "He doesn't do this by himself," Pollin said. "But we agree completely. There is 100 percent unity. There is no split."
Pollin said the economic model that helped the N.B.A. flourish financially for the past 15 years is no longer fair -- to owners. "It doesn't work," he said. "We need one that works. When you have a system where most of the teams aren't getting any type of return on the value of their investments, and for many it's negative, the system doesn't work."
Regarding the Wizards' finances, he said, "I'm not getting anywhere near a fair return."
But he said the lack of revenues from Wizards games will not hurt his ability to pay the debt service on the arena. "I've never missed a payment and I never will," he said.
NBC and Turner Sports will make their full $16 million-a-team payments this season, cushioning teams' loss of revenue from ticket sales and concessions. Pollin's bottom line is also comforted by revenues from Capitals games and other events.
Nonetheless, Pollin is peeved by the suggestion that if the return on his Wizards investment is so small, well, maybe he should sell the team -- a recommendation made by Michael Jordan during a negotiating session last month.
"I'm not going to let Michael Jordan or anybody else tell me to sell my team," he said, anger cutting his genial tone. "Nobody is going to tell me I have to sell my team."
Pollin has maintained his affection for his basketball team despite years of disappointment since Washington's 1978 championship. He was prompted to propose changing the team's name in 1995, from the Bullets to the Wizards, after his friend Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister, was assassinated.
"I love this sport and I love this team," said Pollin, a widely respected owner who is deeply involved in Washington-area charities. "This team and this league have been a big part of my life. I love the players individually. I get to know the players' wives. They come to my home. I've taken them to China and Israel. This team is a very important part of my life."
Pollin has been involved in nearly every major issue in the N.B.A., and served on nearly every major committee. "You enjoy having someone like Abe, with his experience, with his league mentality, who's also very charitable and has a great sense of humor," Stern said.
Pollin is still yearning for a second N.B.A. championship to add to the team's 1978 title. "I just hope we get better," he said. "I think we will."
But first he wants to change the system. The owners want to limit players' salaries to 50 percent of league revenue, not the 60 percent players have proposed, and below the 57.1 percent players made last season. Owners also want to limit rookie salaries and alter the so-called Larry Bird exception that lets teams exceed the salary cap when they re-sign their own free agents.
The system, he said, has resulted in ticket prices rising far beyond the capability of families to attend games without financial hardship. "That disturbs me," he said. "My greatest pleasure is to see families and children come to my building to see an N.B.A. game in a clean environment. So the escalating salaries have to be addressed."
The lockout, a product of the owners' frustrations with the system's flaws, has created a public image of avarice.
"I don't consider myself greedy, so I resent that," he said. "I've spent my life helping others. I resent being called greedy."
Pollin retains an optimism that an agreement can be reached, "but I can't say when -- it's up to the players." Unfortunately, he said, players don't seem to trust the owners' proposals or claims about team finances, among them that 15 teams are losing money.
"I'm not putting blame on owners or the players for the way things are," he said. "We signed a deal in 1995 that doesn't work, so we have to change it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Sinks 40.16 Amid Fading Hopes for a Cut in Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, reversing an early advance, as investors pondered what now seems little better than an even chance that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again next week.
The third consecutive session of declines was brightened by Intel's projection of stronger-than-expected revenue for this quarter, which lifted some technology stocks, and by enthusiastic receptions for three initial public offerings. 
 But mostly this was a day in which the tone seemed to be set by investors cashing profits following a month of large gains amid uncertainty not only about the Fed's meeting next Tuesday but about the possibility of military action against Iraq.
"We've had a very powerful rally in a very short amount of time," said Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. At a time when many believe that foreign instability seems at least to be getting no worse, he called the Fed's decision whether to make a third round of rate reductions "a very close call."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss of 40.16 points at 8,823.82. It was up as much as 72 points in early trading.
The much broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks shed 7.29 points to close at 1,120.97. Even the Nasdaq market, which is dominated by technology stocks and had posted five consecutive advances, closed 3.51 points lower, at 1,862.11, and the Russell 2000 index of smaller issues fell 3.39 points, to 393.47.
"It was a little surprising that the Intel rally didn't take the Nasdaq higher," said Warren Epstein, head trader at Richard A. Rosenblatt & Company.
Intel surged 6 1/8, to 103 11/16, while Texas Instruments rose 5 9/16, to 69 7/16, and Micron Technology was up 3 3/8, to 47 5/8, after hitting a 52-week high.
But most Internet stocks slumped, with Yahoo dropping 12 9/16, America Online 7 3/8 and Ebay 14 15/16, part of what Mr. Epstein called "pretty good profit taking" after sharp run-ups.
Some speculative money might have been redeployed into the new issues, especially Earthweb, which sold 2.1 million shares at 14 and saw them soar as high as 59 before closing at 48 11/16, a 247 percent increase and the second-biggest first-day rise ever, according to Securities Data. The record was Broadcast.com's offering in July, which went from 18 to 74 before settling at 62 3/4, a 250 percent gain.
And in what was the third-largest initial offering on record, News Corporation sold a 20 percent stake in Fox Entertainment Group, a 124.8-million-share deal that was priced late Tuesday at 22 1/2. The shares traded as high as 25 5/8 yesterday before closing at 24 1/2, an unusually big premium for a multibillion-dollar offering.
The other issue to trade for the first time was MONY Group, the insurance company formerly known as Mutual of New York, now owned by shareholders instead of policyholders. The shares, priced at 23 1/2, finished at 28 1/8.
The bond market, from which stocks sometimes take their cue, was closed in observance of Veterans Day.
Stocks were mixed overseas, closing up 4.28 percent in Hong Kong, 2.27 percent in Tokyo and less than 1 percent in London and Frankfurt. The main declines were 2.97 percent in Rio de Janeiro and 1.13 percent in Paris.
Despite the latest skittishness over Iraq, the usual demand for oil shares was missing, with most fractionally mixed. ARCO fell 1 15/16, to 66 5/8, and Phillips fell 1 1/4, to 43 1/4.
Drug stocks were among the prominent losers yesterday, with Merck, Pfizer and Schering-Plough more than 2 points lower and Lilly and Abbott down more than 1.
In a soft financial sector, BankAmerica was down 2 5/16, to 57, the main loser, but J. P. Morgan jumped 1 3/16, to 98 13/16, amid continuing takeover rumors and word that it won Phelps Dodge's 401(k) business.
American Express lost 1/2, to 92 9/16, despite news that Warren E. Buffett bought 1.08 million shares in early October, the first time the multibillionaire investor had raised his Amex stake since 1995.
Chrysler edged up 1/8, to 47 1/16, in its last week of trading before the company's shares disappear because of its merger with Germany's Daimler-Benz. Analysts said index funds may already have disposed of their Chrysler shares. Safeway, taking Chrysler's place in the S.& P. 500, climbed 1 3/16, to 49 3/16.
On the New York Stock Exchange, volume was 715.8 million shares, up from 679.7 million Tuesday. There were 33 new highs against 19 new lows, but 1,797 issues declined while only 1,215 rose.

HEADLINE: America's Turn to Colonize;
CreditCard Issuers Invade Britain, With U.S. Firepower

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
What, precisely, is Billy Connolly, the Scottish comedian, doing in biblical robes and beard in a commercial with floating goldfish that fill the television screen?
Improbably, the answer lies in a remarkable American invasion of the credit card industry in Britain that has left big British credit card issuers smarting. For the goldfish represent the Goldfish card, which has gained 800,000 customers since it was first issued in 1996 by a British subsidiary of Household International Inc. of Prospect Heights, Ill., in conjunction with a British gas utility. 
 Indeed, in just a few years, Household and other American companies -- including MBNA of Wilmington, Del.; People's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn.; American Express, and Capital One Financial of Falls Church, Va. -- have captured 10.2 percent of the cards issued in a $136.7 billion market that was once controlled exclusively by four big British banks led by Barclays P.L.C. with its Barclaycard. The Americans have shaken up the industry with innovative marketing and by offering interest rates that are lower than the average rates of 22 and 23 percent charged by British issuers.
"It's a battleground," acknowledged John Eaton, the managing director of Barclaycard. The company is still the dominant issuer of cards in Britain, but its share of the market here has fallen to 31 percent last year from 37.1 percent in 1995, and the number of different cards available in Britain has grown to 1,200, from 40 in 1990.
"It's a tough, competitive market," Mr. Eaton said.
Some American companies see further gains ahead. The credit card business in Britain is similar to the way the United States market was in the 1980's, said Patrick Nelson, corporate communications manager for Capital One.
"If you look back at the U.S. market in 1986, and look at it now, you will find only three or four of the big players in '86 are still there," he said. "And there is that same potential here in the United Kingdom. U.K. High Street banks have been charging far too much for far too long."
The American beachhead in Britain could serve as a springboard into a much bigger and largely untapped market: Continental Europe. The Continent has outstanding Visa and Mastercard debt estimated at $49 billion -- much less than the $397 billion in Visa and Mastercard debt in the United States. Credit cards have failed to win mass acceptance in much of Europe, where big banks dominate with debit cards and personal checking accounts.
The trick for any new competitors in Europe, then, is essentially to create a bigger market, bankers say. And that has happened in large part in Britain, where a boom in the overall use of credit cards has cushioned big banks from the effects of their eroding market share.
"The credit card cake has been growing all the time," said David Joy, an economist with the Credit Card Research Group, an industry organization. "So while people like Barclaycard have been losing market share, they have not been losing money."
The total amount of debt outstanding on credit cards in Britain, mostly Visa and Mastercard, now stands at 21.8 billion, or $36.2 billion, up 23 percent from 17.7 billion ($29.4 billion) a year ago.
And Mr. Eaton of Barclaycard says figures showing simple market share are misleading. Over the last 18 months, he said, four million new credit cards have flooded onto the British market, but many of them have been issued to people who already held a card.
"Three years ago, about 20 percent of card holders had more than one card," he said. "Now it's 40 percent." Moreover, although credit card use has nearly doubled as a proportion of British retail sales to 20 percent -- of which Barclaycard claims 50 percent -- from 12 percent in 1990, the numbers show that many people still rely on cash, debit cards or checks.
"The marketplace is now very much about share of wallet: how do you sustain your share of wallet?" Mr. Eaton said. "The most powerful indicator is the share of turnover in the total market. How much of customers' spending am I getting on a monthly, weekly basis?"
Beginning in the mid-1990's, some American financial companies reached for the British wallet by taking aim where they thought British issuers were most vulnerable: interest rates.
"The single largest comment is: give me a low rate and no annual fee," said Carlos Mello, managing director of People's Bank, which introduced its card in Britain in 1996. The bank, with a modest British operation of 55 full-time workers, has so far issued 120,000 cards, with an introductory rate of 6.9 percent that later rises to 17.9 percent, according to the Nilson Report, a credit card industry newsletter in Oxnard, Calif.
American companies are also introducing unfamiliar marketing strategies to Britain. Capital One, for example, offered an introductory 6.9 percent interest rate on a Mastercard coupled with an offer for tickets to last summer's World Cup soccer tournament. Other special themes include a card offering discounts at specific London stores and a personalized Mastercard sporting the card holder's photograph.
It also offers a set interest rate of 12.9 percent for customers who are confused by the idea of cards that offer an introductory rate that later rises. Capital One issued 630,000 cards by the end of 1997, a year after its introduction, according to the Nilson Report.
A Household International subsidiary, HFC Bank P.L.C., which has been in Britain since 1973, introduced a credit card linked to reduced prices on General Motors' Vauxhall cars. The program was a British version of the G.M. card in the United States. Then Household hit on the idea of using a goldfish as its emblem, and charging 19.8 percent interest but offering a 1 percent reduction on a gas utility's bills. "Everyone has a gas bill to pay," said Mark Rutland, director of corporate communications for HFC Bank.
With a growing share of the market, American companies are expanding. Capital One, for example, is planning to invest $50 million in a new processing plant in Nottingham, in the Midlands.
Plans like this show just how much the American presence has mushroomed. Starting from scratch in 1994, Household, through its British subsidiaries, last year ranked as the biggest American credit card issuer -- and the fifth over all -- in Britain, with 2.1 million cards issued. That represents just 4.2 percent of the market but is nearly a threefold increase from 1995, according to the Nilson Report. A close second, MBNA had 1.9 million cards issued by the end of 1997 -- more than double the number in 1995. Counted by cards issued, American issuers over all hold 10.2 percent of the British market.
Barclaycard has responded swiftly to the American challenge to its dominance. The company, which has some 6.5 million customers holding 15.3 million cards, announced last summer that it would shed 1,100 jobs -- a quarter of its work force -- over the next three years. It also plans to invest around $50 million in new systems over the next three years.
And it has sought to counter the low-interest-rate invaders, Mr. Eaton said, by offering to cut its own rate to 18.9 percent from 22.9 percent for people charging more than $825 a month -- considerably higher than the British average. It has also instituted loyalty programs offering discounts on Ford cars and Cellnet mobile phones.
Still, the American insurgents are not the only challenge. Supermarket chains like Tesco and J. Sainsbury have also issued their own credit cards, along with the many building societies -- the British equivalent of savings and loans -- that have converted into banks. There is also an array of affinity cards linking credit to particular interests and brands.
The contest may soon get even sharper. An anticipated slowdown in the British economy next year has already doubled the number of credit card accounts in arrears compared with last year, according to figures from the Equifax financial information group, suggesting that both the newcomers and the veterans of the credit card industry will be scrambling to maintain growth.
"It'll be a tougher assignment next year," Mr. Rutland of HFC Bank said. His concerns reflect broader worries in Britain about a possible consumer credit crunch if the economy slows -- or even slides into recession as it did in the early 1990's, exacerbated by a sharp increase in consumer debt. "It will be interesting to see if other American competitors are here for the long haul," he said.
While Barclaycard is being challenged at home, it is among the pioneers in Continental Europe. Along with Citigroup's Citibank unit, which has an estimated 1.34 million cards in European countries, Barclaycard has sought to penetrate the new European markets, with 600,000 cards, for instance, issued in Germany alone.
Here, too, competition is beginning. Though some American banks active in Britain say they have no immediate plan to test the broader European market, American Express has introduced in Italy and Germany, as well as in Britain, a new blue card that like its better-known green, gold and platinum cards charges an annual fee, but unlike the others also offers revolving credit.
The blue card, said Peter Godfrey, American Express regional president for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, is aiming at customers in their early 20's to mid-30's in nine countries from Australia to Canada, but not in the United States. The card has plunged into the market with a lower introductory rate, 1 percent standard discounts on purchases and -- for November -- a 5 percent cash-back discount.
While Mr. Godfrey declined to give figures, he said the number of initial customers was "substantially above our internal forecast."
With 11 European countries set to introduce a common currency, the euro, in January, the European market clearly offers new opportunities for credit card holders. Initially, the euro will be limited to electronic trading of all kinds from intergov ernment transfers to stock markets. Cash and notes will become mandatory only in January 2002. But exchange rates between member countries will be fixed from the beginning of next year, meaning that credit cards could offer travelers a way of eliminating currency exchange costs if they, say, pay a hotel bill in Milan in euro-linked lire, and pay their credit card bill in euro-linked marks. The problem is that relatively few Continental Europeans use credit cards.
"You are dealing with a debit card, overdraft mentality in Continental Europe, and it's difficult to break these markets," Mr Godfrey said. "The key thing for us is to create that market. It is worth the effort to create a credit card environment in Europe."

HEADLINE: Front-runner for Gingrich Seat Emerges

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga., Nov. 11

 BODY:
The campaign to succeed Speaker Newt Gingrich as the Congressman from Georgia's Sixth District began taking shape today as Johnny Isakson, the chairman of the state school board and a fixture in state Republican politics, announced his candidacy and instantly became the presumptive front-runner.
Among other political assets, Mr. Isakson, 53, has the blessing of Mr. Gingrich, who issued a statement on Tuesday encouraging him to run. 
 "He is a very close personal friend," Mr. Gingrich said, "and I believe he would do a great job of representing Georgia's Sixth District."
Mr. Gingrich announced last Friday that he would step down from the Speakership and resign his House seat because of Republican losses in last week's elections. The party lost five seats in the House, and, counting Mr. Gingrich, now holds 223 seats to the Democrats' 211 and 1 independent. The Republican majority is six.
Mr. Isakson's announcement is likely to keep some prospective Republican candidates out of the race. The state Republican chairman, Russell K. Paul, said today that he would no longer consider running and joined other party leaders in the district in handicapping Mr. Isakson as a heavy favorite.
The Sixth District, which spans an arc of affluent suburbs north of Atlanta, is considered one of the most Republican Congressional districts in the country. Politics here are driven primarily by economic conservatism, but social issues also play a role and that could cause problems for Mr. Isakson. He is a social moderate who took the unusual step of highlighting his support for abortion rights during a Republican primary campaign for the United States Senate two years ago, alienating many religious conservatives.
Mr. Paul said Mr. Isakson had already started to repair that damage by contacting Christian conservative leaders.
"He won't make them all happy," Mr. Paul said, "but he's working to shore up his right flank."
In his announcement in the town square here, Mr. Isakson emphasized his Republican credentials, saying he and Mr. Gingrich "were Republicans when Republican wasn't very cool."
A real estate executive, Mr. Isakson has served in the General Assembly and run two unsuccessful statewide races, for governor in 1990 and for the Senate in 1996.
Mr. Isakson focused his remarks today on economic issues; he did not mention social ones.
"I believe in the principles of economic conservatism," he said. "I believe in the principles of local control. And I believe in a manageable government that takes less out of the pockets of the taxpayers and enlightens the life of all of us."
One social conservative, State Representative Mitchell Adam Kaye Sr., a Republican who gained national attention this year for proposing that teachers be allowed to carry guns in schools, has said he will challenge Mr. Isakson, and several others are still considering their options. On the Democratic side, Michael Coles, an entrepreneur and former state party chairman who lost a campaign for the United States Senate last week, is considering entering the race.
Because Mr. Gingrich has yet to formally notify Gov. Zell Miller of his resignation, no date has been set for a special election to fill his seat. It also remains unclear whether the election would be nonpartisan, with Democrats and Republicans running together, or whether a general election would be preceded by party primaries.
Some Democratic officials said today that they would like to see partisan primaries because Mr. Isakson might be challenged from the right. Although the district is considered strong Republican turf, the Democrats believe they have a chance to win in a race against an extreme social conservative.
"The district can be won with the right combination of Republican candidates," said David Worley, the state Democratic chairman. "There's a real possibility that the Republicans will choose as their leading candidate a radical nut, for lack of a better term."

HEADLINE: A $5 Billion Revamping At Monsanto

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Monsanto Company, which for the last few years has aggressively pushed into biotechnology and pharmaceuticals, said today that it planned to raise about $5 billion by restructuring its operations, reducing its work force as much as 9 percent, or 2,500 jobs, and selling additional shares to the public.
The company said that the plan, which comes just a month after its failed merger with American Home Products, a giant pharmaceutical producer with large reserves of cash, is expected to help finance Monsanto's recent acquisitions of a number of large seed businesses and prepare the company to develop a number of promising new products. 
 Monsanto announced the plan after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, where its shares closed at $38.6875, down 50 cents. But Wall Street analysts say that without the American Home Products deal, which some think broke down because of a dispute over who would run the new company, Monsanto found itself in desperate need of cash.
"They paid big bucks for their seed businesses, and they also have a lot of drug products in the pipeline," said Richard O'Reilly, an analyst with the Standard & Poor's Equity Group. "Right now, they have a lot on their plate, and so they have to pay some of the bill until the drug pipeline comes to fruition."
Executives at Monsanto evidently agree.
"What it really means for the company is that we will get the financing issues behind us and we can focus our energies on bringing the pharmaceutical pipeline and the agricultural and biotechnology products to the market," said Gary Crittenden, chief financial officer at Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis. "We are on the brink of launching one of the largest pharmaceutical products of all time."
That product, Celebra, has been described by Monsanto as a promising new arthritis drug, which is under review by the Food and Drug Administration. It is also a symbol of the new path that Monsanto has taken in recent years, shifting its focus from the chemicals business, which tended to be cyclical, to the high-growth pharmaceutical and futuristic biotechnology businesses.
That shift has sent shares of Monsanto soaring in recent years, more than tripling in worth. And the deal with American Home Products, which analysts expected to benefit both companies, seemed to have offered a solution to backing Monsanto's huge bet on what it calls the "life sciences" business -- an approach to integrating the businesses of agriculture, health care and nutrition.
The life sciences business, the company says, is creating more efficient crop yields, cotton that can be protected against insects and healthier foods. But Wall Street analysts say that without American Home Products, Monsanto found itself lacking the cash it needed, particularly after it made huge investments in the seed and biotechnology business. In the last year, it has spent more than $8 billion on the seed business, including the acquisition in June of the Cargill Company's international seed business.
Some deals are still pending. The company recently announced plans to acquire the 60 percent of the DeKalb Genetics Corporation that it does not already own for $2.3 billion. DeKalb is one of the nation's largest seed-corn companies.
Monsanto's other big seed deal, valued at $1.9 billion, is a proposal to buy the Delta and Pine Land Company, the largest domestic cotton-seed producer.
"They have a lot of opportunities, but they need cash," said Timothy R. Meyer, an analyst with Equity Advisers in Chicago. "So their first choice was American Home Products, which is a cash cow. But if they're not going to get it, they're going to have to go to the public markets. But it's good; it relieves a lot of uncertainty."
According to the plan announced today, Monsanto would issue about $1 billion in new common stock, about $500 million in debt that is convertible into stock, $2.5 billion in long-term debt, and about $1 billion from the sale or divestiture of some of its assets. The company said it would take a pretax restructuring charge of $400 million to $600 million in the fourth quarter of 1998.
Monsanto also plans to revamp its operations in ways that will eliminate as many as 1,000 of its more than 28,000 jobs, and cut as many as 1,500 more through the sale of assets. By 1999, Monsanto expects administrative costs to be reduced by 20 percent.
But marketing and technology spending will rise as it brings products to market, and hopes to move aggressively into new biotechnology ventures.
"The actions today continue a long-term process," Monsanto's chairman and chief executive, Robert B. Shapiro, said in a statement. "From 1992 to 1995, we developed our strategy to transform Monsanto into a leading life sciences company. From 1995 to the present, we've been putting together the resources and capabilities -- business portfolio, people, technologies and infrastructure -- to carry out that strategy."

HEADLINE: Milton Handler, 95, Is Dead; Antitrust Expert Wrote Laws

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Milton Handler, a leading antitrust expert and drafter of some of the nation's best-known laws, died on Tuesday. He was 95.
Professor Handler suffered a stroke on Thursday, said his daughter, Carol E. Handler. 
 Professor Handler, who taught at Columbia University Law School for nearly half a century, ranged far beyond the classroom. He was President Franklin D. Roosevelt's chief adviser on antitrust matters, served as the first general counsel to the National Labor Relations Board and helped to draft such landmark statutes as the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938, the National Labor Relations Act and the G.I. Bill of Rights. In the 1950's and 1960's, he became one of the top antitrust litigators in the country.
An ardent Zionist, he was close to the founders of the Israeli state and participated in the legal brief submitted to the United Nations in support of the 1947 partition plan. His proudest legal achievement, he often said, was securing Albert Einstein's papers for Hebrew University.
"In the realm of trade regulation he was a colossus and in all respects he lived grandly in the law," said Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg of the United States Supreme Court, who is among the many prominent jurists who studied under Mr. Handler and later became friends.
The youngest of seven children, he was born in the Bronx in 1903. His father died when he was 2, and the family moved to Brooklyn. He graduated from Columbia College in 1923 and briefly dreamed of teaching literature before he became captivated by the law. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1926 with top honors. For one year he was a clerk for Justice Harlan Fiske Stone of the Supreme Court, for whom he developed a lifelong admiration, and then was invited by the dean of the Columbia Law School to teach trade regulation in the summer session. That marked the beginning of a 45-year teaching career.
One of his first assignments at the Supreme Court had been to help Justice Stone draft his landmark opinion in United States v. Trenton Potteries Company et al, a ruling that held that price-fixing agreements always violated the Sherman Act, whether or not the prices charged were reasonable. From then on, Professor Handler focused his intellectual energies on antitrust issues, a scholarly endeavor that became, as he later put it, "the essence of my life."
As a teacher who taught by the Socratic method, he was diligent, even daunting. "By working day and night I was able to amass enough knowledge for each class session, generally being one day ahead of the class," he later wrote.
In 1932, while still in his 20's, Mr. Handler was drafted by the Roosevelt campaign to work on the Democrats' antitrust message and stayed on as the Administration's chief antitrust adviser. In 1937, he helped create the Temporary National Economic Committee. The summary of antitrust law that he wrote for the committee has since become part of the legal canon.
During World War II, Professor Handler served on the Lend-Lease Administration. He was also a key organizer of a Government emergency board to rescue Jews from the Holocaust. In January 1944, Professor Handler drafted the executive order creating the War Refugee Board, but only after an uphill battle for support. "One cannot but wonder how many lives might have been saved if the board had been set up in the early war years," he later said.
After the war, Professor Handler prepared amendments to the Social Security Act that later became the foundation for Medicare. He was especially proud of his role in creating the G.I. Bill of Rights. "Nothing is more important than providing people with the skills that they get from an education," he later wrote.
By the 1950's, Professor Handler was developing one of the most successful private antitrust practices in the country. He became a partner in a leading New York law firm, Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler. As counsel and litigator, he represented some of the nation's biggest corporations, including Xerox, Pepsico, the American Tobacco Company and Texaco, and he argued many cases before the Supreme Court.
By then, Professor Handler's reputation as a scholar was so stellar that judges, many of whom had been his students or were devotees of his published lectures, frequently consulted him.
"He had an extraordinary presence in the courtroom," recalled David Klingsberg, chairman of Kaye, Scholer, who worked closely with Professor Handler starting in the early 1960's. "Judges listened to what he had to say."
Prolific well into his 90's, Professor Handler published numerous articles, casebooks and texts, including classics on trade regulation, labor law and antitrust. His annual series of antitrust lectures, published in three separate collections, have long been considered required reading for anyone interested in the field.
On antitrust matters, Professor Handler's philosophy was distinctively centrist. "He stood for balance," said his daughter, who is also an antitrust lawyer. His philosophy was that the principle of economic competition was as fundamental to American democracy as the freedom to express competing ideas. In the "big is bad" 50's and 60's, Professor Handler criticized the Government control of business issues preferred by Justices William O. Douglas and Hugo L. Black. But in the 80's, he also said the Reagan and Bush Administrations brought too few antitrust cases. Human nature had not changed, he liked to point out.
Professor Handler was granted numerous prizes and honorary degrees. Last May, he received the prestigious John Sherman Award from the antitrust division of the Justice Department.
Elegant and urbane, Professor Handler lived on Park Avenue and had a second home in Palm Beach and closets so full of suits and elegant shoes that house guests were hard pressed to find an empty hanger or shelf. A lover of music, interesting people and dinner parties, he could talk intelligently on subjects ranging from the law and politics to philosophy and biography.
Professor Handler enjoyed excellent health until almost the end. Indeed, he had just been host at a dinner for some of New York's leading legal lights at the Four Seasons a few nights before he suffered a stroke, dominating the conversation with witty anecdotes.
Professor Handler's first wife, Marion Winter Kahn, whom he married in 1931, died in 1953. His second wife, Miriam Adler, whom he married in 1955, died in 1997. In addition to his daughter, he is survived by two granddaughters, Alisa Marion Schoenbach and Ilana Abigail Schoenbach.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nissan, Losing Money, Seeks Public Loan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Japanese Government is poised to come to the aid of the Nissan Motor Company, the nation's ailing No. 2 auto maker, by making loans from the Japan Development Bank available to it.
The auto maker said that it was negotiating with the Government-backed bank for a loan but that the amount and timing had not yet been determined. 
 The development bank typically lends to companies needing money to finance capital expenditures. The laws governing the bank's lending state that at least half of any loan must be used for financing projects like building new factories or installing major technology.
Nissan's needs are of a more immediate nature, according to some analysts, who think that the company is having trouble raising money in the capital markets to finance its operations.
But they think that the latest economic-stimulus package the Government is preparing will include plans to ease the development bank's restrictions and otherwise find ways of helping corporations survive the worst credit squeeze in recent memory.
Analysts said the loan's importance would depend on the specifics, particularly its size, but they disagreed over what the loan meant in terms of Nissan's financial health, which has been shaky for the last several years.
Some regarded the company's turn to the development bank as a sign of dire financial straits.
"It's an undeniable fact that the company is short of cash and wants to do anything to accumulate it," said Koji Endo of Schroders Securities.
Nissan is shouldering debt of 4.3 trillion yen, or about $35 billion, and is trying to reorganize amid the worst economic downturn since World War II.
Car sales in Japan fell 14 percent last year and a further 8 percent in the first half of this year, and Nissan announced yesterday that it expected to post yet another loss for the full fiscal year, which ends on March 31.
It has also suffered from bloated inventories in the United States, some of that caused by supplies of used vehicles turned onto the market as leases ended. Nissan had provided heavy incentives for Americans to lease, leading to this year's glut.
It has lost money in six of the last seven years, and Mr. Endo thinks that company debt ratings will fall to junk-bond status by the end of the year because of the expected loss.
"If that happens, there will be almost no way they can raise cash," he said.
But Steve Usher, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities, cautioned against interpreting the negotiations as a sign of desperation.
"The situation Nissan is facing at this point would not necessarily imply a cash squeeze," he said. "There is a deterioration in its profitability, but virtually all companies here are having that deterioration."
He noted that the bulk of the losses announced on Tuesday -- $266 million for the six-month period ending on Sept. 30 -- were related to securities Nissan holds and were thus largely paper losses.
"They're in a position at this point, given their cash flow, to meet their requirements," he said.
Mr. Endo said Nissan's borrowing costs had sharply risen since August, when Moody's Investors Service lowered its credit ratings, which now hover one notch above junk-bond status.
Its usual lenders, the Industrial Bank of Japan and Fuji Bank, have problems of their own and can ill afford to extend further loans to the company -- although they can afford its demise even less.
The company does have access to a credit line of 500 billion yen it obtained last month from 10 banks to protect it, should it have difficulties raising money.
But Nissan's parts suppliers and affiliates are also experiencing credit constraints and need its help. Mr. Usher said the company had increased its borrowing last year and in the first half of this year to support its group companies rather than finance its own operations.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
So Just Whose Party Is It? A G.O.P. House Divided

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
As they battle for slots in the House Republican leadership, candidates talk passionately about their party's need for new faces. Or a new generation of leaders. Or better communication.
But what is it they want to communicate? 
It is difficult to find a single answer. The majority that Newt Gingrich built is so deeply splintered that it seemed at times during the last Congressional session to dissolve into its 228 component parts, each Republican member of the House with a different idea of what the party should be.
Is it the Eisenhower-era road-building party that Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania might have envisioned when he pushed through the House the largest public works bill ever before Congress? Or is it the party of frugality and small government that Representative Joe Scarborough of Florida calls for when he criticizes that bill as a pork-laden abomination?
Is it the Teddy Roosevelt-style reformist party that Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut fights for when he calls on Republicans to overhaul campaign finance law? Or is it a party so in step with its corporate donors that Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, feels free to pressure trade associations to hire Republicans as their lobbyists?
How can the idea of conservation voiced by Representative Sherwood Boehlert of upstate New York ever square with Representative Helen Chenoweth's support for the Idaho timber industry?
For all his flaws, Mr. Gingrich was widely acknowledged to be his party's most skilled conceptualizer and theoretician.
But across the past year, with a Republican majority five seats larger than the party will have in the 106th Congress, he could make no coherent synthesis out of this swirl of interests, no matter how painstakingly he sounded out ideas on issues like tax reform, tax cuts, individualized private Social Security accounts or a strong global role for America.
Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, who will take over the Speaker's post from Mr. Gingrich, has already made clear that he intends not to be a theoretician but rather to use his management skills to make sure legislation is moving through the House. He has also said that because of his narrow majority, of only six seats, he will be looking to strike compromises with conservative and moderate Democrats.
But watchful Democrats, who now think they could win back the House in 2000, suspect that such management skills will not be enough to provide the Republicans a compelling new message for the electorate.
"When the history of the Republican revolution is written, Bob Livingston will play Brezhnev to Newt Gingrich's Lenin," said Mark Mellman, a pollster for the House Democratic leadership. "Members of Congress care deeply how the bows in the legislative packages are tied. The public doesn't care a whit about that. They care about agenda and message."
Part of the Republicans' problem is that the political ground has shifted as a result of their own policy successes.
Ever since Ronald Reagan, Republicans have believed in an inevitable triumph of their philosophy of tax cutting, a strong military and a scaled-back Federal Government. In fact, until the arrival of Bill Clinton, both parties had come to believe that the Republicans had a natural advantage -- some called it an "electoral lock" -- in the race for the Presidency.
The Republican takeover of Congress in 1994 left the self-proclaimed Republican revolutionaries with an even greater sense of omnipotence, at least until Mr. Clinton won re-election two years ago. Even last week, on the Election Day that brought his party a loss of seats and led to his own resignation, Mr. Gingrich called the Clinton Presidency "an ongoing, slow-motion collapse of the Democratic majority that Franklin Roosevelt created."
But Congressional Republicans, while holding their majority, have been floundering ever since Mr. Clinton flummoxed them by agreeing to a balanced budget with tax cuts, signing their welfare overhaul into law and proclaiming that the "era of big government" had ended. Further, the end of the cold war has caused military and foreign policy to weigh less on the public mind, crippling a perennial Republican election issue.
Democrats came out of the elections last week believing that they now had the edge on policies of public concern -- on education, regulation of health maintenance organizations, the economy and Social Security.
"It's the first time in my life that the Democrats are in the mainstream of the country on issues that people care about," said Douglas B. Sosnik, a 42-year-old senior adviser to Mr. Clinton. The White House is working to unveil new proposals in these areas and to make another run at proposals that died this year.
Wondering where to go, Republicans are uncertain whether to fight back on this Democratic ground or to put renewed emphasis on traditional Republican issues.
Representative Shays says the Christian right must stop having a disproportionate influence on his party.
"As soon as my leaders started to jump when the Christian Coalition and Gary Bauer and others said jump, we lost a lot of voters," he said.
But Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana says moving toward the center would be a "recipe for disaster."
"I think the message in this election," Mr. McIntosh said, "was that Reagan Democrats in particular and Perot independents felt there was not a big difference between Congressional Republicans and President Clinton. So they went back to their traditional habits of voting."
Many Republicans believe that their best course is to show the kind of "compassionate conservatism" practiced by the party's successful governors, making their party more diverse to reflect the nation's changing demographics and focusing on the issues that unite all their factions.
"I think the party has the best cohesion when it talks about fiscal issues," said Representative Rick A. Lazio of Long Island. "The public needs to know the Republican Party, as it lowers taxes and lives within its means, is also watching out for those less fortunate."
So Representative Jennifer Dunn of Washington State, who is vying for majority leader, and Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, the only black Republican in Congress, who is competing for conference chairman, may be picking up some currency, as leadership candidates who would appeal to women and minorities.
But Republicans have had their troubles finding unity these days, even on fiscal policy. All year long, the members battled over whether to have a tax cut focused on married couples or a tax cut focused on capital gains. In the end, they got neither. At one point, some House Republicans sought a $700 billion tax reduction over five years, but that idea was quickly squelched by Senate Republicans. A sweeping tax overhaul, another potential Republican issue, has brought no greater consensus, with House members splintered over whether to replace the progressive income tax with a flat tax or a national sales tax.
Perhaps the best the House Republicans can do is create few waves and let the party's Presidential candidates move to center stage to fight out in primaries the issues that have divided the Congressional majority.
Said Mr. Sosnik, the Clinton adviser, who remembers the Democrats' own plight during the Reagan and Bush Presidencies: "I do believe at the end of the day God invented Presidential primaries so that parties out of power can have a leader and have a message."

Internet Stocks Fall Sharply As Investors Take Profits
Shares of Yahoo fell $11.5625, to $165, and America Online declined $7.375, to $137.125, as most Internet stocks slumped on profit taking after recent increases. Although shares of the chip maker Intel rose $6.125, to $103.6875, after the company projected stronger-than-expected revenue for the quarter, it was not enough to rally the Nasdaq, which decreased 3.51 points, to 1,862.11.
Market gauges fell as investors pondered what seems little better than an even chance that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again next week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 40.16 points, to 8,823.82, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 7.29 points, to 1,120.97. Page C7. 

Shares of Fox Entertainment rose $2, to $24.50, in their first day of trading. The News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, raised $2.8 billion selling 18 percent of its film, television and sports empire to the public. C6.
 
Gates Blames Rivals for Charges
William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, told shareholders that the Government's antitrust case against the software giant was driven chiefly by the company's rivals. C6.
 
Ailing Nissan Motor in Loan Talks
The Japanese Government is poised to assist Nissan Motor, Japan's No. 2 auto maker, by making loans from the Japan Development Bank available to it. C4.
 
The Sherlock Holmes of Trademarks
As the intellectual property counsel for Compagnie Financiere Richemont, the owner of such elite brands as Alfred Dunhill luxury gifts, Cartier jewelry and Montblanc pens, Frederick Mostert helps make sure no one steals or imitates the names, shapes or slogans of the Swiss-based company's products. He is also the president of the International Trademark Association, so he keeps his eye on other companies' products as well. C2.
 
The Last Days of Chrysler
After a history of close calls with bankruptcy, a Federal Government bailout and a recent flood of profits from minivan and Jeep sales, the Chrysler Corporation will disappear as an independent company today, merging with Daimler-Benz of Germany. C4
 
Medpartners Exiting a Business
Medpartners is leaving the business of physician practice management. It plans to concentrate on more profitable units that provide managed care drug benefits and coordinate medical treatments. C20.
 
Federated Profit Climbs 4.8%
Federated Department Stores said fiscal third-quarter profit rose 4.8 percent as cost controls offset lower sales at its Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other chains. Profit before a charge rose to $110 million, or 50 cents a diluted share, a penny above estimates. C20.
 
No Deal for Barings Bondholders
Investors holding the bonds of Barings P.L.C., the failed British bank, rejected a proposed settlement seeking to recover their losses, saying the amount was a fraction of the $1.3 billion lost in 1995 during a wild trading spree by one of the bank's Singapore traders. C2.
 
Biotech Company in Cell Discovery
A small biotechnology company, Advanced Cell Technology of Worcester, Mass., said that its scientists had for the first time made human cells revert to the primordial, embryonic state from which all other cells develop, by fusing them with cow eggs and creating a hybrid cell. The method could eventually be used to create replacement body tissue. A1.
 
Pacific Lumber License Suspended
California forestry regulators, citing what they called continuing egregious violations, have suspended the conditional old-growth redwood logging license of Pacific Lumber Company. The suspension could complicate a $380 million state and Federal deal to buy one of the world's oldest groves of virgin redwoods from the company. A18.
