SECTION: Section 6; Page 68; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1453 words

HEADLINE: Taking the Starch Out of Status

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera 

 BODY:
In the spring of 1996, two young men named David Filo and Jerry Yang, both still in their 20's, became overnight multimillionaires. They did it, of course, the way everybody becomes an overnight multimillionaire nowadays. They started an Internet company in their spare time --just for fun, they called it Yahoo! -- and after securing some venture capital, they completed an Initial Public Offering, or I.P.O., to use the initials that even schoolchildren can now toss off on the playground. Yahoo! stock opened for business at $4.33 a share (split-adjusted, I scarcely need to mention), and by the end of that first day, the stock had risen 154 percent. That's a bigger first-day gain than even during Netscape's fabled I.P.O. Presto! Filo and Yang, who held 31 percent of the stock, were suddenly worth a combined $270 million. If that's not the classic definition of "New Money," I don't know what is.
New Money. Now there's a phrase you don't hear anymore. Once upon a time, though -- 50 years ago, just 10? -- New Money was a term that was meant to contrast with Old Money, and there was no doubting which was preferred, at least among the taste makers on the East Coast. New Money was grasping and crass (think: your typical Texas oilman); Old Money was refined (think: David Rockefeller). New Money yearned for respectability; Old Money had it. New Money flaunted its wealth; Old Money believed there was no greater sin. Old Money had status that New Money could only dream about. 
In the 1950's and early 1960's -- an era, please recall, when personal income was taxed at rates as high as 91 percent -- the act of trying to get rich quick, by, say, striking oil in Texas, was regarded with suspicion, if not outright hostility. An oilman who stumbled on black gold was viewed, with enormous condescension, as lucky more than smart -- more akin to a gambler than a titan of industry. Real wealth was something accrued over generations, not days. The self-made man stood several orbits outside the nation's elites. The typical entrepreneur couldn't get a decent table at "21" unless he bought the joint -- as the entrepreneur Marshall Cogan did in the 1980's.
Today, it's Old Money that has become ever so slightly disreputable -- with its associations of undeserved connections, "coupon clipping" and third and fourth generations that were messed up because of their inherited wealth. Meanwhile, the act of trying to get rich quick by, say, starting an Internet company has become virtually the sole requirement for entering the ranks of the nation's elite. Now the assumption is that the richer you are, the smarter you must be and the more status you have. It's not a matter of privilege, or birthright, but merit -- or at least that's how it is now seen. Consequently, the word "entrepreneur" has become a term of praise rather than opprobrium.
Billionaires or near-billionaires -- like Bill Gates; Jeff Bezos, the head of Amazon.com; Scott McNeely, the head of Sun Microsystems; and even Filo and Yang -- have become something akin to national heroes. Think about it: when mothers used to tell their children that they could grow up to be anything they wanted, they usually cited the Presidency as the greatest possible aspiration. Now mothers are more likely to tell their kids that they can grow up to be the next Bill Gates.
How does this sort of thing happen? How does the entire culture change the way it views money? One theory, proposed by Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., the author of the 1988 book "Old Money: The Mythology of America's Upper Class," is that Ronald Reagan began the shift in attitude. As Aldrich observes, Reagan was a self- made man who surrounded himself with other self-made men, like his Treasury Secretary, Donald Regan (and later White House Chief of Staff), who had risen from a working-class childhood in Cambridge, Mass., to become the chairman of Merrill Lynch. These men, in turn, promoted the values of the self-made man -- "Market Man," Aldrich calls him -- and set about rousting the patrician elites from their business enclaves. Aldrich cites in particular the rise of the hostile takeover movement in the 1980's -- which a different administration might have put a stop to, but which the Reagan Administration tacitly encouraged. It overthrew one family-dominated company after another, "all in the name of greater efficiency."
Aldrich's theory is fine so far as it goes, but a more powerful factor, it seems to me, was that business simply became cool in the 1980's -- and has remained so ever since. And this had nothing whatsoever to do with Reagan or with the government's promoting the values of the self-made man. It was because out in Silicon Valley, a new kind of industry was being born. It wasn't dirty or slick. It didn't require digging holes in the ground. Instead, it was a futuristic industry that was clean and fun. It took place in an office -- or more famously in a garage. The only equipment required was a computer and a brain. It was run by a bunch of wide-eyed kids who captured the public's imagination. They weren't just out to make money: they were idealistic and were going to change the world -- or so they said. And, oh yes, it turned out to be the greatest creator of instant wealth this nation has ever seen. In a sense, New Money became respectable the moment it was connected to a California computer start-up instead of to a Texas oil well.
On the whole, the respect given to New Money is laudable. In a country that claims to celebrate achievement, it is nice to see business achievement getting its due. The old entrepreneurs used to say that "money is a way of keeping score," and to an astonishing degree, the culture now accepts that idea. At the very least, it's a good thing that we're no longer so quick to sniff at the making of money -- an activity, after all, that drives our economy (and puts food on our tables).
And yet, I can't help missing something. For underlying this change are all the old issues that have always formed the subtext of Old versus New -- issues of class and "sophistication." It wasn't the Texas oilman's riches that caused the elites to shun him; it was his tastes. He preferred a slab of beef to foie gras; he listened to country music instead of to Chopin; and when he wanted to buy some expensive artwork for the house, it was more likely to be a Western Remington sculpture than a European Impressionist painting. The elites saw the entrepreneur's wealth as less attributable to real skill than to his happening upon the right hole in the ground.
The new entrepreneurs are nothing if not tasteful. Their industry revolves around "brain power." It is populated by kids who have gone to the best schools (or, better yet, have dropped out of the best schools, as Gates did: he was too smart for Harvard). They live in big, elegant homes. Ultimately, New Money has joined the ranks of the elites because most of the new billionaires are elitists. They don't think they are, but they are. The have the same general tastes and sophistication that used to mark Old Money.
I remember when I first realized this, about 10 years ago, while I was working on an article about Steve Jobs. I was living in Texas and had gained a great fondness for the old New Money men I'd met there -- oil prospectors, flamboyant real-estate types and the like -- a fondness I still retain. But Jobs, I could instantly see, wasn't like them at all. He was, instead, an exemplar of the new New Money ethos that had begun to reign in California. There was nothing crass or grasping about him. He wore jeans, but the casualness was studied. His tastes were understated and modern. When we went out to dinner one night, he took me to a place that served nouvelle cuisine and ordered a beautiful bottle of wine. Then he drove in a sleek foreign import to his big, elegant home.
And there was this: Jobs professed to care not at all about money. This has also become part of the Silicon Valley ethos -- everybody there claims not to be doing it for the money. "I was pretty comfortable before," Marc Andreessen of Netscape told Fortune magazine two years ago -- when he was worth about $100 million. "I'm just sort of more comfortable now."
So, has New Money acquired the values that used to be associated with the Old? I suppose so. But I've got to tell you, it makes me long for the Texas oilman. There was something finally, reassuringly democratic about the notion that anyone lucky enough to hit a gusher could become an instant millionaire. And in his willingness to be loud, to admit that he wanted to get rich, he was at least being honest. Can the New Money boys in California really say the same?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 62; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2472 words

HEADLINE: Taking the Starch Out of Status

BYLINE: By Alan Wolfe 

 BODY:
Of all the inequalities around us, those involving status are surely the most benign. Status's main rivals -- wealth and power -- are, to those who want them badly enough, worth killing for. No wonder those who study economics and politics tend to be, in William James's term, "hardheaded, hardhearted and hardfisted." Pursuing wealth or power means treating the world as composed of isolated individuals, each seeking a cutthroat advantage over everyone else.
Status is made of far softer stuff. It is, for one thing, more subjective than either money or clout. Owning the company or commanding the troops gives you certain privileges irrespective of whether the folks whose destiny you control admire (or even like) you. But the qualities that constitute status exist in the eyes of the beholder, not the possessor; if ordinary people did not admire exquisite taste, athletic prowess, stunning beauty or insider knowledge, no one could acquire prestige by monopolizing them. Those who seek status, no matter how snobbish their disdain for those who lack it, have no choice but to recognize people of lower status as important enough to give them what they need. Status is therefore symbiotic: we look up to people of high status, but those fortunate souls are equally dependent on us. 
 Status is also simply more interesting than wealth and power -- perhaps because, being so intangible, it is so much harder to control. Ask Bill Gates, who found it easier to make billions of dollars than to gain admission to the Augusta National Golf Club. Or Isaac Mizrahi, who has maintained his coolness quotient despite having bombed as a businessman. When the economist tells us how much a person or corporation earns, the story is over. When we learn how much status a person may have, the questions have only begun. If we want the world to resemble a balance sheet or a lawyer's brief, we can be satisfied with wealth and power. If we like the world mysterious and ironic, we ought to appreciate status.
It is, I admit, a little hard to celebrate status when those who once monopolized it -- the blue-blood aristocracy -- gave it such a bad name. There is something downright embarrassing about such old-school signs of elitism: debutantes, bridge tournaments, junior leagues, burial vaults. Taking appearance as reality, those once charged with the responsibilities of status confused their mandate to entertain us with a mandate to rule us. Their chattering frivolity was fun in films like "The Philadelphia Story," but when it came to excluding Jews, women and blacks from top schools -- and promoting their own to corporate boards -- status became more sinister.
Rebelling against the sheer absurdity of distinctions based on birth and breeding, however, Americans have largely cleaned up the status game. They have dismissed private clubs as sexist or racist. They have voiced their preference for meritocracies over old-boy networks. They have even taken pleasure in the improbable romance between an aristocrat and her social inferior as the Titanic sinks. Proms are still in, but prom kings and queens are out -- while Big Men on Campus are not especially big and most certainly not men.
At the same time, those institutions truly deserving respect have, by and large, maintained their cachet. We can bicker about whether a particular college should have been ranked a bit higher or lower by U.S. News & World Report, yet we accept that most rankings do a fairly good job of dividing prestigious institutions from mediocre ones. The position of United States Supreme Court Justice routinely appears very high on surveys of job prestige -- probably because our top judges generally have done a fine job interpreting the Constitution. Artistic endeavor, culinary expertise, ministerial authority: none of these qualities are easy to define, yet it is a source of continuous wonder that status in such areas generally goes to those not only with the most talent but also with the determination to put their talent to use. As Americans have come to realize, just because status exists in the eyes of others does not mean that the others are always wrong. Granted, a few anti-status extremists have tried to flatten the social landscape by abolishing class rankings in schools, refusing to keep score in their kids' soccer matches and finding fault with whatever role models cross their path. But the majority of Americans recognize that there is something to be said for assigning high status to those people who, year after year, maintain their prestige in a world filled with competitive rivals.
Indeed, without status, human social life would barely be worth living. As much as we may dislike distinctions because they offend our egalitarian sensibilities, we require distinctions for the same reason we have borders between states. They make possible a map of the social territory capable of guiding us through the myriad institutions and practices that surround us. In a world without wealth, we would be poor. In a world without power, we would be impotent. But in a world without status, we would literally be lost. So automatically do we assign things into rankable categories -- even as we then immediately suspect the categories we create -- that we come to take status for granted, rarely recognizing how important its markers are to defining who and what we are.
Yes, the skeptic might respond, distinctions are necessary, but arbitrary distinctions, the stuff of status as we generally understand that term, are not. Since at least "The Marriage of Figaro," we have loved to unmask the pretension of status, to affirm that ordinary people are, if anything, more authentic than their hypocritical superiors. Yet there is even something to be said in favor of distinctions that are unable to justify themselves by the cold logic of merit. As much as our democratic sympathies rebel at the arbitrary ways some people get to be counts -- or, in our world rather than that of Beaumarchais and Mozart, obtain a "legacy" admission at Princeton or win the rewards given to a bond trader who happens to guess correctly -- our curiosity is nonetheless piqued. Arbitrary distinctions -- from having a trust fund to having blond hair -- furnish the raw material for our satires and become the butt of our jokes. We are attracted to them precisely because they are arbitrary, for they remind us of how little of the world we really can plan and predict. It is as if, unable to believe that we can ever do completely without hierarchies of distinction, we instead create essentially silly ones and then spend most of our time mocking them. (Surely the recipient of the gentlemanly "C" in college will become a gentlemanly alcoholic, while the bond trader will lose as arbitrarily as he gained.) In novels like "The Financier" and "The Titan," Theodore Dreiser wrote about moneyed worlds in which distinctions had real consequences -- and nobody reads them. Jane Austen wrote about seemingly frivolous social status and everyone reads her.
The very accidental qualities that render status distinctions unfair, moreover, also render them safe. Possessors of high status often think that what gives them prestige in one area can be used in another. They are almost always wrong. Sammy Sosa or Mark McGwire may be exalted as sports heroes -- but because their status was achieved by training themselves, however skillfully, in the essentially arbitrary act of hitting home runs, they are excluded from applying their status in other realms of endeavor, like business. Similarly, a chemistry whiz may find that social acceptance eludes her. And a downtown hipster may find himself rejected by a conservative co-op board.
Fortunately you need not spend much time justifying the absurdities of inherited status, for we are living through a period when status is being transformed in America. If we cannot help being fascinated by endless speculation about who is up and who is down, we can take comfort in the fact that status is increasingly being stripped of the pretensions of an earlier time. Now subject to the same democratic energy that has revolutionized our economy and our technology, status can energize and excite just as it once deadened and stultified.
Consider, when it comes to status, how much is in play. Venerable law firms -- the kind depicted in the drippingly status-conscious novels of Louis Auchincloss -- are either driven into bankruptcy or taken over by younger partners more willing to put in billable hours than to be pictured at black-tie charity events. Moreover, the corporate lawyer, as a breed, is now subjected to continuous scorn from journalists and stand-up comics (both professions with prestige problems of their own). Tennis survives, but sustained only by the outrageous antics of bad boys who flaunt their disdain for Wimbledon whites yet are far more athletic than their genteel predecessors. Those who keep the ancient art of polo alive by financing it also insist, despite their lack of skill, that they be allowed to play, but without their support, there would be no polo to play. Prestigious academic institutions that once paid their faculty poorly -- "You mean you actually plan to live on your salary?" the dean of a Seven Sisters college exclaimed to a friend of mine when he first sought academic employment -- now, in the face of raiding tactics by on-the-make schools in the South and the West, offer deals too cozy to be refused. A younger group of politicians, calling themselves conservative of all things, seek prestige, not by joining, but by attacking, the Establishment. What once made Sammy run now makes all of us run.
Status, in short, has persevered, the decline of the WASP notwithstanding; it has just been turned upside down. Formerly associated with the well bred, status was assumed to be quiet. These days, it often clings to the loud and the brash. Under the rule of noblesse oblige, the person of status was under an obligation to use his privilege for some public purpose; today status is acquired for the sake of status, an end in itself rather than a byproduct of, or means to, something else. Status was once the kind of thing that, if you had to ask who had it, you betrayed that you did not. Now so rapidly does the terrain shift from one day to the next that we all need guides to know with whom it lies.
Newly acquired wealth did not purchase status; if anything, it delayed its arrival. Now the rich try to convert their wealth to status before the age of 40, wanting for themselves what John D. Rockefeller knew he could bequeath only to his children and grandchildren. Occupations once associated with status -- the priesthood, the military -- can no longer automatically guarantee it. And some people who earned their status the traditional way (Colin Powell comes to mind) convey the sense that they are not especially interested in using the status they have.
This democratization of status constitutes the Revenge of the Bypassed. Those engineering students with slide rulers in their pockets who were never invited to the high-school beer bash are now approached for donations to our cultural institutions. Kids from the inner city who lacked the educational credentials so valued by our society not only entertain us with their athletic or musical ability but also become taste makers for the society as a whole. Two Jewish guys looking for a prestigious state to identify with their ice cream choose once economically depressed Vermont. Celebrities like Roseanne flaunt, rather than hide, their white-trash backgrounds. The lowly bagel replaces the lofty croissant. For a few months, the beer of choice in the fanciest Manhattan bars comes from Mexico, not Europe. Your publisher suddenly wants you on Oprah, not in The New York Review of Books.
None of this necessarily represents the triumph of bad taste. Just like the old elites, upstart Americans -- the kind dismissed by cultural critics like Dwight MacDonald for their "midcult" sensibilities -- prefer Monet to paint-by-numbers, even if they look at the paintings at a Las Vegas hotel called Bellagio instead of at MOMA. More and more Americans opt to spend a weekend in Paris rather than at the Jersey Shore. Pavarotti, maybe even Puccini, has become a household word. Even in Arkansas these days, the cappuccino is top-notch.
Ought we to lament this transformation in the nature of status? By all means, no. What is actually taking place in America is a decent compromise between a system of inherited status and all its snobbish pretension and a system without status and all its poverty of the imagination. It is as if the part of us that does not like status has fought the part of us that needs status to a draw. Status is not being eliminated; it is being made more freewheeling and fun.
For all our determination to kill off older forms of status, they are dying of their own accord -- and the cause of their death is boredom. Breeding is an inefficient way to insure that some people will have respect in the eyes of others, for rarely can the qualities that enabled one person to rise to the top be passed down beyond one generation. Edith Wharton and Henry James could make something of the upper class at the end of the 19th century. By the end of the 20th, there is not a whole lot left to make much of anything. Inventive people that we are, Americans have decided to keep status but to bring creativity to the ways it is defined. This not only means that we do not know in advance who will have status and who will not; it also means that we cannot easily predict what will provide status and what will not.
Revolutions in status give us all the excitement of rapid social change with little of the accompanying turmoil. Unlike swings in the stock market, which churn the stomach and leave victims on the floor, transformations in status enable us to participate vicariously in the irresistibly fascinating game of dividing winners from losers. Computer geeks, up 300 points! Journalists, down 50! And because the stakes involved in struggles over status are less bloody than they are in politics, status revolutions enable us to purge ourselves of old ways without purging ourselves of actual people.
Status transformations have their victims and their costs, but if there is going to be rapid change, then let it be over symbols. No one knows who will be in America's status elite tomorrow. But we do know that just as we will have the rich and the poor and the powerful and the powerless, some will have more status than others. Perhaps we will learn, even as we are bothered by the unfairness of the whole thing, to appreciate with the right kind of ironic detachment our status distinctions. As distinctions go, they really are not so bad.

SECTION: Section 2A; Page 42; Column 3; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY MOVIES;
An A-List Writer, Minus the Attitude

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
ASK a studio mogul, top producer or agent for the names of the superior screenwriters in Hollywood, and Steven Zaillian will be near the top of the list.
"He's one of the two or three best screenwriters in town, and I'm being liberal when I say that," said Joe Roth, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, which made "A Civil Action," the newest film written and directed by Mr. Zaillian. "There's an economy and clarity to his writing that's always entertaining." 
 Mr. Zaillian, who won an Academy Award for his adaptation of "Schindler's List," is a surprisingly diffident, almost modest and entirely un-Hollywood figure. In contrast to other screenwriters, who may earn lavish sums but complain all the way to the bank about their plight at the hands of producers, stars and executives, Mr. Zaillian, 45, shrugs off any problems he has faced over his 18-year career. "Maybe I've been lucky," he said one recent morning as he sat drinking coffee on the patio of a house in Mandeville Canyon where he and his small staff were editing "A Civil Action."
"I mean, not every script I've worked on has turned out the way I've wanted them to turn out," added Mr. Zaillian. His screenplay for "Awakenings" (1990) earned him an Academy Award nomination, and he also wrote such films as "The Falcon and the Snowman," "Mission Impossible" and "Clear and President Danger."
But, he went on, "If you're going to write and not control it then, somehow, you've got to expect that sometimes it's going to turn out different than you thought. Sometimes worse. And sometimes better, if the director is, like, really good and brings something to it," Mr. Zaillian said.
"A Civil Action," adapted by Mr. Zaillian from the Jonathan Harr nonfiction legal drama that was on The New York Times best-seller list for two years, opens in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 25, in order to qualify for Academy Award nominations, and then will open nationwide in January.
The movie deals with an eight-year fight by working-class families in Woburn, Mass., who claimed that two large corporations had contaminated their town's drinking water with chemicals, causing the deaths of five children and one adult.
The central figure in the film is Jan Schlichtmann, a self-possessed personal injury lawyer who becomes consumed with the case at the cost of virtually everything else in his life. The film stars John Travolta as the lawyer and Robert Duvall as his highly skilled adversary. Also in the cast are William H. Macy, Tony Shalhoub, Zeljko Ivanek, Kathleen Quinlan, John Lithgow, Sydney Pollack and Kathy Bates.
Mr. Zaillian said he had first read the book, in manuscript form, when one of the producers, Rachel Pfeffer, sent it to him.
"I didn't know if it would make a movie at all," he said. "I had to write the script to see if I could make sense of what was 1,200 pages of manuscript. It was a wonderful book, but what was troubling about it for a movie was the sheer length of it, the number of characters, and it wasn't a whodunit. It was more about the process of the law -- and is that dramatic?"
Mr. Zaillian smiled. "Also, there was the fact that everybody loses, at least on the face of it," he said. "That's not usually the typical movie fare. It's a tragedy. I mean, that was the thing that we all had to keep in mind. I mean, it's really kind of remarkable that the studio let us do it."
Mr. Zaillian said he had handled the adaptation much the way he had dealt with "Schindler's List," the Thomas Keneally novel based on the Holocaust. For both screenplays he rigorously concentrated on the main character and avoided the pitfalls of trying to tackle the enormity of the historical circumstances. In "Schindler's List," for example, about a German profiteer who saves the lives of more than 1,000 Jews during World War II, Mr. Zaillian would have been overwhelmed as a screenwriter if he had decided to take on the Holocaust.
"I wanted to focus on Schindler, and Schindler alone, and imagine events almost entirely through his eyes," Mr. Zaillian said. "It's such an imposing subject that you can be overwhelmed by trying to tell too much of it and having too many angles on it. The point was to follow him, just follow him, stick with him, and what he learns about the subject, you learn. The same is true of this one."
In shaping the script for "A Civil Action," Mr. Zaillian said, the environmental drama and the legal story, and even the human tragedies, were secondary to the story of one man's obsession with the case. "It's ultimately his story," he said.
Mr. Zaillian is far more ambivalent about directing than screenwriting. His directorial debut, in August 1993, was a gentle family drama with an unfortunate title, "Searching for Bobby Fischer," which was far less about chess than about a family's relationships. Few films opened that summer with higher critical praise, but it proved a box-office disappointment.
Mr. Zaillian shrugged. "Sure, it's a bit depressing," he said. "It's sort of like you work really hard on something for a long time and it lasts two or three weeks and you think, 'I'm going to kill myself.' It's too much work not to have people see it, although the funny thing about 'Bobby Fischer' is, almost everybody I meet has seen it, and not just people in the industry. Maybe it's the bargain matinee. Maybe it's the video."
He said the sheer difficulty of being a director had surprised him, and that was why it took him so long to take over another project. "I wasn't prepared for how hard it was -- I was spoiled by the life style of a writer," he said. "Being a director you face the pressure, the hours, the staying focused for six straight months or much longer on one thing, just so focused with a lot of money being spent. It took a lot out of me, and I didn't want to do it again. I just wanted to write a couple of scripts after that."
Mr. Zaillian does not see screenwriting as something to be taught with specific rules. "It's the same as any other kind of writing: it just has to be good, the ideas have to be clear and the writer has to convey them in a way that's interesting, and it doesn't matter whether it's a screenplay or novel," he said.
And he is loath to analyze what makes a great screenplay. "You hear about these books and courses on screenwriting," he said. "On page 20 something has to happen. The character arc and all that stuff. I have no idea. I don't think about those things. Every time I do it, it feels like the first time and I'm scared and I don't know if it's going to turn out. And if I get to page 50 or so and I'm not enjoying it, then I know it's not working."
"The tone of the movie is the magic thing for me," he said. "That's like the big battle. The tone and the voices and how people sound. The level of realism. That's what matters to me."
Scott Rudin, one of the producers of "A Civil Action," said of him:"There's not one wasted moment in the way he tells a story. And there's a compassionate strain in his writing that most people don't come close to. The way he directs is exactly the way he writes. It's about the accumulation of detail; it's very methodical, very empathetic and very compassionate."
Mr. Zaillian, who is married and has two sons, grew up in Los Angeles. His father, Jim Zaillian, who died in 1980, was a radio news reporter. After he graduated from San Francisco State University in 1975, an interest in making documentaries led him to a series of low-level film editing jobs. Then a script he wrote in 1979 called "Bad Manners," about high school boys in the late 1960's, caught the attention of Ray Stark's producing company. Soon, Mr. Zaillian was being hired to write scripts.
"For a long time I wouldn't call myself a writer, it was so hard to say the word," he recalled. "I would say, 'I write.' But I didn't consider myself a writer until I did three or four. I kept thinking it was going to end and it wouldn't last."
Asked about his unfortunate experiences, Mr. Zaillian said without hesitation, "Jack the Bear." This strange 1993 comedy-drama starring Danny DeVito was about the unraveling of a television horror show host whose psychopathic neighbor poses a threat to children. "People got hired and it just got taken away from me," he said. "I don't want to bad-mouth anybody; these things happen. But it so upset me that I said to Scott Rudin, who I've known for a long time, 'I want to do this again, write another thing about kids, but do it right.' And that's how 'Bobby Fischer' happened."
Besides being relatively modest, Mr. Zaillian is also surprisingly loyal, at least by Hollywood standards. Although any of the major talent agencies would welcome the high-priced Mr. Zaillian as a client, he has remained loyal to Harold Greene, his first agent, who is now in his mid-80's and who runs a one-man agency in Marina del Ray, Calif.
"If I'm missing something, I don't know what it is," Mr. Zaillian said, smiling: "I always think I'm working on the best things that are being done out there. I haven't worked on anything because I needed the money or done something that I didn't believe in."

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS: UP AND COMING -- Famke Janssen;
Transformations As a Way of Life, Not Just on Screen

BYLINE: By JUSTINE ELIAS; Justine Elias writes about film, television and theater from New York.

 BODY:
IN "The Faculty," which opens on Christmas Day, Famke Janssen plays a timid, bespectacled high school teacher, a woman whose voice quavers when she urges a promising but wayward student to apply himself. Since the movie is a thriller directed by Robert Rodriguez ("Desperado") and written by Kevin Williamson ("Scream"), it is safe to expect that the shy educator will undergo a radical shift in personality and appearance before the final reel. Then it should be easy to recognize Ms. Janssen as the confident actress who has given a series of witty, engaging performances in relatively small parts: the Russian-born owner of a gambling joint in "Rounders," the bitter, alcoholic ex-wife of a Southern lawyer in "The Gingerbread Man" and a tough, blue-collar Bostonian in "Monument Avenue." In "Celebrity," a Woody Allen film that opens on Nov. 20, she plays a sophisticated editor in love with a neurotic, on-the-make writer played by Kenneth Branagh.
"I'm trying to fight typecasting as hard as I can, while I have time," says Ms. Janssen, who lives in Manhattan with her husband, the director and screenwriter Todd Williams. Though she earned good notices in 1995 for her performance as a lethal Russian spy named Xenia Onatopp in "Goldeneye," Ms. Janssen says that the international publicity she earned from being a Bond Girl led her to reject offers to play glamorous, cartoonlike leading women and to seek out more intriguing supporting roles. "Once you achieve a certain level of success or fame, it becomes really difficult to go against type. This is a good time for me to experiment." 
 Though it is hard to imagine Ms. Janssen blending into a crowd -- she is 5 feet 11 inches, and her exotic beauty has been compared to that of 1940's stars like Hedy Lamarr -- her colleagues praise this very quality, as well as her dedication and humor. Denis Leary, who acted with Ms. Janssen in "Monument Avenue," says he didn't recognize Ms. Janssen when first saw her in the film's Boston production office. "She came dressed in character, in leather pants and denim, and I walked right by her," he says. "I thought she was someone from the neighborhood, auditioning for a small role," he says. "She spent a few days hanging around, and within a few days she had the accent down. I was really impressed."
Ms. Janssen's ability to adopt a convincing regional accent -- Slavic by way of Brooklyn, Savannahian, or blue-collar Bostonian, to name a few -- is all the more surprising because English is not her native language. The 34-year-old was born in Amsterdam, and she did not move to the United States until she was in her early twenties. By that time, she had dropped out of her Dutch university, where she was studying economics, and spent several years working in Europe as a fashion model. She arrived in New York with enough money saved to join an acting workshop and re-enroll in college -- this time as a creative writing and literature student at Columbia University.
Though Ms. Janssen now sounds thoroughly American, an agent urged her to change her name to avoid being perceived as foreign. (Her first name, unusual even in her native country, means "little girl" in the Friesland dialect.) "I know actors do it all the time, but I felt I'd be losing my identity," Ms. Janssen says. "Instead, I worked harder on losing my accent."
She did, however, make one concession for her career: convinced that she would have a better chance at getting film work, she spent five unsatisfying years as a struggling actress in Los Angeles, playing a crime-fighting supermodel in a television movie, and an object of desire in a "Star Trek: The Next Generation" episode called "The Perfect Mate."
At this stage of her career, she says, her success is tied to the director. "It's really in the director's hands, and I've tried to work with directors who consistently do their own thing. If you do well as an actor, a good director will pick up on it, and keep it in the film."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I'm trying to fight typecasting," says Famke Janssen, left, whose roles have ranged from a Russian spy in "Goldeneye" to a timid teacher, above, in "The Faculty," opening on Dec. 25. (Photos by Robin Holland for The New York Times and Miramax Films)

HEADLINE: WORKING;
Seeing the Fruit Of One's Labor

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I recently switched from a small, hands-on company to a large, hierarchical one. Adjusting has been a bit of a struggle. Before, I had a say in all aspects of the business, and I saw the impact I had. Now, I'm a widget handler and wonder if I am adding any value to the company's products. What should I do: stay put and work my way up to a position where I'll clearly make a difference, or go back to being a big frog in a small pond? 

A. As far as corporate culture shock goes, nothing is quite as depressing as feeling that you've signed on to be an inconsequential drone in a giant cubicle hive. But before you rush back to your former pasture, make sure you're not just suffering from the grass-is-greener syndrome.
Compile a list of everything you loathed about your old employer and reflect on whether the problems were related to the small, entrepreneurial nature of the place. (To keep you honest, talk with friends who can remind you how you complained while working there.)
Try to assemble as complete a picture as possible of your personality and work style, advised George Zeller, a senior employment specialist with Career Moves, a counseling service in Boston. You may even want to take one of those personality tests intended to reveal whether you're best equipped to be the chief financial officer of a multinational corporation, a French teacher or a zookeeper. But don't expect any big revelations, Mr. Zeller warned. In some ways, these tests just mirror what you already know.
Still, you might be discovering that you have landed in the wrong environment for your personality type. I asked Joseph Frey, a clinical psychologist in Augusta, Ga., for the Highlands Program, a career development firm, about your case, and he said you sounded like a "structural generalist."
The "structural" part of that phrase means that you need a hands-on type of job. You enjoy having a product that you can feel, see, or touch at the end of the day. But as a generalist, Mr. Frey said, you also like being part of a team and want a bit of diversity in your workday. Smaller companies are ideal environments for structural generalists, Mr. Frey said, while large, hierarchical firms often force such folks to choose between their dominant personality traits.
Even if you decide to stay with the larger firm, start planning your rise from dronedom. According to Mr. Zeller, a lot of people just want to get lost and be invisible, so you need to make it clear that you are not one of them. Volunteer for different assignments. Acquire as many skills and experiences as you can. Maintain a diary of your accomplishments. After a while, go to the boss and say, "For the past few months I did this. I did that. I went to training and picked up these skills. I helped Sally with that project. Now I want to take on a new project."
Some companies, of course, don't allow such cross-pollination among departments or positions. In that case, your only option may be to seek a less-rigid hive.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
A Planned Community Progresses in Smithtown

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: SMITHTOWN

 BODY:
FOR now, a 11.5-acre parcel on Terry Road is still a sea of sand, but it will soon become the site of a 29-house development called Coventry Village at the Galleria, where sales of the first 11 houses began last weekend.
The new project is the third phase of a much larger development called the Galleria, which, when completed, will not only include housing but also small neighborhood stores, a day-care center, a restaurant, other commercial space and possibly a supermarket. 
 The Galleria's distinction from most projects on Long Island is the way it was structured as a planned community, with elements that would complement one another in a cohesive fashion.
The project began 15 years ago when the DiCanio Organization of Smithtown began assembling properties along Terry Road -- occupied by a cement plant and sandmining operations, among others.
In all, DiCanio assembled 83 acres, which with additional purchases have since grown to 88 acres. Most of the land fronts on Terry Road, but a 1.5-acre section fronts on Route 347.
The property originally had some residential zoning, but most of it was zoned for industrial and commercial uses.
"I felt it would be good planning to place housing next to existing residential neighborhoods and to place businesses along the periphery of the site," said Vincent DiCanio, president of the DiCanio Organization.
Town planners were of like mind. The zoning on the various parcels, which dated back to 1932, "didn't make a lot of sense," said Frank DeRubeis, Smithtown's Planning Director.
"What we wanted to do was start with a fresh sheet of paper that eliminated the industrial zoning, reconfigured the neighborhood business zoning and put the residential portion in locations that made sense, to come up with what we felt was the best plan," Mr. DeRubeis said. "I wanted a neighborhood."
The master plan for the Galleria, which the town approved in 1989, not only provided a residential and commercial mix, but housing that offered something for everyone as well. There will be rental apartments for those not yet ready to purchase a home; town houses for young couples buying their first home and for older couples trading down from a larger house and detached houses for families with children.
The town also received a pledge that 50 of the rental units would be made available at below-market rents to town residents who made no more than 80 percent of the median income.
Four of the Galleria's six phases are residential. A property owners' association will act as an umbrella group to maintain an internal road that will link the various phases to one another and connect Terry Road to Route 347. Property owners will also maintain a private sewage treatment plant.
A 312-unit apartment complex called Avalon Commons owned by AvalonBay Communities of Alexandria, Va., already occupies a 20.6-acre portion of the 88-acre site and a 10,425-square-foot CVS Pharmacy, the first commercial development, is under construction on 1.5 acres next to the apartments. It is expected to open next month.
At Coventry Village, colonials designed by Axelrod & Cherveny, architects in Commack, will each have three bedrooms, spacious front porches and an attached two-car garage toward the rear of the house.
Prices for the initial 1,552- and 2,016-square-foot dwellings will be $209,990 and $219,990. At the end of the 30-day period there will be a $10,000 increase. Lots range in size from about 8,000 to more than 14,000 square feet. DiCanio is developing this phase of the project in a joint venture with Greenview Properties of Islip.
Still to come is a 187-unit town-house development called Windcrest at the Galleria that will occupy 33.9 acres. Prices there will range from $169,990 to $229,000. The two- and three-bedroom town houses ranging in size from 1,400 to 2,400 square feet will be sold under a condominium form of ownership. That phase is expected to open for sales by March.
The overall Galleria project also will include an enclave of 13 single-family houses to be called Galleria Heights, on which construction is to start on 7.5 acres some time next year. They will sell in the $279,000 to $329,000 range.
DEVELOPMENT of the Galleria was delayed for several years by the downturn in the economy that already had begun when the project won town approvals in 1989. Lenders also pulled their financial support for a number of DiCanio's projects, forcing the developer to file in 1991 for reorganization under Chapter 11. Chapter 11 stipulates that creditors must approve the payment plan.
Nevertheless, a joint-venture agreement with what then was Trammell Crow Residential, a Dallas builder, for the 312-unit rental development survived the Chapter 11 filing, and Avalon Commons became the first phase to move forward.
Ultimately, DiCanio sold its ownership interest in the joint venture to Avalon, a company formed in 1993 by the Northeast and MidAtlantic division of Trammell Crow Residential. Avalon purchased the 20.6 acres from DiCanio in 1996, the same year the rental community opened.
The apartment complex, which has 13 two-story gray clapboard buildings trimmed in white grouped around landscaped courtyards, a pool and a clubhouse, was an instant success.
It has enjoyed a 98 percent occupancy from the start, said Gary Steinfield, senior development director of AvalonBay Communities, the name of the real estate investment trust formed by Avalon and Bay Communities of San Jose, Calif., when they merged earlier this year.
Monthly rents for the market-rate apartments range from $1,250 for a one-bedroom to $1,725 for a three-bedroom. The 50 apartments in the town's affordable housing program rent for $750 for a one-bedroom and $935 for two bedrooms.
Mr. Steinfield praised the master plan concept, saying "it introduced a series of land uses that will complement each other."
"The day-care center for example will be a perfect complement because our development attracts a lot of young professional parents with children," he said. "And having a CVS on our doorstep will also be a great convenience."
The concept of designing a planned community is gaining popularity on Long Island.
Although Smithtown never adopted a zoning category for planned unit developments -- or PUD's as they are often called -- the Town of Brookhaven among others adopted zoning it called planned district development in 1996, and the Town of Oyster Bay is holding public hearings next month on such a proposal.
"These districts allow you to get away from the rigidity of traditional zoning and present a mix of uses that are appropriate to that particular site," said David J. Portman, president of Frederick P. Clark Associates, planners in Rye, N.Y., which was the planning consultant to both Brookhaven and Oyster Bay when the towns drafted their ordinances.
"The idea is to look at property in totality and to give the developer flexibility subject to town board approval," Mr. Portman said.
John Girandola, Commissioner of Planning for the Town of Brookhaven, said the town had adopted the zoning because it wanted to see "better proposals and better designs that would enhance the town." Tied in are requirements that if a developer requests higher density for a planned unit development than the zoning allows, it must provide a park or a recreational facility or other public benefit.
The planned community "is a rapidly emerging concept that has been used very effectively in the south and is now finding its way north," said John Venditto, the Oyster Bay Supervisor. "It's a good concept that is welcome here in the town of Oyster Bay."
Usually, planned unit development zoning is proposed when a particular development seems ideal for it. In Oyster Bay, for example, the Holiday Organization of Westbury has signed a contract to purchase 65 acres of town-owned land and has proposed building different categories of housing on the property ranging from attached to detached units. The proposal also includes some commercial space.
The downside of planned unit developments is that once the master plan has been agreed to, any changes have a domino effect, said Mr. DeRubeis, the Smithtown planner. "In a PUD you have a vision of how the community is supposed to work," Mr. DeRubeis said. "If you change one element, it has an impact on all the rest."
But Mr. DiCanio said that this is a risk he was willing to take. "You do have to have foresight," he said, "and hopefully the tenacity if something turns within the market to live with that decision."
He added that the years spent on planning and building the Galleria, with probably five more years yet to go, have been worth it.
"It's been a long road and one that has taken its twists and turns," he said. "But it's going to be quite rewarding to see the project completed and perhaps used as a model for other planned developments."

(Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1351 words

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
In Elizabeth, Outlets and Entertainment in a Mall

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WHEN the 1.3-million-square foot mall now rising on a former landfill in Elizabeth is completed next October, it will be the first in New Jersey to combine manufacturers' outlet stores and large discount retailers, as well as traditional large mall stores, with entertainment.
Set in an old industrial section of this Union County city, what is officially called the Jersey Gardens Value Megamall will also become the state's eighth largest shopping center and, its developers as well as city officials hope, a tourist attraction. It is to include more than 100 outlet stores, 33 large traditional mall stores, a 10,000-square-foot food court in a two-story building and parking space for 5,528 cars off Exit 13A of the New Jersey Turnpike. 
 So far, the entertainment portion has signed on six restaurants and Jeepers, a 25,000-square-foot family recreation center, including rides for children 12 and younger. And Loews Cineplex Entertainment, created in May by the merger of Sony/Loews Theaters and the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, will open its newest theater format, a 108,000-square-foot, 22-screen theater with 5,000 seats plus a lounge area and special reserved seats for those paying a premium on their tickets.
There will also be an as-yet undetermined sports component where some retailers will offer "reality-based shopping," which means customers will be able to test out their purchases.
Road and traffic improvements, from ramps to an elevated roadway, are now under way to connect the 130-acre development site to the Turnpike.
The developer is the Glimcher Realty Trust of Columbus Ohio, a real estate investment trust, or REIT, that secured its financing before Wall Street's recent travails. Michael Ovitz, former president of Walt Disney Company and, before that, head of Creative Artists Agency, is involved in the mall's entertainment component.
"What we are offering is an experience," said Michael Glimcher, senior vice president of development and leasing at the company, noting that nearly 65 percent of the space at the mall had been preleased.
Beyond Jeepers and Loews, other tenants that have signed on for space at the mall include: Annie Sez, a discount women's clothing store; Record Town SuperStore, Oshman's SuperSports USA, Bed Bath & Beyond, Off Fifth-Saks Fifth Avenue Outlet, Jewelers on Fifth and Mikasa, a tableware store. Rents, including common area maintenance charges, range from $20 to $165 a square foot and average $55. Leases run from five to 15 years.
Financing includes $140 million in tax-exempt bonds and grants from the semi-autonomous New Jersey Economic Development Authority, most of it for the road improvements, as well as a $163 million loan from Bankers Trust and Huntington National Bank. Glimcher is also investing $56 million of its own equity.
"The mall has been talked about for years; now it is a reality, creating a sense of excitement about the opportunity for jobs and additional economic development it will create," said J. Christian Bollwage, Mayor of Elizabeth. "In the 80's other cities around us developed. Now, it's our turn."
He said the mall has stirred early discussions about a possible arena for the New Jersey Metro Stars soccer team on a portion of a 200-acre undeveloped tract adjacent to the mall. The arena, he said, could help the area to become a tourist attraction.
Estimates by the city are that when the mall is complete it will generate 5,200 permanent jobs, as well as $4 million to $5 million in annual tax revenues. The city, Mayor Bollwage added, will also receive a similar amount from a tax on retailers of 3 percent of gross sales and "hard goods," such as appliances, electronics and furniture -- permitted under a 1996 state law specically targeting Elizabeth -- that can be levied on tenants in the mall, which sits within a state Urban Enterprise Zone. In such a zone businesses are offered tax breaks and retailers can charge a 3 percent sales tax instead of the normal 6 percent.
The idea of building a mall on the former landfill, which closed in 1972, dates to 1995. But preparing the site for development was started three years earlier by OENJ Corporation of Elizabeth, a land developer specializing in difficult sites.
IN June 1997 Glimcher bought 126 acres of the site from OENJ, which still owns 40 acres along Newark Bay that it will develop. The company would not disclose the price.
Location was a key reason the company got involved in the Elizabeth project, said Mr. Glimcher. He noted that the site offered "access to all of New Jersey as well as to Manhattan" and represented "an opportunity in an untapped market."
Some 180,000 cars pass the site daily and 15.2 million people with an average household income of $61,000 live within a 40-mile radius of it. Newark International Airport is five minutes away and just to the north sits an IKEA furnishings store, which was recently expanded by 80,000 square feet to 268,324 feet and attracts more than two million shoppers a year.
Those factors along with the appeal of the 3 percent sales tax and the mall's hybrid nature will serve it well, despite the stock market's recent mood swings and signs of tempered consumer confidence, its developers said and many retail brokers agree. "Consumers are cautious but they are not paranoid," said Ted Kraus, who heads TKO Real Estate Advisory Group, a retail consulting firm in Mercerville.
The uncertainties in the world's financial markets, he added, have not severely affected the retail market in New Jersey, where the statewide vacancy rate is under 3 percent and rents remain stable at $15 to $41 a square foot on average, up from $12 to $35 a square foot annually last year.
"If there is a downturn in the economy and consumer spending slows, traditional retailers will be more affected than discounters, who may be more in demand by shoppers looking for value," said Richard E. Kalvoda, manager at the Ridgewood office of the real estate advisory group for PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, a commercial brokerage in Woodbridge, added: "The expansion of the discount speciality chains, or category killers, which has started to put supply in front of demand, will accelerate and at that point, only the strong will survive."
While the location of the Elizabeth mall makes its retail potential clear, brokers say the area's entertainment draw is cloudy. "When you think of entertainment, you don't think of that area," said Mr. Kalvoda. Added Mr. Schultz: "It may take time to catch on."
The developers and Loews Cineplex are betting otherwise. "It's one of the few areas in the state that has a dense population and no theaters," said Mr. Glimcher.
To Loews Cineplex, "it is an unbelievable location that with the quality of the mall will have a regional draw," said Marc J. Pascucci, its vice president of advertising and publicity. He said the Elizabeth theater reflected his company's newest design, and will be first in the New York-New Jersey area. He likened what he called the V.I.P. lounge to skyboxes in sports stadiums. It will have its own concession stand as well as an area where liquor and light snacks will be sold. Patrons will pay a ticket premium of 25 to 30 percent, said Mr. Pascucci.
Mr. Glimcher said his company will offer van service to and from Newark Airport to draw travelers on long stopovers. It is also negotiating with a ferry operator to run a service from a location on the property along Newark Bay to and from Manhattan.
The movie theater and the mall are being designed by David Rockwell of Manhattan, who has been involved in designing many entertainment attractions, including the Academy Awards Theater in Hollywood and improvements to Radio City Music Hall.
Jersey Gardens will have an "earthy" exterior finish of brown, beige and green to reflect "its name and create a green oasis in an otherwise gray area," Mr. Glimcher said, adding that he expected the mall, which began construction last April, to attract more than 20 million visitors a year.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Westchester;
For Rye Brook, Intergenerational Housing

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
AN intergenerational approach to housing is taking shape at the Belle Fair development here, where work has begun on the first component, a combination of 170 detached houses and 46 duplexes on the site of the 140-acre former High Point Psychiatric Hospital on King Street.
Next month ground will be broken for the second and last component, Chancellor Park, a 168-apartment building for independent living for the elderly. The two components will form the county's first community integrating separate accommodations for the elderly with residences for all ages.
The houses were first marketed in late June and so far a total of 103 have sold from blueprints, according to Mitchell C. Hochberg, president of Spectrum Skanska, of Valhalla, one of three partners in the project. The others are the Benenson Capital Company of Manhattan and CareMatrix Corporation of Needham, Mass. 
 "When sales began prices started in the mid-$300,000's," Mr. Hochberg said. "Now they range from the low-$400,000's to the mid-$600,000's." The housing embraces a wide variety of styles and sizes, including three-and four-bedroom houses and duplexes, the latter designed for empty-nesters and retirees.
"The intergenerational aspect is one of the most important parts of Belle Faire," Mr. Hochberg said. The entire project, based on principles of what architects and planners call the new urbanism, aims to have some aspects of life in a small village.
All roads will lead to a village green at the center of the development, where there will be a general store, an outdoor swimming pool with a terraced deck, and a community center with an indoor swimming pool, a gym, a health club, a catering kitchen and a library with computers.
Chancellor Park is being developed by CareMatix, which currently operates 44 residential and assisted-living projects for the elderly. In addition, 22 more are expected to open in the next six months, said Michael Zaccaro, an executive vice president.
For CareMatrix, Chancellor Park is also the first independent-living building for the elderly to be constructed as part of a larger residential community, with people of all ages. However, three years ago the company built one of its retirement communities in an already established multi-age development, in Bonita Bay, Fla.
"But Belle Fair is the first time we've been partners in the development of the multi-age community at the same time we're building our own project," said Mr. Zaccaro. "It creates greater opportunities to really integrate the two projects together. I don't know of any other examples of this kind of partnership anywhere in the country." His company is now looking at starting similar projects in Florida, California and North Carolina.
Chancellor Park will be housed in one three-story building whose focal points will be two interior courtyards, according to Amy Carpenter, senior manager, at the Martin Architecture Group, based in Philadelphia, which is designing the project.
"Many of the units will look out on the courtyards," she added, noting that one courtyard would be used for al fresco dining. The other will be a garden setting, with seating, meandering paths and lots of landscaping, Ms. Carpenter said.
THE main entrance to the building will feature a lobby dominated by a circular staircase and two-story limestone fireplace, she added. The lobby's floor will have four different kinds of marble, and the walls will be accented in pickled oak trim.
"We needed to make the building appear residential and elegant to fit in with the rest of the complex," Ms. Carpenter said. "Nothing has been spared to create a truly elegant space."
Physically integrating the building to the rest of the development was also essential, Ms. Carpenter added. Since Chancellor Park is on a slightly lower grade than the rest of Belle Faire, a pedestrian bridge and ramp were designed to link the building to the complex's swimming pool, community house, and other amenities.
Rents at Chancellor Park will start at $2,700 a month for a studio to $4,550 for a two-bedroom apartment. That will include services such as housekeeping, meals and local transportation. There will also be a one-time community fee, ranging from $3,000 to $5,000, based on the size of the apartment. "We charge that to cover our costs of having to refurbish an apartment each time it's vacated," Mr. Zaccaro said.
Other residents of Belle Fair, whatever their age, will also be able to use the services at Chancellor Park, on an individual fee basis, Mr. Zaccaro added. "They can come to Chancellor Park and participate in the meals," he said. "We can also provide housekeeping and transportation services on an as-needed basis."
CONSTRUCTION has already begun at Belle Fair and the first homes are expected to be delivered in March, according to Mr. Hochberg. At the current sales space, he added, all houses will be completed in two to three years. Chancellor Park is expected to be completed within 18 months of the ground-breaking.
Since the project will border the Westchester County Airport, several noise-reduction features have been added, such as triple-pane windows and extra insulation.
"We already have deposits on 25 percent of the units, which is a lot more than we counted on getting prior to construction," said Mr. Zaccaro. Most of the people who have already signed up to live at Chancellor Park are from central Westchester, and "it's about an even mix of singles and couples," he said.
This will be CareMatrix's second project in Westchester. The other is Cambridge House, a 112-apartment rental development that opened in Ossining 11 months ago. "There the units are a lot smaller than at Chancellor Park," Mr. Zaccaro said. "There are more studios and one bedrooms, starting at $2,200 a month."
Mr. Zacarro added that there was a great need for more of these projects, especially at the level of Chancellor Park. "With rents starting at $2,700, that requires an income of $35,000 or more," he explained. "Fifty-nine percent of seniors living in the New York region have incomes higher than that. And that's not even counting other assets they may have."
The reason more such projects have not been developed is that the approval process is a lot more difficult in Westchester than in most other places around the country, Mr. Zaccaro said. The plans for Chancellor Park were first proposed in 1995. "Site procurement, obtaining permits and approvals, it takes a long time," Mr. Zaccaro said.
"The cost of doing business in the county makes it very difficult," he added. "As a result, a lot of other companies shy away. The upside for us is that if you get to actually complete a project, the pent-up demand is tremendous."

(Martin Architectural Group)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Historic Districts Council's Annual Preservation Award;
Honoring a Landmarks Lion

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
"Landmarks Lion" is the name of the Historic Districts Council's annual award to devoted, aggressive preservationists. In its choice of James Marston Fitch this year, the council found a lion with a considerable mane and formidable roar.
As head of the preservation program at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation through 1977, Mr. Fitch educated a generation of professionals who went on to fill the staff ranks at the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, Municipal Art Society and New York Landmarks Conservancy. 
 "He has been an enormous influence through the course he started at Columbia," said Jane Jacobs, no small influence herself since the publication of "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" in 1961. "His students are everywhere now."
Though cloaked in a soft Tennessee cadence, Mr. Fitch's voice has been unmistakably strong over more than 40 years on the front lines of preservation. He has espoused unpopular causes (he championed cast-iron buildings when the whole Victorian period was held in low esthetic repute) and has not shied from disparaging contemporary architects ("frivolous" is a term he has used more than once).
Indeed, he is currently having trouble writing the closing chapter of his next book, "The Architecture of the American People: 1621-2000," because he so disapproves of postmodern architecture.
Even his colleagues at Beyer Blinder Belle, where he directed the preservation program after retiring from Columbia, were not immune from his criticism. Mr. Fitch said he would have opposed the firm's plans to replace the facade of the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South. (The project, for Donald J. Trump, was scuttled in April.)
But it would be a great mistake to view Mr. Fitch simply as an 89-year-old curmudgeon. At Beyer Blinder Belle, he was deeply involved with the decision to build a new east stairway in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal, where the Landmarks Lion ceremony will be held tomorrow.
He has also been finishing the third edition of "American Building: The Environmental Forces That Shape It," first published in 1948, which Oxford University Press will bring out in January.
Running through his work is the theme of architectural preservation as a form of environmental conservation. He has argued that if the cost of razing and replacing old buildings is measured not only in economic terms but in the expenditure of energy -- literally, in British thermal units -- preservationists have a much stronger case.
Twenty years ago, Mr. Fitch said, "The time may come when too many old buildings are being saved -- but that time is not yet foreseeable."
Last week, he offered an update, with typical fervor: "The number of buildings that deserve preservation has grown enormously. If you approach buildings from the standpoint of conserved energy, they present a priceless resource. The whole idea that a building with a facade that is slightly out of fashion is not worth conservation is grotesque." DAVID W. DUNLAP

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Marston Fitch. (Barbara Alper for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Habitats / 419 East 140th Street;
Wandering U.N. Aide Finds a Home in South Bronx

BYLINE: By By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
SAM OGLESBY had worked overseas in economic development for the United Nations for 25 years, living in Thailand, Burma, Indonesia, Bhutan and Bangladesh.
In 1989 he was back in New York, working at the headquarters and living in a studio apartment on the Upper West Side. Because he liked walking, he spent hours roaming through the city's neighborhoods and found himself charmed by brownstones. He decided he had to have one of his own. 
 With the eyes of a stranger, he visited places like Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope, Carroll Gardens and Boerum Hill. But he had only $200,000 to spend, and even five years ago, when he really began his search for a house, they were out of reach. He wanted something architecturally interesting, and no more than 30 minutes from midtown.
Relatively quickly, he became enamored of Harlem, attracted to its atmosphere and its history. But he had no luck. Maybe it was timing. Maybe he wasn't decisive enough. In 1996, he almost bought a house in Morningside Valley for $90,000, but while he was worrying that it would be too complicated to untangle its problematic certificate of occupancy, someone else bought the house. Frustrated and disappointed, he gave up.
But after a while, reinvigorated by an article that described the Mount Morris area in Harlem, he began exploring there. One day about six months ago, walking on Fifth Avenue near 125th Street, he approached a man sitting on a stoop and asked him if he knew of any houses for sale in the neighborhood.
The man said no, but he did know of a landmarked block in the South Bronx with a house for sale. The man, it turned out, was a real estate broker, and he arranged to show Mr. Oglesby the house at 419 East 140th Street in the Mott Haven section, where most of the residents are Spanish-speaking. On the day of their appointment, Mr. Oglesby took the Lexington Avenue subway to 138th Street, which is only 15 minutes from midtown.
When he walked out of the subway and up 138th Street, he found himself in a place that reminded him of the developing countries where he had lived.
"The shops are very simple, and poor," he said, "with big plantains and yams and mangoes, not plastic tomatoes. The little Mexican grocery store has music blaring out, and there are people hanging out on the street. There is one kind of toothpaste, not 10."
He had liked the idea of living in Harlem, but never quite felt accepted. In Mott Haven, he said, he felt like he had come home.
When he reached East 140th Street, which is lined with well-tended houses of different colors, "it was suddenly like a 1950's sitcom," he said, adding that "people were tending their gardens and smiling and talking."
IT was not at all like the Upper West Side. "There you're lucky if you get a hello in the elevator," he said. In fact, in an elevator once, making what he considered neighborly conversation, someone told him that he "overshares."
When he arrived at 419 East 140th Street, he found a three-story brick town house built in 1897, with three fireplaces, a solid staircase, appealing woodwork, a pretty little garden in front and a yard in the back. It was structurally sound, with obvious but fixable flaws. All of the wood floors were covered with linoleum that seemed to have been applied with glue of steel, and the walls were obscured with plastic paneling.The ceilings had been lowered and surfaced with Styrofoam panels.
Like most people who live in New York, however, he associated the South Bronx with devastation, with gangs and knifings and burned-out housing, even though that image had nothing to do with what he was seeing. So he went to the local police station and asked, "If I were your uncle, would you tell me to live in this neighborhood?" They gave him mixed advice. "One said it's a good block," he recalled. "Another said, 'Don't do it.' "
He chose to believe in the believers.
Mr. Oglesby bought the house for $113,000, which was $6,000 less than the asking price. He had retired from the United Nations at the beginning of 1997 when he was 58, but was able to get a mortgage from the credit agency there, and when the house was appraised it was valued at $140,000. The taxes are only $595 a year. It is a landmarked block, and some of the houses, he said, are very elaborate, with marble floors and lavish moldings.
He closed in July, and since then has been working with friends, many of them from Indonesia, to renovate the building. He has also hired an Indonesian contractor who is putting in a new kitchen on the ground floor.
On the main floor, he has exposed gracious 12-foot ceilings. The center room, once a bathroom, will be his library, and is now being supplemented with books about the Bronx.
In the living room, he ripped out a closet and discovered a graceful arched opening that makes the perfect backdrop for his carved day bed from Thailand. Like all of the furniture collected during his years in Asia, it can go into a small van, because it is made from panels. "These pieces were built before nails," he said.
ON the top floor, he has turned the front room into his bedroom, furnishing it with a grand four-poster bed that looks as though it must have come from his travels, but turns out to have been recently bought on sale at Macy's. He has also stripped the paint from oak woodwork around the windows in the bedroom.
The back room, a guest bedroom, has, like the main bedroom, large closets. There is so much space he literally doesn't know what to do with it. Asked what he will do with the front room, opposite the living room, he said: "I don't know. Help me decide."
Not counting the value of his own labor, or the contributions of his friends, he figures it will cost about $15,000 to renovate the house. He will try to fix the outside, which is cracking and crumbling, with a grant from the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, which gives up to $15,000 per homeowner to help people of modest means preserve landmarked buildings.
Although he sometimes lectures on Asian culture and international relations as an adjunct professor at places like Fordham and New York University, his retirement is giving him time to take singing lessons and prepare for a cabaret performance.
When he's out at night, he never takes a cab because he knows too many people who have been in accidents. Instead he takes a bus that lets him off half a block away or the subway. Even at night, he says, "it's not a menacing place.S
And it is quiet. He found the Upper West Side very noisy, filled with trucks. In Mott Haven, he hears church bells on Sunday, and an occasional rooster. But his friends from Manhattan are dubious. "The South Bronx is the kiss of death to them," he said. "The area still has a horrible stigma."
He has quickly become a part of the neighborhood, getting to know its quirks, like its profusion of stores selling beepers. Around the corner, he can buy a good cup of coffee for less than a dollar.
"There's everything you want," he said, "but no tonic water, no New York Times." He has met a lot of people, like the couple down the street who have lived there for 50 years, and his neighbor, who the other day showed him pictures of her grandchildren.
When he dropped off some old clothes at the church up the street, the pastor reciprocated by giving him a funky lamp with pink and green glass, which now shares a room with his lacquered chest from Burma and clay jars from Indonesia. The beat policeman who is legendary for his good relations with the residents of Mott Haven stopped by to introduce himself and spent a half hour touring the house.
When he walks around the neighborhood with a visitor, showing off the antique shops on Bruckner Boulevard, the new houses selling for $300,000, and the recently sandblasted facades, people know him and say hello.
"In this neighborhood," he said, "oversharing is a virtue."

He is working with friends, many from Indonesia, to renovate the house, which is on a landmarked block. (Photographs by George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)
